They're headed by Whitaker, the only one with a heart as demonstrated much later on in the movie, in one scene he shares with Stewart, that I really liked, almost as much as I liked this film. His outcome, was one that sucked in the film's ending. This was the only thing that faulted the movie. Whitaker, accompanied by a snooty, younger, and sleazy looking guy (Leto, a trademark in character acting) really hasn't informed him about the third guy, for good reasons (hotheaded and detestable psychopath, Yoakam- Slingblade) a performance that'll scar you. Foster and Stewart hold out in the panic room, only what the thieves want, is in that room, making for one claustrophobic dilemmas, you could say. As well as being a solid never slacking psychological thriller, the story really works from a realistic standpoint, which I liked, one stunt Foster tries to get rid of them, almost backfiring, causing Leto to lose his stack. A hairy standout moment. Foster's husband is a seemingly much older guy with stringy who must be loaded. We share a little time with him, near the end. What Foster and Stewart do in their circumstances is exactly what you would do in their position, where the same goes for our thieves after that moolah. Watching Leto, blowing his stack is fun, but as I said it's really the piece of s..t Yoakam's character that has us. You really want to see this guy go, the inestimable hatred between him and Stewart, frighteningly evident. At one point, he candidly shouts threateningly to her saying "What the F you looking at". Fincher to me is a really interesting director, with not a large inventory of films to his credit, but they are handpicked stories, and original, discounting Alien 3 of course. Panic Room, continues that chain of originality, as if an event, in the waiting, if only for a better ending and rosier outcome for Whitaker, who sort of becomes the hero. I actually know a couple of people who disfavor this film, one a video store clerk. You can't please everyone. Fine choice for a night of suspenseful viewing, where ever actor does us solid in their fine performances.

"Panic Room"  directed by David Fincher, tries to copy the style of Alfred Hitchcock. It is a creepy dark old house movie that contains many twists and turns in its plot, and holds a few surprises as well. Meg Altman (Jodie Foster)is separated and has moved into a large old brownstone town house with her daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart), formerly owned by an eccentric and paranoid multi-millionaire. The furniture has not all arrived and many boxes remain unpacked. In the house, the former owner had built a "panic room", a room that could be sealed off from the rest of the house and hide the residents if danger threatened.
 As luck would have it, three burglars intent on finding a large amount of hidden cash left by the former owner, break into the house. Burnham (Forest Whitaker) was the man who designed and built the panic room. Junior (Jared Leto) had worked for the eccentric. Junior has brought along a mysterious brooding and masked third member, Raoul (Dwight Yoakum) to help out. Of course, mother and daughter flee to the panic room and most of the rest of the film deals with the cat and mouse games played to get them to open the door.  Burnham just wants to get the loot. Junior harbors a secret and Raoul is a ticking time bomb. Meanwhile Meg's ex-husband Stephen who had been alerted by Meg before communication was cut off, arrives on the scene and is used by the criminals to coax the women out of the room. Finally, Meg is tricked out into the open and the crooks gain entry to the panic room. Then we learn that Sarah, who is still inside, has an unnamed illness which requires her to have an injection to survive. But how will she get her injection? By the way, this "illness" suggests diabetes although the disease is never mentioned. An injection of insulin would require a specific measured dosage and the patient would have to eat something immediately after the injection. In the film Sarah, appears to be given a pre-mixed injection but does not have anything to eat. If this was the case, she would have relapsed into the comatose like state she was in before. Anyway, eventually everything is sorted out and justice prevails. Jodie Foster is excellent as always and young Kristen Stewart does Ok as Sarah. Whitaker is good as the bad guy with a conscience, Leto is suitably sleazy as Junior but country crooner Yoakum is positively frightening as the psychopathic Raoul.  "Panic Room" is a pretty good claustrophobic thriller.

Any movie that builds an entire plotline around one room in one house is just begging for trouble. I don't care if that one room's outfitted like Chuck E. Cheese's restaurants; if you limit your setting, you're asking for yawns. But that's what Panic Room does. Sure, there's a lot of action - such as it is - outside the room - but even what isn't contained within the ultrathick walls of the safe place is contained within the relatively small house itself (or maybe just the ultrathick walls of the screenwriter's mind).The gist of the story is that Meg Altman (Jodie Foster), who's recently been divorced from her husband, a very wealthy pharmaceutical dude, is buying this upscale brownstone in Manhattan for her and her generic kid (although not a cute generic kid; looks like they ran out of "cute" at Child Actors R Us and had to settle for not-so-cute-but-oh-so-spunky). Even though the fee is more than she's willing to pay and even though it's a little weird looking, our plucky heroine throws caution to the wind and buys the place. And immediately moves in - which, you homeowners know, happens with all the frequency of a loan getting approved quickly.The place has this complicated security system - it doesn't look all that large, frankly, but the system separates the house into zones, all "armed" at night. Sounds safe, right? When the house was being shown to Meg, she noticed that the master bedroom was smaller than it should be - surprise! There's a hidden room! Oh, what fun! What's it for, you ask? It's explained to Meg that if someone breaks into the house, she can get to the room and call the police from the handy-dandy not-connected-to-the-main-line phone; even if the main line's cut, you see, she can still call Officer Bob.
Now, I don't know about you folks, if, while being shown a new place, I am told that the house has an awesome "safe room" in case someone breaks in - I'm getting the hell out of there. Wouldn't that tell even the biggest dunce that there's a crime problem in the area? I mean look - there's a friggin' security system! They're saying that a) people will break in, b) the security system won't do squat, c) you can't call the cops from the main line because they'll show up next week, so yay! We have this neato safe room for you.So to begin with, the premise is mired in utter stupidity. In fact, I sit here dumbfounded by its stupidity.Naturally, the first night Meg and her daughter Sarah are sleeping in the house, someone breaks in. Three burglars are there to recover something from the panic room's vault, but of course they don't expect anyone to be in the house. Okay, common mistake. One of them, Burnham (Forrest Whitaker), almost decides to call off the thing, since people are in there and he's got this thing against hurting people, and all that. But don't worry, he's soon talked out of it by Junior (Jared Leto), the nominal head of this happy bunch, which also includes the unexpected Raoul (Dwight Yoakam - didn't he used to have a music career, or something?).Whoosh! Meg and the youngster rush to the panic room, where they proceed to panic.A lot of contrivances abound. For one thing, Meg's claustrophobic, so she has problems dealing. For another, Sarah is diabetic, a fact that plays an unfortunate major role in the movie. Can Meg save her child before the bad guys get to her? Oh, can she?You know, just as an aside, I remember when Forrest Whitaker was just starting out in show biz. Remember Good Morning, Vietnam? That boy made some great career moves - Smoke was another. He's a great supporting-role kinda guy. It's just a crying shame this movie depends on him so heavily. He's the only one - yes, only one - who turns in even a decent performance. And since he's a bad guy, I should have been rooting against him, right? Ha! Guess again, Dr. Watson. I was hoping Burnham would escape.Jodie Foster, on the other hand, gives one of the most constipated performances of a lifetime. Did she check out her contract before agreeing to this crap? This woman's won OSCARS, for crying out loud! Geez, they couldn't get Ann Archer to do this role? Or Christine Lahti? Or Kathleen Turner? Or anyone else whose career has slowed down a bit?Eleven people, including me, were in the theater when I watched this movie. Eleven! It's a new movie, too! And because there were 11, I tried my darndest not to laugh out loud at the moronic dialog, inept direction, and incompetent camerawork. Really. I tried hard. But failed. I mean, I didn't want to embarrass myself, much as the actors onscreen were embarrassing themselves.Oh, and to add more insult to the whole shebang, the director is the same guy who brought the creative Fight Club and Seven to the big screen. Talk about slumming!This turkey is rated unwatchable. The movie was somehow allowed to rise from somewhere in the murky bowels of Mother Earth to fester like a cold sore in the mouth of the American audience.

I have varied opinions on Director David Fincher's thriller `The Panic Room'. Please don't panic! I will state my opinions in just one paragraph. Jodie Foster stars as an overprotective mother of an androgynous diabetic teenager. They are entrapped in a home security room nicknamed The Panic Room after burglars invade their two-story New York residence. Forrest Whittaker, Dwight Yoakam, and Jared Leto co-star as the argumentative perpetrators. `Panic Room' is intense and Fincher's direction was secured enough not to be invaded with negative reviews. However, the film's cause of alarm was in its staid screenplay. `Panic Room' is not enticing enough to break into, but there is no need to panic if you do decide to enter `The Panic Room'. *** Average

Review title: Formulaic yet effective - Foster brilliant as usual
Review_body: (7/10)Isn't it amazing when Hollywood takes an unbelievable script, adds a world standard actress (Jodie Foster), deft camera work and a score by a recognized master (Howard Shore) and turns out a movie that, grudgingly, we have to admit is pretty good? I don't mean it's a work of art, but the flimsy premis (a woman and her teenage daughter trapped in a house with three burglars, spiced up with the addition of a high security "panic room" in that house) kept me on the edge of the seat for an hour and a half. Nail-bitingly good.

Review title: A good, effective thriller, kept above average by a skilled director and a committed cast
Review_body: Throughout the '90s David Fincher emerged as one of the most talented and interesting American directors of his generation, delivering four bold, fascinating films, two of which (Se7en and Fight Club) stand out as decade-defining (alongside the likes of Pulp Fiction, Magnolia and other gems). This is why his fifth feature, Panic Room, may seem an odd choice at first: a straightforward thriller with none of the director's typical shocks and twists, it is as close to mainstream as Fincher has got thus far. But in his hands even a conventional story manages to rise above the standard level, so while it isn't a genre classic, the movie is professionally executed and very likely to please most viewers.The film gets its title from a bunker located in a New York apartment. Once you enter this bunker, you are completely safe from any external threats. But what if the burglars who break into the apartment are actually looking for something that is inside that room? And what if they are led by the guy (Forest Whitaker) who designed the whole security system? These are the questions Meg Altman (Jodie Foster) and her daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart) will have to answer as they embark on a cat-and-mice game with Burnham (Whitaker) and his associates, the edgy Junior (Jared Leto) and the cold, gun-carrying Raoul (Dwight Yoakam).If handed to another director, David Koepp's script would probably have been turned into something overly contrived and unconvincing. Fincher, on the other hand, embraced the realistic aspects of the concept and manages to get most of the tension out of a believable scenario, with the exception of a few set-pieces (the burning propane especially) which, as superbly achieved as they may be (Fincher is a real camera virtuoso), simply are hard to buy in this kind of film. The other key element is the characters, who, thanks to the actors portraying them, manage to convince despite being fairly archetypal (this is particularly true in the case of Foster and Whitaker: they manage to save roles that could have been awful if miscast), and the tension between victims and crooks (and within the latter group as well, thanks to terrific work from Leto) is consistently palpable and real.As for the trickiest aspect of a film like this (how to end it), that is actually the only point where both writer and director fail to deliver, the conclusion being too flat and unsatisfactory if compared to the premise. Prior to that, however, there isn't a dull moment in the whole film, proving that even when he's going mainstream Fincher is capable of doing something a little bit more interesting than the usual Hollywood production.

(Flash Review)A separated woman and her daughter move into a cold and spacious New York condo previously owned by a paranoid wealthy person who installed an elevator and surprise surprise a highly secure panic room. During the first night (which felt a bit rushed) three robbers, one with a conscience, break in with a plan to steel something valuable inside the panic room. The rest of the film is them trying to break into the panic room where the mother and daughter have locked themselves in. Will the thick metal walls keep them in and the robbers out? Watch while the thieves wrestle with that challenge as well as their own erratic personalities. The film's color pallet uses virtually zero color; just a couple mutes reds and not only for blood. ;-) The camera is an invisible character and frequently in quiet motion with non-human direction to paint the picture of the 'large' New York apartment of which the entire film is contained. The story was solid and provided ample tension yet felt a little pedestrian or par for the course. Fincher's direction and eye made this better than it should have been.

This film is said to have a budget of forty-eight million dollars. Half of that could well have been spent on the destruction of the house cum palace in which all the action takes place. How much action can there be with such a small cast and restricted scenes? The pleasing answer is quite a lot.This is a slightly off-beat thriller; three dudes with bad intentions break into the house in question hoping to find it empty save for a massive hoarde in bearer bonds under the floor of the panic room. Unfortunately, the new owner has moved in ahead of schedule with her daughter - who might be mistaken for a boy the first half hour, although no one is likely to make that mistake now, even though Kristen Stewart still wears her hair short.When the bad guys are unable to get their hands on the goods, a game of cat and mouse ensues. One is far more ruthless than the other two, and they end up turning on each other. The grand finale is rather obvious with the least bad of the crew, who is clearly a reluctant participant, finding salvation, even though he will clearly face years if not decades behind bars.There is not a lot more to it than that, but many far more spectacular productions have promised more but delivered less.

PANIC ROOM is a fun suspense-thriller with some great characters and surprising moments. The single setting is utilized well. Fincher's editing and cinematography really elevate the material as well, immersing the viewer in the setting. I will say the movie is WAY too long for what it is, but I think it gets panned more than it deserves just because it isn't FIGHT CLUB. This isn't art-- it's popcorn entertainment, perfect for a cold October night.

Review title: Tension-Packed Hollywood Take on a Hitchcock-Type Premise
Review_body: I missed the opening credits and a few minutes of back story of "The Panic Room" but was still pretty much able to follow all the action. And wollop it comes fast and furious. David Fincher's directing definitely added to the excitement, and it's nice to see that today's filmmakers have seen Hitchcock movies, and Hitch would have loved blonde Jodie Foster I think.But excitement is also added because the characters are quite unpredictably individuated, particularly the bad guys.Howard Shore's music keeps the suspense keyed up without being obtrusive.When Hollywood does what it does well, we can have a crackling good time!(originally written 5/19/2002)

Review title: Excellent, nail-biting, edge-of-your-seat suspense ride that will leave you with goosebumps all over your body and take your breath away
Review_body: Wow! In my opinion, PANIC ROOM is an excellent, nail-biting, edge-of-your-seat suspense ride that will leave you with goosebumps all over your body and take your breath away. When I first saw it, I didn't exactly get goose bumps all my body, but my breath did get taken away. When the burglars (Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto, Dwight Yoakam) broke in, I let out a huge scream of terror. From the moment Meg (Jodie Foster) and Sarah (Kristen Stewart) got into hiding, I thought to myself, "Don't let anything bad happen to them! Please!" I also took quite a few deep breaths to prevent myself from screaming any more than I already had. On the bright side, if you ask me, the house was very luxurious and spacious. Now, in conclusion, I give this excellent, nail-biting, edge-of-your-seat suspense ride four stars.

Review title: Suspenseful; and Jodie's performance is awesome
Review_body: I am, since the age of 14, a huge Jodie fan; I began with several of her flicks (the Lecter flick, of course; and two other movies), that I still cherish above other Foster vehicles. And even in this thriller Jodie's role is strikingly sharp, intense and focused, beautifully crafted, and also amazingly delightful, likable; one of the greatest actresses. It's true that she's also highly sexy. As a matter of fact, Jodie is a terrific thriller actress. She's equally able in such physical roles. It's an enthralling good hostage thriller, rather akin to DESPERATE HOURS, and implicitly much better stuff than, say, the DIE HARD franchise. And it's the incomparable Jodie who makes this flick eminently worth watching. The pace is frenzied, and the suspense is genuine and enjoyable. Every Fincher flick, however well made, has nonetheless flaws and proofs of clumsiness. Jodie's role is far above the value of the movie. I mean, she's gold, she's incomparable and stunning. A great actressand an especially great actress for thrillers. Jodie's roles are not only incomparably focused and clean, they're extremely lean as wellagility deprived of stuffing, of rubbishhallmark nononsense roles. It's like for a long time we didn't have actors for the thrillers; and now, that we have the performers, we don't have thrillers to match them. Several varyingly annoying things in this flick:--the scene with the two policemen at the door (if the cops supposed they're all listened to by the aggressors, the plainly telling Mrs. Foster how to act wasn't such a good move; the girls; the exhusband's (otherwise venerable) age; the 'Raoul' villain not being very messed up after he just got smashed with a hammer. In view of the ex's fortune, his age might be conceded.Otherwise, the movie's thrilling, suspenseful, nicely paced, and thin. Mrs. Foster is an awesome actress, and she makes a nice B. Willis/ McCulkin here.A reliable performance from Whitaker, who typecasts as a postmodern AfroAmerican Gabin , and 'Raoul' makes a stunning villain (Yoakam).

Review title: Honestly one of my favorite action/thrillers!!
Review_body: This film is smartly written and very well made, and omg Jodie makes this movie!!! Great acting from everyone on board, a few twists and turns, very exciting moments, and intense action sequences make for a great film and a heck of a fun time!! Seriously who could give this a 1?? This is a quality piece of cinema, at least as far as action movies go. Kristen Stewart was great in her role. She really captured and nailed it, same goes for forest Whitaker and jared Leto. The movie focuses on its characters, it isn't just a lot of pointless action, I love a good thrilling action film like this that actually has meaningful characters. If you are a true movie fan, then I really don't see how you could think negatively about Panic Room. 8/10.

This may not be one of the best movies ever made, but it's as good as thrillers can get. The story is simple, yet unpredictable. The whole experience is thrilling, gripping and suspense. The actors were marvelous. I loved everything about it.

i really enjoyed this movie,, the idea that a panic room actually exisats is totally awesome i wish i had one,, Meg Foster is great in this,, and Forest Whitaker is pretty good as a bad guy with heart. the teenage girl is a little brat tho. apparently the mom get's this house for half of what it's worth, so they move in and are shown the panic room, it has it's own dedicated phone line separate from the house , which could be very useful. the family is attacked , bad guys are looking for some bearer bonds buried in the floorboards of the Panic Room of course , so the bad guys wanna get the teen brat and mom out of there,, all in all i thinnk that this movie is pretty darn good and i would recommend it to anybody.

Although it may seem a bit simple of times, especially in terms of premise, Panic Room makes the most out of its claustrophobic scenario and makes for quite an interesting and entertaining thriller- even despite its flaws. The film is largely led by its strong performance by Jodie Foster, as well as some rather good performances from a young Kristen Stewart and Forest Whitaker. Dwight Yoakam also gives the role all he has, and makes for a bit drastic, but cool villian to follow. Jared Leto seems to try a little too hard in his role as Junior, and his character and line delivery seems too anxious and over the top for it to feel anything except menacing. The film can be a bit formulaic at times, but it's fun nature, and strong direction from Fincher makes the film an absolute blast to watch for the majority of the runtime. It makes clever use of its characters and circumstances, and proves to be a fun B-movie adventure that I was glad I could catch before it was taken off of Showtime. In the end, Panic Room is not a great film, but a very amusing thriller with some strong qualities for such a small premise.
My Rating: 9/10

Review title: A worthy effort from David Fincher
Review_body: Panic Room may not be David Fincher's best films, but it is certainly one of his more thrilling. The claustrophobia, the suspense, and the inevitable question of "How will they escape?" makes this film a must see.My only beef with the film is the cinematography in the second half of the film. Its obvious Darius Khondji put his mark on the first half,especially considering how pedestrian the rest of the film looks compares to the first half.

This is not up to the directors other movies, not by a mile.  Its not up to other female-in-distress-in-an-urban-setting either, such as "Wait Until Dark" or "Lady in a Cage".But its all right time filler.  Jodie is not her usual mannered self, for which I was deeply grateful, and the kid that plays her daughter is not overly obnoxious, but close..They are moving into what amounts to a castle, in terms of what most Manhattan apartments are.  The rent has to be six figures a month; most people pay $1200 for something the size of the panic room alone.Almost immediately, they are broken into.  They retreat to the 'panic room' and much to their horror, what the robbers are after happens to be in that very room.  The robbers are amateurs, almost bumbling idiots who couldn't break into a little girls diary, but they seem to think they have a chance at the safe in the panic room.I didn't mind the movie except for one scene in which the cops finally show up.  By now, Jodie has switched locales with the robbers and has to answer the door when they ring.  She is told to get rid of them and through video cameras, the robbers can verify that she does exactly that, but since they can only see and not hear, it didn't seem logical to me that Jodie would not vocalize the situation to the police officers, given the opportunity.  One of them is next to positive something is wrong and even suggests that she give a signal to indicate danger, but I guess the movie wasn't supposed to end there.  Nice to see that Jared Leto's arm grew back after "Requiem for a Dream" and its always a pleasure to see Forest Whitaker, although I found his character a little too nice, given his intentions.  7/10.

Review title: one of the best films of 2002
Review_body: "Panic Room" is a strong thriller that rewrites the rules of its genre with assured audacity.  Through inventive, Hitchcockian camera techniques (through the coffeepot handle, between pegs in the banister, etc.) and three-dimensional characters, director David Fincher pulls off the astonishing feat of confining us, like the characters, in a steel-walled 'panic room' reserved specifically for home invasion.  Jodie Foster shines in a strong female role that's the equivalent of her work in "The Silence of the Lambs," and Fincher proves--as he did previously in "Fight Club"--that he's one of our finest up-and-coming directors.8/10
Seeing Jodie Foster lay on her pillow, helpless, as shadows walk through hallways behind her, frightened me to the core.

Review title: Like a Good Game of Chess
Review_body: I'm reluctant to make lengthy comments about films that hundreds of others have already posted about because it seems like a waste of time, so I will just make a few observations about "Panic Room".The most important thing was that it instantly pulled me in and took me for a ride for the entire two hours. That does not happen often, particularly for a film that I was late seeing and therefore had tons of preconceived notions. I was pleased with how well they established the basic premise of the film at the beginning as, something that had seemed silly in the trailers was perfectly credible in the actual film. The $95 Million U.S. box office must have happened from word-of-mouth because the trailer simply does not do the film justice.There were only minor plot holes, although the lame way that Meg and her daughter initially got into the panic room almost derailed the whole thing. And I still find it inconceivable that $48 Million had to be spent on what is really a very small film. Since so little of the budget ever makes it onto the screen they would have been better served with the creative incentive of a smaller budget.Nicole Kidman was originally cast to play Meg but hurt her knee and had to drop out. I don't think they lost anything by bringing in Jodie Foster, I can't imagine Kidman doing any better, Meg's kind of brainy stubborn scrapper is Foster's specialty. And she is much better from a physical casting perspective as Kristen Stewart looks like she could actually be Foster's daughter. In fact, there were more that a few times when I momentarily got the two of them confused. This was very appropriate because "Panic Room's" heroines are not the usual film-fare mother and daughter (one strong and one weak), but rather a like mother-like daughter situation. I think Stewart has a great future in films (see "Speak" for a example of her ability to carry a whole feature) and it was nice that she got a chance so early in her career to work closely with Foster. I was particularly impressed with the pacing of this story and its similarity to chess masters hiding one line of attack inside another. The battle progresses much like a chess match, as pieces are lost the layout becomes less familiar and the alternatives fewer. As the two sides use up resources and get sucked in deeper, their earlier choices limit the choices that are available to them. This chess-like process holds until the very end of the film.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.
But Wig cannot act to save her life. She's not good in this or anything that came after. Everybody else did a good job.

Review title: Like a serious Home Alone. W/ Jodie Foster.
Review_body: I donno-this was passable, predictable, not that believable, decently acted, ummmmmm about what you expected. Watching the baddies wind up Inside the Safe room w/ Foster on the Outside in the last third of the movie wasn't Quite what I expected, esp. w/ her daughter locked in-but there ya be. It's Hollywood.I didn't really buy into some of the plot-twists, the phones not working, Forest saving the day at the end, Yoakum becoming 'Jaws' from the Bond flicks after a he gets hammered and falls 2 flights over a stair well, etc. C'mon that was really believable unless it was a Michael Bay movie, and this clearly was Not.Foster and Whitaker are fine. It's a decently paced suspenseful flick until you get into the last third, then-well you saw my points. It's cliché time.Good time passer, nothing more. Foster as always is good.**1/2 outta ****

The conceit sounds too good to be true: a mother and her diabetic daughter move into a chic Manhattan townhouse which has a panic room made expressly for emergencies. It so happens, it also contains bonds worth in excess of millions. Three thieves are after these bonds and will stop at nothing to get their hands on them. They break into the apartment, forcing mother and daughter to hide in the panic room while the daughter's medication is still on the outside. A progressively tense chess game between her, her daughter, and her captors ensues during the course of one long night.David Fincher hits the right note once more with this domestic thriller. Pointing as a reference to WAIT UNTIL DARK, he makes the narration as sparse as possible to get into the meat of the story. As written by David Koepp, nothing is laid to waste and no sooner than Meg Altman is in her apartment that her own security and that of her daughter's is put on the line and the mundane becomes more and more nail-biting as the situations become tense and threaten to veer out of control. Jodie Foster plays Meg with the perfect balance of femininity and steel this kind of role requires her to and Forest Whittaker is a great foil, a man caught on the wrong side of the tracks, who has a good soul.PANIC ROOM is one of those instant classics that asks for repeated views because even when there is the requisite moment of violence late in the film, it is believable and serves as an emotional outlet because of the anguish Meg and her daughter are subjected to. With one of those Hitchcock endings where things are best left to the viewer to determine just how events played themselves out, this is the thinking man's thriller, tight, compact, beautifully constructed. A must-see.

Review title: Good but not as good as his previous movies
Review_body: When Panic Room first came out, it made the biggest opening weekend of David Fincher's Career, coming off a box office bomb called Fight Club that soon became a hit DVD. It had Jodie Foster and marked the acting debut of a girl named Kristin Stewart, who would go on to star in the much bigger twilight franchise as well as Snow White and the Huntsman. This movie was recently shown on HDnet movies, with a 4k bluray release coming after debuting on Superbit DVD years ago on the same date as Monsters Inc.

Review title: Effective Performances From Last Minute Performers
Review_body: When it comes to thriller themed movies, Jodie Foster can deliver a fine punch.It's such a delight to see her stand up to defend herself against a group of baddies and to show them a thing or two of messing with her or her daughter in the 2002 film "Panic Room. Foster was a lat-minute replacement to play the leading protagonist role of Meg Altman after Nicole Kidman bowed down because of a knee injury. Most of the other cast members were last minute replacements including Kristen Stewart who replaced Hayden Panettiere as Meg's daughter Sarah, and country star Dwight Yoakam replaced Maynard James Keenan as Raoul. After a four year absence from his very successful 1999 film, "Fight Club", director David Fincher is back giving his fans a taste of Hitchcock-like suspense that will likely send shivers down your spine.According to Fincher, "Panic Room" wasn't intended to be grandeur in terms of cultural provocation, though the suspense remains throughout and the twists depicted here could come at you unexpectedly. At best, Fincher says it's generally a popcorn flick with relatively no outwardly implications, but a simple story on the quest of survival and protecting the ones that you love. Well that could be debatable. As long as I've known Fincher, he never depended on simplicity. Whether it was "Fight Club", "The Game", "Se7en", or "Alien 3", But the simplicity actually stems from the script by David Koepp. So here we have Foster starring as Meg Altman who was recently divorced and has custody of her young pre-adolescent daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart). She leaves the suburban life in Connecticut and purchases a 4- story house in the Manhattan Upper West Side. Their reason was to rub it in on her ex-husband Stephen (Patrick Bauchau) who dumped her to be with a sexy supermodel. Meg and Sarah gloomily consume pizza on their first night in their enormous abode. The ladies are oblivious to the fact that three intruders (Forest Whitaker, Dwight Yaokam and Jared Leto) are breaking into their enclave. Fortunately, the house is equipped with a panic room that also has surveillance cameras, steel door locks, a phone line. So they're safe in there right? NOT! Apparently the phone line to call for emergency doesn't work and now our victims are trapped. As an homage to Hitchcock's "Rear Window", and through the monitors we could see the thieves squirm their way in while Meg firmly tells them to get out of her house.The thieves are not gullible to play the whole "Home Alone" mind games that easily. Aside from the suspenseful elements, "Panic Room" does have moments of subtle humour to carry the film over. In a scene, Sarah uses a flashlight to signal a nearby neighbour (Andrew Kevin Walker) for help via Morse Code. When asked how she knew that trick, Sarah replied, "Titanic". It takes courage to laugh at your own expense over the cliches that has been utilized in suspense films and knowing that burglars visitation is not for a house warming party, their motives is to retrieve $3 million worth of bearer bonds and it's located in the panic room and one of the thieves is willing to kill someone to get it.What's refreshing is that in this suspense thriller is that it's no surprise is that it rains for the atmospheric effects, however the backgrounds are very effective in tone. Originally, Fincher wanted the Altmans to have their scenes in the dark, cinematographer Conrad W. Wall who filled in after a falling out with previous cinematographer Darius Khondji having our heroes squirm in pitch blackness letting the fear factor do all the talking. The camera is the star of this movie on its own as it guides us through the mansion, exploring all the rooms in this four-story house, while composer Howard Shore's music adds more intensity through each scene. Even though resting on a contrived plot, the performers do what's given to them. Leto shines as Junior as the hip rich kid, Yoakam in his role as Raoul sports a ski mask in the first half manages to become more sinister without it. Whitaker as Burnham is the more self-conflicted one as thief with some level of humanity even when the scenes become more violent. The bonding between Foster and Stewart feel genuine and never once does it feel corny or forced. Foster just kills it in this role, serious, focused and never meanders off in other character traits and even when she has to depend on her ex-husband for help and the supermodel answers instead she lets both of them know who's boss. Even with the level of intensity, Fincher assures you that this is not some mindless suspense thriller and the conflict of two bruised heroes against the dark atmosphere they never anticipated in has some food for thought moments of discussion.

Fincher has never made me sit up as a director of note and this film reinforces that view.Elegance in filmmaking here is limited to some hi-tech cinematography which makes the audience feel that they fly through furniture miniaturized to the size of a fly. Much of the film was filmed in near darkness. The plot development was most unimpressive. Facts were wrong (propane being lighter than air, for one). Why does one of the hoods cover his face in the beginning? What has the broken marriage to help with the screenplay unless Fincher sees the Panic Room as a refuge to that as well. But the end of the film makes you wonder if the film had any impact on the marriage.Jodie Foster, so impressive in "Contact" seemed dumber than her daughter--who I thought was her son until halfway through the movie.I keep seeing Fincher's films to spot an iota of brilliance but I have not seen anything that makes him an above-average director by world standards.

Review title: Is there something wrong with me because I don't hate this movie?
Review_body: Hmmmm, after reading the comments on this movie I'm thinking I've seen a completely different movie than all the other people on IMDb who wrote a review about it. Especially Jodie Foster's performance seems to be a point of discussion. Personally I liked what I saw. I'm not saying it is the best, most shocking thriller ever, but it sure was able to keep my attention from the first minute to the last.It's about a woman who left her rich husband because he cheated on her with a B-rank model. Because she wants to take revenge on him, she buys a very big, nice house with his money (of course, that's how angry women are! Hahaha), where she will live with her daughter. There is even a 'panic room', a room where they can hide as soon as they are in some kind of trouble. During the first night that they stay there, some burglars, who are convinced that the house is still empty, pay them a visit, because somewhere in the house the former owner had hidden a lot of money.Don't expect any special effects, explosions or other kinds of special things that they like to put in today's movies. This is a thriller like it could have been made 30 or 40 years ago. Perhaps that's what bothered some viewers, but does that mean that this movie can't be good? Not in my opinion. Something else that might have bothered some of the viewers may be the fact that you don't get any images of the city or the surroundings. All the action happens in the house, and the biggest part of it in the confined space of the panic room itself. I guess this may be a perfect movie for the people who loved Phone Booth. It's more or less the same principle, but this time in a house and with a woman that you don't love to hate. Anyway, I don't care what other people think about this movie. Personally I liked to see Jodie Foster play this role and I think all the actors did a fine job. The script was good, despite some minor flaws and the director did a very good job. What else could you possibly want? I give this movie a well deserved 8/10.

'Panic Room'. Is set in a colossal old 'brownstone' semi in New York.It looks big enough to garrison a regiment, yet an embittered mother and her daughter, mean to live in it all by themselves. It's expensive, but their husband/father - who has apparently run-off with some air-head - is apparently rich enough to foot the bill. In short; it's financial revenge. On the master-bedroom floor is the titular panic-room. It's a mini-fortress, almost impregnable by conventional means and self-sufficient.On their first night, three hoods turn-up to burgle. Unbeknown to mother and daughter, there's a floor-safe in the panic room. It contains what the villains are after.Mother and daughter flee inside before the villains can catch them. A siege ensues.For the most part, I found this a very tense, well-acted piece of drama. It definitely had its moments. Jodi Foster was good as the over-protective mother, Kristen Stewart was adequate as the rebellious daughter. The villains did their villain thing.I was a little nonplussed by the curious lack of colour throughout. It might well have been filmed in black & white. Perhaps it was meant to lend some noirish element; for me it was just inexplicably gloomy.I also enjoyed the fluid nature of the relationship dynamics. The nominal leader who ultimately goes to pieces and gets shot by the hard-man in a ski-mask. Later, after trapping his hand in the panic-room door, he himself is unmasked, gunless, a whimpering impotent. The 'expert' knows the criminal consequences of harming anyone whilst committing the robbery and means to avoid bloodshed at all costs. He, of course, has the most to lose. The police will soon realise that inside knowledge was needed. It can only be a matter of time before enquiries lead to him. He must be long gone without trace, almost proof positive of guilt. Yet he could never bluff it out because the mother and daughter would recognise him. I rather liked the ending, where an overhead helicopter whips all of the multi-million-dollar bearer-bonds into the air.There were a number of irritating little details, but by and large I overlooked these because the rest of the movie was sufficiently worthy.

Review title: It was supposed to be the safest room in the house
Review_body: This story centers around a divorced woman in her 30's and her daughter, who are caught up in a cat-and-mouse game inside their new New York brownstone when three burglars come looking for a hidden cache of cash. Mother and daughter hide in the "panic room," a secret room designed for just such a purpose, but still end up fighting for their lives...From the credits to the beginning, you will realize you are going to watch a movie driven by visuals. Now that is a good, I mean great, thing for the look of the film. Not only is that this film is visually extensive, it is also very intelligent. And let's not forget that is has been directed by the very talented David Fincher.Okay, if you have read the plot of this film, you expect it to be realistic, no? Well, you're wrong. On the contrary, it's unrealistic, in an encouraging and maybe disappointing way. If you want to watch this film just to find advice to help you when your house has been broken in, then the only thing you'll get is: Lock yourself in a room and call the police. There's nothing else. Seriously.But that doesn't drive me nuts. I really like it that the fact that it's unrealistic because it will actually be interesting. Come on, if the film was realistic, it would have been tedious and boring. I like the outlandish situations the characters get themselves into and I know that you would like to see how they get out of them, by using their INTELLIGENCE.That's what makes this film so great. You have a point of view on the goodies and baddies (surprisingly the baddies aren't clichéd) and you see them playing a chess game with each other. The cinematography is great and so is the score.The performance by Jodie Foster is really good, as always. Forest Whitaker gives us a sympathetic (unnatural characteristic for a baddie) and sometimes dangerous performance and Dwight Yoakam is down right sinister and ugly, in a good way.This is a well crafted thriller that will get your attention. It doesn't linger or goes out of steam. Instead, it keeps throwing you more original ideas after another until the movie finishes. The performances are great, the look really great, and the script is good. Want to watch a well made thriller? Watch this one.

I was more impressed by the camera direction than the story. Congratulations to the top camera man that has shot this film! Sometimes it remembered me Alfred Hitchcock but here the picture is better. It is not a boring film because every minute happens something. Okay there isn´t much substance and also not a top suspense atmosphere because you can imagine the next step. The action is set narrowly but director David Finch created anyway a good thriller. For having a nice Saturday evening the rent is worth. I give 8/10.

This is a professional thriller with some details, not common in American movies. And most of these details come from the camera work. It plays with you, and with the actors, but not that much that the story loses speed or thrill.This is a good composition. The script stresses at exactly timed points. You are not always surprised about the plot, but there are turnings sometimes, which aren't to be expected. And Jodie Foster is of course brilliant, although this is a mainstream character she is performing.This is better than the slightly overestimated "The Others". It is however another sort of excitement movie.

Review title: It could have happened to anyone
Review_body: The movie begins with nice images of an ordinary action of two people visiting a house they want to buy or rent. However from that moment on the sharp contrast of these apparently innocuous images with a sound track music full od ominous presage makes us to anticipate that something much more violent is going to happen soon. Well the images are not so innocent as that because as a matter of fact that house is heavily sinister and we don't understand why a young woman and her early teen-age daughter like it so much. So the inner view of the house combined with the sound track music make us shiver from the beginning. The foreseen danger materializes itself soon in the persons of 3 more or less awkward and somewhat human burglars that enter the house with the aim of finding a lot of money they know it's hidden in the panic room, a kind of inexpugnable bunker against burglars where the woman and the girl take refuge and close themselves in. Well I won't tell you the rest of the story of course which develops itself in a succession of events full of suspense until the final  outcome which will rivet your attention until the end. On the negative side of this kind of movies there is always of course a certain amount of clichés but anyhow in this case not very unplausible. All the actors play their parts with talent but not with a special genius. Though not a masterwork this movie will not make you feel you have wasted your time by watching it providing you are a movie fan of course.

Review title: A good home invasion thriller, Jodie Foster gives a great performance ( B+ Movie) My Ratings 9/10
Review_body: Exciting from start to finish, well acted and very well handling the suspense, "Panic Room" is a film that will keep the viewer in his seat until the end.

Review title: No Masterpiece, just a good thriller
Review_body: With David Fincher in the Directors chair, you could be forgiven for expecting a masterpiece (Given his previous successes), Panic room however, is no masterpiece it is just a good Thriller.Trapped in a Panic Room in their new home, Meg Altman (Jodie Foster) and her Daughter Sarah, are caught up in a game of Cat and Mouse with a team of Burglars who just want the money that is hidden there. Trouble is its hidden in the Panic Room.Originally expecting an empty house, the criminals are left without a plan, but still remain defiant in the face of defeat.With some Creepy and Dark Direction, and a solid cast. Panic room turns to be a good thriller, and sadly nothing more.8/10

Review title: Suspenseful, but marred by inconsistent tension levels
Review_body: With two excellent actors and a strong premise, this suspense thriller opens with potential. The basic premise is that new tenants to an apartment, a mother (Jodie Foster) and daughter (Kristin Stewart), inadvertently get caught up in an "inside job" robbery at the apartment building. They're in the wrong place at the wrong time.The ensuing cat/mouse pursuit, complete with a well crafted claustrophobic atmosphere, provide for what is usually an exciting story. The chess moves made by both sides are logical to the characters, building the plot and suspense level. Forest Whitaker (as one of the three criminals) and Foster deliver the convincing performances expected from these talented actors. However, weaker acting of others in the cast, and inconsistent direction, don't maintain the mood or tension. This weakens the film's effectiveness.The other two villains start out menacing, but when you see some idiot trap his hand in a doorway (and some other slapstick behavior), it's too awkward to take it seriously. The intent was clearly not a Home Alone type satire, but sometimes resembles it. The line reads by the the two dumb crooks, as well as Stewart, just aren't convincing; they each become caricatures. The latter's role is a tom-boy diabetic teen with an attitude, but she plays it more like a mumbling zombie that spikes her insulin shots with heavy depressants.Whitaker and Foster carry the film, and ultimately, succeed in saving it. The ending sequence works well, and has a nice irony attached. Good for one-time viewing, but you probably won't want to revisit it.

This was a decent movie, ok?  I will just say that right off the bat.  It's about Jodi Foster and her daughter who happen to buy what must have cost several million dollars, house in manhattan.  Oddly enough it came equipped with a PANIC ROOM.  And low and behold, some folks break into the house on THEIR FIRST NIGHT.  The Trip is led by the dude from Prefontaine who does a good job as a WHITE MAN with CORN ROWS.  Forrest Whittaker does a SUPERB JOB as always.  He is one hell of a good actor.
