Review title: A tight thriller that you have probably overlooked
Review_body: "Panic Room" is a well-made, really exciting thriller that stays interesting despite the limited location. This is one of those movies that I had seen years ago when it first came out. I'm not sure if I had simply forgotten or I hadn't realized how great this one was because at the time I was a dumb teenager but it really is terrific. The premise is pretty simple. A single mom (Meg, played by Jodie Foster) and her vulnerable daughter (Sarah, Kristen Stewart) move into a new house. The house comes with a panic room, a place where you can hide in should anything go wrong. A bunch of bad guys (Forest Whitaker, Dwight Yoakam and Jared Leto) break into the place, so Sarah and her daughter hide in the room. Trouble is, that's where the villains are trying to get to.There are many smart choices in the movie, one of which is to keep the cast small. For most of the movie we only get 5characters and that allows us to get to know them. You feel like you're inside the movie, studying everyone and trying to get the edge on them by observing their mannerisms and gaging their personality, just as the people on either side of the panic room are doing. While you're getting inside the characters' heads, a strong sense of urgency builds. I'm no criminal, but I know that with a robbery, you have to get in and get out quick. The longer the plot drags on, the worse it's going to get because you increase the chances of something going wrong and of you getting caught. On the side of our heroes, there are some complications that build too, so you've got Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart's characters that want to get out asap, and the thieves that want to get in. Everyone is either trying to find a way to trick the other party into letting them in or out of the room, or trying to find a way around the big door that's separating everyone, or trying to force someone else to do it for them. Because the characters are intelligent, they're always trying something new and it kept me guessing as to what was going to happen next. It's really satisfying to see a movie where people act logically; always trying to sneak past each other's defenses (both physical and mental/emotional) and you'll constantly be surprised by the new elements introduced. "Panic Room" is a terrific thriller that really cleverly uses its location, creates genuine thrills and exciting feelings of paranoia and claustrophobia too. (On DVD, September 2012)

There are too many anomalies in the story for this to be considered realistic, and without realism the viewer will not believe the story and therefore quickly lose interest. I won't detail the errors in case you want to watch it and make up your own mind. Let's say, Meg demonstrates some intelligence, but it appears to be selective and geared towards creating dramatic film sequences - maybe she knew her story would be turned into a movie?! Stupid script aside, the performances are all quite good and the tension is aided by good lighting and camera work, albeit said tension is lost due to aforementioned errors. We do learn a lot about the characters and some credit is due for that.However, with the viewer having invested some interest in a character, it seems pointless to undo all that good work by skimping on a decent ending. It may be logical in terms of the way the film is constructed, but in terms of the story I found it unsatisfactory.If you can stand the frustration and disappointment, it's worth watching for the good points, but as a film overall it deserves a low rating for sheer stupidity.

Review title: A Boring Thriller with No Thrills
Review_body: Except for a couple of scenes, watching PANIC ROOM was like watching paint dry.  As a big fan of the director from his work on SE7EN, I had expected suspense and plot twists.  What I got was HOME ALONE with four letter words and gore effects.It was at least half an hour too long.  Well, it could have been an hour shorter, though: there's a scene early in the action where mother and daughter are in an elevator that no doubt had an alarm button in it.  But then it would have been a short subject.The scene where the bad guys try to pump toxic gas into the room and the last time the door slams shut are both exciting.  The camera work is awesome, the sound and music are great, and the opening titles are among the best I've ever seen.  But there's so much talk, talk, talk between the three very dull bad guys.My respect for Jodie Foster would have been greater if at some point she had just turned to the camera and said, "Look, I know how bad this is, I'm ashamed of myself for doing it and I know how bored you are, but do you have any idea how much they're paying me to do this crap?"

This movie was really cool.  The acting is superb, and the plot is very cool.  The movie follows Jodie Foster, a recently divorced mother, who just moves into an apartment with her daughter, Kristen Stewart.  Well just their luck, three burglars break into the place the first night.  The three burglars, played by Forest Whitaker,Jared Leto, and Dwight Yoakem.  The first two questions are obviously, "Who are you?" and "What do you want?" Well I'm not going to tell you anything more because I might spoil it. What we did learn is that Forest Whitaker is a burglar with a heart of gold, Jared Leto plays an idiot, and Dwight Yoakem is not a happy camper.Overall this movie is a good cat and mouse and the acting was over the top excellent. Rating 9 out of 10.

I'm really surprised people have rated this as high as 7/10. It was another one where the trailer made it look better than what it was. Occasionally Panic Room threatened to get interesting but never was more than ok.We had the entire cinema to ourselves for this & 20 minutes in I could see why. It was handy as we were able to regularly say to each other "why is she doing that" or "I thought that couldn't happen" without bothering anyone. Likewise we had a loud chat about what a stupid idea it was calling a boy Sarah, before eventually one of us suggested it may be a girl.Anyway, the film. The main problems (aside of the cliched to death, diabetic girl who needed her sugar intake) was the flaws & inconsistencies. I was aware of some beforehand & thought I could put up with them but they became really irritating. Leaving aside the propane gas error!(1) You had a panic room which you could only speak out of, not into. By the end of the film it had reversed & Jodie was speaking into it. There may have been a reason I missed, but even allowing for that would have created more questions.(2) We're told at the start there are sensors so the door of the room would not shut if something was in the way. Fine. What happens later? Jodie traps the villains' hand in there. Why did it not open again? If it was because the hand was between the 2 ultra violet sensor lines (and not through them) why mention it at the start at all? Forget the sensors completely & it would have worked better.(3) Then there's a brief allusion to Foster's claustrophobia at the start, that miraculously disappears without trace as the film went on.(4) Why tell the police she was fine, and then immediately proceed to smash all the cameras up? Surely the latter would've angered the villains' just as much as the former.On top of that, what a gas lighter was doing in the room I weren't sure, nor why they couldn't have use the hole looking out to push something(s) through to gain help. The ending also seemed a rush job, infact the final scene seemed of no purpose whatsoever other than to suggest the moral of the story was 'don't live in a big house.' The directing from Fincher (and I enjoyed Seven & The Game) become a tad over the top by the end moving through wall, so did the over emphasis on darkness.The story could moved along quicker but was best suited to a one hour TV crime show , not a film. But even allowing for the Home Alone esque villains, the acting wasn't bad & I've still seen a lot worse.3/10

Review title: Skilfull thriller, but disappointing for Fincher
Review_body: "Panic Room" is all in all a very thoroughly made thriller. The camera work is outstanding, the suspense is built up very professionally, and the whole thing comes across as quite believable, although there are of course some minor plot holes (for example, how is it possible that the ski mask guy got his hand stuck between the door?). The acting is good and especially Forest Whitacker's character is very likeable in spite of the fact that he's a bad guy. But still, seeing that this movie is directed by one of the most promising and brilliant directors of the past decade, having brought us movies like "Fight Club" and "Seven", it's simply way too standard: there's a happy end, there aren't any major plot twists etc.Very enjoyable, very high production standards, but ultimately a bit disappointing.*** out of **** stars

Review title: Say What? The script's the thing...
Review_body: I watched part of this film on 'Rogers Pay-TV' after seeing the nifty trailer on iTunes. About 15 minutes in, I wished I'd spent my $3 on a really good cup of coffee instead! Then, I started to read the reviews here at IMDb and realized that I was witnessing a murder in progress--a murder of the suspense-thriller genre.Since the camera work and cast are first class, how does one create such a muddled flick? Simple: the script. High school kids can't really act, but when they perform 'Oklahoma' or 'Fiddler on the Roof', the presentation is usually passable. Why? good script.There is no camera work at a live presentation of one of Shakespeare's plays, even using unknown but gifted performers - yet the final product is generally intriguing. Why? good script.A compelling actor like Hugh Laurie, Anthony Hopkins, Ralph Fiennes, or {fill in name of your fav American actor here - don't want to hurt your feelings - you get my point} could sit in a chair and stare at a live audience, or at a single camera for 2 hours - you'd be spellbound if they spin a good yarn, but only if they had a good script.But without a script, even the best actors toil in futility. Forest Whitaker is always brilliant. Jody Foster has 'A'-list talent. Jared Leto plays a good 'bizarro-type' (try his understated performance in 'Switchback' with Danny Glover) and Dwight Yoakam has the chops to 'weird you out' in bit roles (made me shudder in 'Sling Blade'). How could such a roster produce this piece of junk? Bad script. A revealing clue that the writer tanked the screenplay is when the bad guys show up and start cursing for no particular reason. The 'script' probably reads 'the bad guys show up and start cursing for no particular reason'.The array of dumb things in this film, listed here at IMDb, seems endless, but I'll add one more (apologies if someone got it before): Jody and daughter are using a flashlight to signal a sleeping neighbor for help,100 yards away. He wakes up, looks out his window and.... and.....and... they stop flashing the SOS and they begin to holler 'Help Help Help' (through a rainstorm). He can't hear. He goes back to sleep. Darn it - I hate it when that happens.Finally - looking for a good cast, nifty camera work, decent performance, and forgivable minor slips in logic? try 'Red Eye'! the difference? good script.

Mother and daughter move in a big house, learn about secret room and become victims of robbery the first day they moved in. Three guys with totally different motives for robbery are looking for couple of millions hidden inside house. From the start Fincher shows us some pretty nice directing of the movie and how camera goes from scene to scene. After Meg realizes that they are in trouble she picks her daughter up from sleep and manages to get inside panic room. Now movie turns into a big thriller story which has it's high and low notes that sometimes get too dull and just have no sense. Considering that Meg and Sarah are unable to contact anybody only thing left is to wait and after Sarah gets seizure attack movie really speeds up and gets to a different pace which is more exciting than the one before and now there is a lot of violence, action sequences and even some pretty tense moments that really kicked in at right time. Jodie Foster played Meg and she was very good as well as Forest Whitaker that played one of the intruders and his character was a really nice touch to the whole story. 3/4
So Jodie foster phones her husband to tell her she needs help as there are 3 men in the house and what does the old man do? He comes alone lolUtterly stupid

Average suspense yarn where a young mother (Foster) and his daughter (Altman) are enclosed in a fortified room inside an old mansion while harassed by a bunch of bad guys who are searching for a fortune concealed just inside the safe security room. An original premise that receives a electric but otherwise routine treatment by Fincher. Anyway, you will find some good moments here and fine performances (although the dialogue is not the main point here) especially by Yokam as Raoul, a violent and cruel killer. I give this a 6 (six).

Review title: Falls somewhere in-between Home Alone and Funny Games.
Review_body: Through the lens of David Fincher and the pen of David Koepp comes this simplistic, but highly polished home invasion thriller that while being one of it's directors more incidental films, is still a hugely competent effort with more than enough to recommend it by. Meg Altman (Foster) and her daughter Sarah (Stewart) have just moved into their new Manhattan pad. Built into the master bedroom is a state of the art panic room and – 'whaddya know!?' – on the first night there's a break in. And so begins the film. Just like in his previous feature film Fight Club, David Fincher cleverly opts for CGI to create some otherwise impossible visuals as the camera prowls and glides around the huge house with an eerie grace prompting some good early tension. Once the break-in happens and we get acquainted with the invaders, some of that tension dissipates, indeed there's one comical moment in which a slightly burned Jared Leto reacts in a way that recalls the bungling burglars of Home Alone , but thanks to a menacing turn from Dwight Yoakam the balance is never tipped too far that way and we're never allowed to fully relax. Like all good survival horror's, Panic Room works like a fun puzzle as it often gives you the opportunity to mull over what you yourself might do in similar circumstances. Good direction makes Panic Room a functional suspense thriller that while in terms of classic status could never be mentioned in the same sentence as Se7en or Fight Club, still helps it stand tall in a long line of the old school Friday night-in popcorn rentals.

Panic Room is one of those rare movies that features less than 10 actors and a set piece acting as a character in the film. While thin on story, there is plenty of action that helps sustain the movie from start to finish. Jodie Foster plays Meg Altman, a newly single mother who moves into a posh Manhatten home with her daughter Sarah, played by Kristen Stewart. The first night they live in their new home, a team of robbers (Forest Whitaker, Dwight Yoakam, and Jared Leto) attempts to extract contents from the previous owners of the home late at night, setting in motion the cat and mouse game that supplies action throughout the movie. The house is outfitted with a "Panic Room," a solitary fortress that allows the home's owners to lock themselves in, the bad people stay out. It's a great plan, except the out-going telephone service has not been hooked up yet, so the Altmans are locked in the room, and the robbers have to wait from them to get out--what they are looking for, millions of dollars in stocks and bonds are located inside the room. For every move the crooks make, the two ladies have to make a counter-move, each time you think the girls have come up with a brilliant idea to get them out of their problem, something else goes wrong. There is a truly scary moment when gas is used to try to suffocate Meg and Sarah out, you can imagine yourself trying to gasp for breath. Beyond that, there are tense moments, but nothing groundbreaking. It's a solid suspense thriller, and it looks really good. Forest Whitaker plays the role of the crook who has some morals, he doesn't want to hurt anyone, he just wants the money, very very well, by far the best performance in the movie. There is a remarkable camera pan from the bottom floor of the house to the roof, the camera had to pass through a window to finish the shot. But overall, it's not a movie that really stays with you forever, but is good for about 2 hours of entertainment.

This movie does most things right. It's creates a good amount of tension even if it is some what predictable. Camera work and some shoots are really good with the setting working really well. The negatives about the movie are that some of the CGI is bad which seems out of place and at times the plot seems unbelievable. It show cases its story well. If your a fan of tense movies you will like this one.

My Rating: * out of ****.I saw Panic Room in the movie theater because I thought the trailer looked good. When I was finished I thought What The Hell. I wasted near 2 hours of my time watching this piece of rubbish.First Off, the acting is truly a disappointment. Jodie Foster is a good actress, no doubt, but she is just really unconvincing here, but in a way I dont think she was right for the part. I kind of wish Nicole Kidman took the role instead. The Girl is irritating. Forrest Whitaker and Jared Leto are decent. The Other guy is stupid.There are interesting shots in this movie, but thats just showing off style for its almost complete lack of substance. This movie was one of the worst ones of 2002.

Am I the only guy that has really disliked every David Fincher film to date. I've seen them all. Alien 3- by far the worst of the series.(I loved Alien Resurrection.) Seven- not too bad, but so so bleak. The Game-worst Michael Douglas film ever.  Fight Club- Never has a film begun so promising and ended up so terrible.  Think I was loving the first half. Panic Room-  From the terrific opening credits to the last frame,  I loved it.  Yeah it's one of those movies where the characters have to do a whole lot of implausible things to move it along, but man it moves. And credit must be given to Fincher as well as the terrific cast. Howard Shore's score is perfect. See it in the theatres if you get a chance.  I think it will lose a lot of it's impact on the home screen.
David Fincher's Panic Room is full of suspense, dramstic moments, and stella performances, particually Jodie Foster and little Kirsten Stewart.

Review title: A great thriller that didn't have to have "killer jumps out of closet" screams
Review_body: Panic Room is a different thriller from the rest. Scream made you scream, at some points. I Know What You Did Last Summer just stunk. Panic Room doesn't really do any. Director David Fincher didn't need to do any of this because the movie thrills you with a suspense I haven't figured out yet, but I liked it. Even though I was hoping to at least get one scream out of me, I was disappointed because it didn't. But overall, a great film.9/10

*May Contain Spoilers*"Panic Room" is a really good movie. I remember seeing it in theaters a few years ago and now I just finished watching it on TNT. The acting was really good, the special effects was great, and the plot was so suspenseful. Some parts of the movie were even scary."Panic Room" tells the story of a mother and her daughter who move into a brownstone in New York City only to be invaded by robbers on their first night in their new house. The best scene in the movie is when the robbers are breaking into the house.Overall this is a really good movie and I suggest everyone should see it. I give this movie 10/10 stars.

Meg Altman is a single mother who is going through a divorce and just moved in separately with her pre teen diabetic daughter Sarah. She has bought a new home in New York which is practically a mansion. For their amusement this mansion has a room called 'Panic Room'. This room is equipped to keep people safe in the event for an emergency. And when some burglars comes to steal some thing the only safe place Meg and Sarah can find to hide is the panic room. But things start to become quite tense when they realize that what the burglars are looking for is also in the same room. While the bunch of crooks plan on how to get inside the room, Meg and Sarah has to look for a way to get help from the outside world. Panic Room is a very thrilling ride. It takes place 99% inside the mansion and over night. The sequences builds tension minute by minute and every move made by the burglars and the home people becomes tense every time. For the viewer it's a game of hoping for the best. And this packs good performance by Jodie Foster (Meg). When her kid starts to get sick she becomes desperate to find help. And she makes several very risky moves keeping her life on the edge. One other major reason for the success of this movie is the cinematography. Especially the sequences which require very dramatic camera movements and long shots combined with CG and moving cameras are done very skillfully. The viewer actually feels how big the house is and how you can really move in and around about it. This was directed back in 2004 by David Fincher way before he won the best director award at Golden Globes for 'Social Network'. And he actually nailed it.more at flickshout.tk

This film is worth seeing in the theatre.  It has special effects of sound and visuals that are intriguing.  Jody Foster and the entire supporting cast give a rivetting performance.  The camera motion is indredible to watch, and though not a 10 it deserves at least an 8 on the 1 to 10 scale.

Review title: Good Suspense Even If A Bit Uncredible
Review_body: The film "Panic Room" is about a recently-divorced mother, Megan Altman, and her daughter who decide to move into an expensive home in a upscale big-city district. The home is striking in its three enormous floors, elevator, and a high-tech security system. The film gets its name from a room that was installed by the home's previous owner - the panic room. It is a safe room in the house, complete with its own air source, staple goods, video monitors, etc.Unbeknownst to its new owners, the house has a large sum of money hidden in it. A bunch of crooks, aware of this, break in late one evening. What ensues is a fight for survival for Megan and her daughter. The panic room becomes the apex of this struggle.Jodie Foster gives us yet another excellent performance as Megan Altman. And the director, David Fincher, displays some great creativity in the introductory credits. The names are shown in a 3D-block format that make them appear as signs within a city. He also does a good job in showing the passage of shots through parts of the house, such as the walls, ventilation system, etc. I was very impressed.Where "Panic Room" teetered a bit (*SPOILERS BELOW) was in things like the almost-too-ironic nature of Megan's daughter happening to be diabetic. The served well in the film's plot, but I felt it was far-fetched. Also, there is NO WAY Megan could have ignited that gas stream and not been burned to a crisp! That was definitely a stretch, although I confess to liking the suspense of seeing what would happen. Raoul's ability to hike up a flight of steps after being hit with a sledgehammer and knocked off a balcony, was...well, draw your own conclusions. All I know is that it is VERY unlikely he could get back up and then almost take out the entire family, especially with a crushed hand. One last point also bothers me. Forest Whitaker's character, Burnham, just doesn't feel credible enough. I understand his sympathy for the family due to his love for his own, but his actions flip-flop. First he is gassing them and next he is helping the little girl. I had trouble believing he would really return to stop Raoul."Panic Room" does a good job at delivering suspense and does so with some unique and quality shots. The cast, including Jared Leto's character and his idiocy, put forth a stupendous effort. The story is just shaky in a few places (why didn't Junior just wait until the family was gone to rob the place?). 6/10 P.S.: I guess the director didn't learn from "Die Hard"'s plot hole. Bearer bonds have traceable serial numbers on them. While it is unlikely the old man would have confessed the bonds' existence only to Junior, it is even more unlikely he (or anyone else) would be able to cash them without jumping some serious hoops.

*** SPOILERS ***Pretty much what you would expect: A bunch of robbers coming to hit a place they hear has a lot of money (think "In Cold Blood"); a sudden, unwelcome, and ultimately psychotic addition to the team (like any heist movie); a character with a potentially life-threatening condition (lots of movies where someone's trapped); and a single location (like "Bound"). All of this is no surprise since the screenwriter is the untalented David Koepp (who ruined the film version of "Jurassic Park").David Fincher uses lots of camera tricks to try to make the film more interesting, but it is ugly looking like a lot of Fincher movies. Lots of monochromatic interiors, for example. Howard Shore's film score is lifeless and uninteresting, typical of modern film scores.Of course, there are a lot of plot holes, chiefly, everyone's making a TON of noise throughout the movie, and no one hears a thing; we learn the police had been notified, but take an hour to show up; Foster's ex just walks into the brownstone without the police (or anything else) in tow; The former owner just leaves tens of millions of dollars in the safe; wouldn't you leave bearer bonds like that in say, a safe deposit box?Oh well, if you're gonna see it, turn your brain off. At least!****** (6 Out of 10 Stars)

Review title: Fincher's brilliant direction in a simple plot
Review_body: "Panic Room" (2002) is Fincher's fifth film, released after "Fight Club" (1999). In other words, few films could be expected so much from as what was expected from "Panic Room".And yet, Fincher does not rest at his laurels as a director. The technical execution is just as convincing as "Fight Club", be it related to cinematography (the closing shot, for example, is one of the most intelligent I have ever seen), editing or pacing. Also, Foster and Whitaker are stealing the show as usual from the both of them. However, it is in terms of plot that this can be seen as a lesser experience.In its own right, I think this is a highly focused and simple thriller that is both entertaining and effective in its storytelling. Recommended as a good thriller, and as one that deserves to be viewed in its own right rather than be compared to "Fight Club".

Review title: A thriller with a sense of reality.
Review_body: This thriller has nothing that could not happen in reality, and it gives us an image of what people are capable of for money.  Take Raoul (Dwight Yoakam):  is there a more bad person in the whole history of cinema?  Jodi Foster as Meg Altman is great and she is a good mother for her sick daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart).  Burnham (Forest Whitaker) looses all but he is not a criminal, and at the end one even feels sorry for his bad luck.  This is a great thriller because the actors are convincing and the script is really good.

Yes... a pretty good story... but underdeveloped in some phases. Especially when it's about the diabetic daughter. Take from a diabetic! And the finale of the film, the real end of it all - that was very dissatisfactory. Please don't release movies, before you got it all in place!

Panic Room is a 2002 film directed by David Fincher and starring Jodie Foster, Kristen Stewart and Foster Whitaker. This film has some crazy camera work, going trough the ground and trough the walls and even though some don't quite work for me, I'd say that it is the stand out part of the film because most of the camera work is really good and original and it explores the layout of the house very well, the best lar is easily when the thieves are trying to get in the house it's just incredible. But besides that I honestly don't think there isn't anything else great in the film. The acting is OK, it's not bad either but except for Forest Whitaker and Jodie Foster whose acting I find pretty good it's just OK. The story is also OK and it has a good premise but it's not very memourable.
Overall the film is still good and the awesome camera work definitely prevents it from being forgettable
6.9/10

Review title: ENTHRALLING, COMPELLING, AND JUST PLAIN GOOD
Review_body: The Safe Room ("Panic Room" sounds better!) cannot be breached by the three home invaders determined to get the millions stashed inside that room. The mother and her diabetic daughter, who just moved into the upscale Manhattan townhouse don't know it is there - and haven't even installed the phone system yet! They are trapped, with time running out and the daughter quickly heading for diabetic shock. The invaders will do whatever it takes to get into the Panic Room, or to find a way to get the frightened pair to come out. Such is the concept of "Panic Room" - and it works very well, although somehow I left thinking it could have been even better considering the cast.It is reminiscent of home invasion movies from "Wait Until Dark" to "Straw Dogs" - although there is no giant bear trap in this one. The three invaders do try some original stuff with propane gas and switching identities. At one point the situation is reversed with the mother outside with the gun, and the invaders in the Panic Room with her daughter. It all works very well to a claustrophobic, tension-filled effect. Jodie Foster nicely underplays the mother, and Forest Whitaker reprises his well-known "lovable bad guy" act to effect. Jared Leto is good as the whiny "brains" of the gang, and Dwight Yoakum correctly psychotic as the homicidal sadistic villain. Kristen Stewart is adequate as the generic kid.One of the more effective aspects of this film is the direction that well uses the architecture of the house; its sterile, scary atmosphere is heightened by the fact that there is almost no furniture or decor, they having just moved in. Very well directed.A good, entertaining movie. 8 out of 10!

I have to admit, this is perhaps the most excruciatingly annoying film I have ever seen. I didn't find it fun - I wanted to kill Jody Foster's character for being such an idiot!Five stars for the camera work. Only.

Maybe it was because of David Fincher that I was expecting a twist in the plot or at the ending, considering he's done it in most of his work from The Game to Fight Club, but it never happened.Very predictable thriller.

Panic room is a 2002 American thriller directed by David fincher starring Jodie foster, Kristen Stewart and Forest Whitaker. A brilliant suspense thriller that will keep you hooked from beginning to end. Was on the edge of my seat the whole time. Fantastic acting from all the cast with a good storyline. The camera work was incredible and was very well directed. I really enjoyed this movie and certainly entertained me . So if you get a chance watch it as you won't be disappointed you will certainly have a thriller of a ride. It's currently streaming on Netflix right now don't wait to long as you might miss it. Just a nice suspense thriller. Watch it !!!

I wish I could think of something passionate to say one way or the other about this movie, but in my view it's just a very run of the mill thriller in which a couple of good actors are wasted. Everything is predictable; the tension barely simmers. Watchable, not nothing special. 5 out of 10.

Surprised by how much I enjoyed this. The performances are great, particularly from Jodie Foster as the lead, but it's the direction that stood out to me. Fincher really helped to make me feel the claustrophobia that the characters were feeling, and that really helped in keeping me invested throughout the entire runtime. The dark colour palette helped to build the tension, and despite me initially being worried that the premise wouldn't hold my interest for the entire film, I was really engaged throughout. The two lead characters are well developed and the film is just exciting to watch on the whole. As far as negatives go, the burglars aren't particularly interesting. I liked Forest Whittaker, but the other two felt way too over-the-top, and it took me out of the film at a couple of moments. But overall, this was a great film that I'd definitely recommend.

When the movie came out, I was rolling my eyes thinking how could they make a movie like this.  Two hours about being stuck in a room that is impenetrable, how much excitement could there be?  But figuring David Fincher is going to direct it, I thought he might be able to make something out of it.The movie had the usual Fincher touches from Fight Club, and there were a few scenes where I could feel my heart beating.  But I could not say the suspense held on long enough for it to be fully effective.  It was basically many short break-out/break-in attempts in between rest periods.  But the rest periods were not like a commercial break, since there were still a feeling of despair during those time.  Also, I guess the writers threw in the diabetic daughter so that it would not just be a sleep-through for the women trapped in the safe roomThere were more than once where I keep thinking why those men did or did not do such and such (like take out the cameras or make a story up about getting access to the safe), I shouldn't have to come to those thoughts, especially when there are three of them there with at least one that has a brain.  Even a thing or two that Jodie Foster's character did came into doubt in my mind. She could have bluffed about calling the police with a cell phone she had when they showed that they cut the phone line.It comes down to the weakness of the script.  Lack of events to allow the director to do his stuff.Still, a decent movie.

I loved both 'The Game' and 'Fight Club', though didn't care for 'Seven'. But I didn't like 'Panic Room' at all.This is a movie conveniently written, and worse, you feel it. I don't want to give anything away since they are many "mini twists", which is what thrillers tend to be. However, once you see the movie, and think back, you'll see what I mean. There's one example where the robbers say they should have thought of doing a particular thing earlier. And that's the fundamental problem -- there are many things done in this movie to sustain the story or add suspense. Bottom line: I suppose if you don't analyze it too much, it makes for a thriller. But for me, I just felt it was a burden to see it through to the absolutlely anticlimactic ending. 4/10.-Mark

Review title: The worst yet from Fincher, and that's saying something.
Review_body: David Fincher is the most overrated filmmaker of his generation.  The only stuff from him that I like are his videos for Aerosmith during their early-90's social realism period.  I remember when everyone was all breathless about "Se7en".  I rented the video & I thought it was a stupid rip-off of "The Silence of the Lambs", with lots of pretentious camera trickery.  Then there was all the deep conversations about "Fight Club".  I saw it & thought it was even dumber than "Se7en".  Now comes "Panic Room", supposedly Fincher's least pretentious film yet.  This is the (unintentionally) silliest thing I have seen since "Deep Blue Sea".The plot as such involves a single mother & her 12-year old daughter moving into a "modest" 4-story 80,000,000,000,000 square foot home with "two bedrooms and one tiny bathroom".  The tiny bathroom is bigger than my entire apartment.  And in the master bedroom, there's a panic room where they can lock themselves in if the house is burglarized.  Which it is.  On the very night they move in, no less.  And as if that weren't contrived enough, the burglars want in the panic room.  But wait there's more:  Mom's claustrophobic.  And the daughter's diabetic & needs insulin shots every few hours.And if the plot weren't bad enough, there's the dialogue:  One of the burglars smashes a mirror with a sledgehammer while trying to get into the panic room, and another calmly says "That's seven years' bad luck."  And when the daughter is trying to calm down, she recites the titles of Beatles albums, starting with "Yesterday & Today".  How would a 12-year-old know about that album?  It went out of print before she was born & has never been issued on CD.And for over two hours, there are shots of things being *just* out of Jodie Foster's reach (apparently, the character's mother took Thalidomyde), alternating with a bunch of hare-brained schemes to get into (or keep people out of) the panic room.  I stuck around for the end credits, half expecting to see the screenplay credited to Lucy Ricardo & Ethel Mertz.There are good points to this film: the visual palate is interesting, and the cast do well with the material they are given.I have nothing against directors who throw in every trick in the book.  I admire Quentin Tarantino, Alfred Hitchcock, Peter Jackson, Sam Raimi, & Robert Rodriguez.  Unlike those other directors, however, David Fincher is bereft of any real sense of humor & expects everything he does to be taken ultra-seriously, not unlike Oliver Stone.  Stone, however, did a couple of honest-to-god masterpieces before going off the deep end into bizarre, over-stylized conspiracy theories.  Fincher has yet to make an even palatable film.  And the screenplay for this film begs for a director who doesn't take himself so seriously.  4 out of 10

Unless Brotherhood of the Wolf came out in 2002 (i'm not too sure), Panic Room is 2002's first best.  It's one of the most entertaining Hollywood thriller movies of the year, up their with Frailty, Changing Lanes and Red Dragon.  Funny and exciting. B+, 8/10

Yes, I know the "don't open that door" type of teasing is a big part of the scare genre. But even within the suspension of disbelief required for these type of plots - it has to make *some* sense within its internal set of rules. For example, the half-naked teenager is allowed to open the door where the monster is obviously hiding instead of calling the police but she is definitely not allowed to hand the chainsaw to Jason and bare her neck...
There were far too many of these *too* stupid and inconsistent moments in the movie which made it very annoying. It was obvious that the director wanted to show off 5 or 6 different "effects" and decided not to let the plot get in the way. Sorry guy, but even for a mindless scare flick, plots and characters matter too, that's why they have screenwriters and actors not just directors and cinematographers...I want my 8 bucks back...

I was surprised when I found out that this was a David Fincher film as it didn't strike me as the kind of thing he would make but just like some of his other films this is a really solid thriller. It has some moments of genuine fear and a really good cast, just a solid movie to watch, if you like films like Zodiac and Seven then you'll probably enjoy this.

Review title: It supposed to be the best thriller!
Review_body: The plot of the film is quite simple, and happened only on one night. The story goes when a single mother (Jodie Foster) and her daughter (Kristen Stewart) just moved into their new apartment and they found this room called Panic Room, which supposed to be the most safety room, in case an emergency happens. Soon after, they already find out what is really utilize of the room, when on that night, three assailant (Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto and Dwight Yoakam) broke in to they house. When the women realized what is going on, she and her daughter rushed to the Panic Room, and organized a battle to the assailants. The result is a perfect combination of heart pounding drama and enthralling thriller. David Fincher does a good director, and he succeeds to make a brilliant film. Of course this film is not award worthy, but manage to its own dignity with became the first class thriller.  Jodie Foster is good as always and so does with Kristen Stewart. She indeed here's to stay! Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto and Dwight Yoakam also display more than it need to make this film superb. Technically, `Panic Room' is in the good parts; good photography, good score, good audio etc. Like I said, it supposed to be the best thriller, because it perfectly combined drama and thriller became a good answer as a modern film's concept. Unfortunately, `Panic Room' is also fell on those typical Hollywood recipe for a thriller (watch it for your self to prove it!). Well, despite of that, `Panic Room' is always be one of my favorite thriller, came a long as `What Lies Beneath', `The Silence of the Lambs', `Scream' and `Psycho', and I certainly sure that you will feel the same. 8/10

Review title: I was expecting this to be annoying but it was a pleasant surprise.
Review_body: This is a nice neat thriller. The claustrophobic setting allows us to focus purely on the lead characters and motivations and actions with no extraneous distractions.The acting is good as you'd expect with the adult cast but even the child, Stewart, is watchable. With the sick daughter the danger was that this would become maudlin and emotional but it avoids that, the danger to her health is simply used to crank up the pressure as the film progresses.There are a few twists as hope is stripped from the pair in the panic room and as the criminals realise they won't be having everything their own way. There are some pieces of action throughout although the action mostly takes a back seat to the build up of tension.Over all there are enough surprises to keep you interested and the ending, although predictable, is done well.

I consider this to be a pretty sub-par offering from Fincher. An unmemorable and dire hour and forty five minutes awaits whoever watches this film. A fair bit of my dislike of the film stems from the aesthetics of the movie – The CGI was pretty mediocre and distracting (such as from the not-really-tracking tracking shots as we are taken around the house, through walls and keyholes and such). Panic Room has that crappy indistinct and cloudy look that a lot of modern movies shot digitally have, despite the fact that the movie was filmed with Panavision Panaflex Platinum cameras. In his defence, Fincher made this in 2002 and a lot of modern movies haven't moved on from this look, whereas he clearly has if you look at his recent films. With a premise that harks back to the days of Hitchcock, Panic Room sees Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart locked in their home's safe room, as a gang of robbers search the house for valuables. Unfortunately, events during the course of the film become so far- fetched and unbelievable that your suspension of disbelief kind of commits suicide and you know longer care what's happening because it's so ridiculous and contrived. The script is a bit dumb, which makes it all the more strange that Fincher directed this. Best Scene: The opening credits were pretty cool. Apparently it was worked on for a whole year!

Review title: Nice ideas, even better camera movement.
Review_body: Panic Room focuses on a woman and her daughter as they search for the perfect house.  They end up with anything other than perfect, however, when they discover that three thugs are looking for something in the safest room in the house.This "Panic Room" is meant to keep any intruders out and keep everybody inside it safe.  However, throughout the movie, the thugs are able to endanger the lives of the house owners over and over again, which seems a little unrealistic, considering it took many years to develop that room.But the good plot, characters, and camera movements are enough to outweigh any flaws that Panic Room might have.  Certain events in the movie really piqued my interest, and I was excited to see what was going to happen next. What could be done to the panic room?  What could the mother and daughter do to evade it?Actually, what kept me going was the question:  "What can they do with this movie?"  At first I was thinking not much could be done.  But a strange, semi-twisted plot caught me by surprise, and I was pretty impressed.The music is composed by Howard Shore.  I generally don't like him, especially with his work in The Two Towers, but in this movie his music is light and eerie.  It doesn't get in the way, and it's not screechy like horror movies.The most interesting part of Panic Room is the use of the cameras.  Just the way they move through floors, walls, or pan around in an eerie semicircle are extremely satisfying.  They really add to the movie.All in all, I was impressed with Panic Room.  It's not the best movie, and not without it's flaws, but it's worth watching.

This movie had a great trailer.and the movie is really good until the last 10 minutes where it just becomes a typical hollywood thriller.The Acting is great.but the movie lacks thrills,suspense and chills.but i have to admit forrest whittakers villain was a great character who is more interesting than the lead heroine.6 out of 10
Most intense movie ever. Really scary, loved it seen it many times.

Review title: Good Thriller that falls apart in the middle
Review_body: "The Panic Room" takes off like a rocket ship but then tends to fall apart in the middle with too many props that are only  there for the sake of the story and 3 references to other Hollywood movies that are 3 references too many. Forest Whitaker as always is great and Jodie Foster gives a competent performance. This is the only David Fincher film I've seen that I didn't absolutely hate with a passion but its still not the great film it could have been.
If suspense is what you're looking for, you've come to the right place.Excellent.Tight and taut throughout.

Panic Room is a disappointing film by David Fincher, who turns to be an inconsistent director. Simply put, it doesn't utilize it's true potential. Here's why.First of all the claustrophobic settings are used to little effect, apart from maybe the scenes where the burglars fill the panic room with gas, and the one with Altman trying to get out to fetch the medicine for her daughter. Then the reverse situation with Altman out and the burglars in is still not used to full effect.Then we have the slight irony of the security cameras. As the burglars break in, Altman and her daughter watch as the intruders move around their house. Not terribly sharp, but a nice touch nonetheless in this age of reality shows et all.Finally there seems to be a very faint touch of symbolism, with the money hidden in the bourgeois mansion inhabited by it's upper class denizens, the lower class burglars breaking in, the most humane of them almost making it, but then surrendering to the police. The final scene with the money flying in the air is nice.But despite Fincher's hints at what could be social commentary, this is mostly a generic action thriller, deplete with Hollywood-type slow motion scenes etc. It does show though Fincher's evolution as a director, using some fairly elaborate angles and shots.

Review title: I've seen this movie several times and I've never gotten bored
Review_body: PROS: JODIE FOSTER, little KRISTEN STEWART, and FOREST WHITAKER give one of the most passionate and heartfelt preferences of their lives. You could feel for every character, you really were able to see each character as a person and not just as a figure. This is both the actors and directors accomplishments. The director said what he wanted the characters to be like and the actors took that and transformed the people on paper to people in real life. I was captivated by this in general because it gave that extra bit of tension to the film. I was more scared for each person than I would've been if they just acted fake. The other thing that I noticed and appreciated was the story line. It's common to see films with different settings, different motives, and different characters being put together and having the film called creative, but this film was actually creative. They took one location and used every bit of that location to the fullest. They also didn't have any character that was basic. Everything that was done in the movie was mostly original which gave the film that extra umph the movie needed.CONS: The ending felt a little too concise for my liking. I wished that they found so room to give the movie a slightly more resolved finish.www.chorror.com

Review title: Suspenseful, But Nowhere Near Fincher's Previous Work
Review_body: After delving into a different dimension with Fight Club, David Fincher has returned to the genre that helped realize his brilliance.  Panic Room brings Fincher back into the suspense game, directing Jodie Foster in a thriller that finds her forced to retreat into the room of said title.David Koepp (Stir of Echoes) scripts this potboiler about a recently divorced mother (Foster) and her diabetic daughter (Kristen Stewart) move into a New York home whose previous owner had a panic room built in; basically it's a room surrounded by steel and filled with surveillance monitors, medical kits, and water to last for days.  It's a good thing, too, since on their first night, three burglars (played well by Whitaker, Leto, and Yoakam) break in, attempting to find a fortune that's been hidden in, of course, the room.Foster is used to playing strong women roles, but she's never come off as being more resourceful as in Panic Room.  She makes her character seem like less a victim than a force to be reckoned with, and instead ably matches her captors.  Whitaker, Leto, and Yoakam all play their parts convincingly as the intelligent, strategic, and violent burglars, respectively.  The only role that comes off as a plot device is the daughter, who seems to be there not as a character but more a hinderance to the film's heroine.Fincher is a master of suspense, and there are droves of it as Foster smartly and able participates in a game of cat-and-mouse with the thieves. She comes up with clever and effective ways of dealing with them, which I won't reveal here.  Suffice to say there are many moments when the audience is riveted to the screen and also never feels as if the movie is becoming an implausible eye-roller.  Panic Room isn't near Fincher's other work, but still is a tense, above average thriller.  7 out of 10

Review title: Panic room is a really good film, but it could have been great
Review_body: *Spoilers Ahead (mostly minor)*I just went to see Panic Room, and I have mixed feelings about it.  The trailer definitely caught my attention as something unique, and though only in one location, I knew that David Fincher, director of Fight Club and The Game would deliver.  The good news is, on most levels, he does.First off is his incredible use of direction.  I have never seen such fancy camera work in a film; the camera will squeak through tiny openings and snake around from one room of the house to another within a single shot. Definitely impressive, and definitely eye candy.  Then we find Jodie Foster and her Daughter, both played very believably forced to seek refuge in the house's panic room when a trio of criminals show up.  I thought that the criminals were the most interesting aspect of the film, though a tad underdeveloped and way cliched (The type of people you might know in real life that would actually be willing to rob a house, yet exagerated in an over the top kinda way).  There were just too many times where they would do things that people in real life would never do.  One of which is at the beginning when one of the three criminals, after establishing to the audience that they have had no prior past together until now, asks for Dwight Yoakam's handgun (the only one who brought one) and he nonchalantly hands it to him.  Why would a professional hand over his gun to someone he doesn't know, let alone an obvious amateur?  Yes, scenes like this really are irrelevant to the story, yet will bother the best of us to no end when we see them.  Still, the criminals are played very well.  Forest Whitaker was superb as Burnham, the conscientious safe cracker with a heart, and Dwight Yoakam was fantastic, as always, as the cold and mostly calm Raoul, a mysterious member of the trio whose screen presence expresses his adherence to violence and mayhem more than the limited dialogue he has at the beginning.  Definitely the most interesting of the three.  Jared Leto was good as Junior, yet his character got annoying very quickly (especially since he demanded that he be in charge and ended up making a complete idiot of himself on many occasions in the film).  The suspense is there, not necessarily enough to make you scared, but enough to hold your attention.  The ending though is very predictable and rather empty, in my opinion.  I feel there could have been more to the ending, something profound to stick with you as you leave the theater (I was also hoping the exact opposite would have happened to Burnham that did.  He did have a good side, you know).  Overall, I enjoyed this film, it was good for what it was, but it could have been great.  This is one of those films that doesn't receive a 9 or 10 for a bad script or bad acting since both were good, but because there is potential for so much more that just isn't there. A solid 8 for amazing camera work, great acting and for overall entertainment value.  Go see it, you'll enjoy.

What an Exciting Movie.  A real home invasion roller-coaster. Jodie Foster was Great. Kristen Stewart may get nominated for supporting actress. Good interaction with Jodie. Forest Whitaker was perfect. Dwight Yoakam was downright Evil.  He was good in Sling Blade but this was a much more sinister role.  He character slowly emerged and you liked him less & less. One scene was very reminiscent of Jack in "The Shining".  You'll see.  Dwight may get nominated too but they have to get over disliking his character.The twists and turns were very well scripted and directed.  Amazing how things change. The Cinematography should get nominated.  Screen play was great. Special effects may get nominated too.  Not one thing todis-like about this movie except it's hard to grasp home invasion incidents. The best laid plans- don't always work do they.I am amazed there are no votes out on this movie yet.  Worth seeing but please don't bring children.  Saw way too many 5-10 year old kids with parents and you have wonder what the heck they are thinking. This movie could make some kids very edgy on dark, stormy nights. Be prepared for a few nightmares if you take yours.Would see it again in a heartbeat.

Review title: It would have been easier if the thieves just rent the place
Review_body: The entire movie falls to pieces when you suddenly realize that if the thieves rent the place to get the three million dollars, it would be a lot less messier, no "thirty years in jail" and a happy ending. But no, they had to complicate matters. Just the fact that they entered the house is enough to scare the people living there would be more than enough to get a vacant building. In any movie, I think the most important element in a story, is not really the plot, as what Aristotle thinks! It is the premise of the story being more important than the plot. Then we have all these movie producers reading up on interesting plots and catchy titles. Yes "must see movie" does grab you, but premise, and then as the story unfolds, it is the suspense that keep people watching. The plots are just the mechanics of holding the suspense minute by minute. The premise of the logic of the whole thing that makes a story believable enough to draw our interest throughout the story. It is true Panic Room has some of the finest actors, including Forest Whitaker, Jodie Foster, but if the premise doesn't hold, the story feels a bit off like a comedy. At least this is my literary criticism studies with four years down the toilet. When will the producers learn?

Cast, acting, directing, cinematography and editing are very good with Panic Room. Despite some holes which are listed by other reviewers, the plot is not so bad. Yes, the events unfold in quite a predictable way but the movie is still very engaging with its fast tempo and suspense that never lets go. On the negative side, the ending turns out a bit cheesy with too much effort to redeem the character acted by F. Whitaker. One interesting observation is that with good acting and captivating storytelling, the plot holes become less noticeable. After all, engaged audience care more about entertainment than analyzing each and every incident with a fine comb. To sum up, this is a very enjoyable movie with its fast pace, unrelenting suspense and lack of fluff.

A great thriller that will make you almost have an heart attack sometimes. With its amazingly written screenplay, rememberable characters and proper cinematography; David Fincher once again proves how talented director he is.

"Panic Room" is a pretty good thriller, but disappointing as a David Fincher film. Any number of directors could have done this. I can't say that about Fincher's previous three films, which all seemed to need the dark and innovative visual style he brought to them. His latest has moments with the feel of a Fincher film, as if another director tried his hand at a Fincher film. But even sub-par work by Fincher is better than almost anything else out there. First-time DP Conrad W. Hall (Conrad L's son) shares cinematography credit with Fincher regular Darius Khondji, which might have been the difference.What makes "Panic Room" tick is the script by David Koepp. This is an example of a film that survives on its premise, in the way it makes use of its location and the situations that location puts the characters in. The script falls short, however, on characters. Meg (Jodie Foster) has feelings and a past life, seemingly, but never takes on more than your basic celluloid heroin/everywoman persona. Let's just say that Koepp tries hard with her, but doesn't succeed. The film should be her story but the film's construction doesn't allow it. For instance when she enters the panic room for the first time and is closed in, we find out that she has a phobia about small spaces (go figure). She's able to overcome that in order to battle her home's invaders-the only development her character gets. In a way, Burnham (Forest Whitaker), is the focus of this story. He's the one who has to make the tough choices, to do the thinking, to do the most changing. Whitaker's is also the finest performance in this. Not surprising. Even that cop who presses Meg to "give him a signal" seemed to contain more depth than Meg.
"Panic Room" has one of those great premises that begs to be utilized to its fullest. Koepp and Fincher go a long way toward succeeding. There was a great risk of having to rely too much on coincidence, but the script is cunning enough to get by this. Anyone who's seen the trailer (the known world, surely) knows that a woman and her daughter lock themselves into their new home's panic room' when some violent men break in, only to find that all these men came for is IN THERE. Making the panic room both the womens' safe haven AND the reason the burglars are there could make some kind of best movie ideas of all time' list. Wisely, the film's creators know enough to just let this be what kicks things off.
Fincher and co. don't go in a direction that I thought they would, which probably just means they're smarter than I am: Eventually we know Meg and Sarah are going to have to leave the panic room. When they do, I thought the idea would be to give a heightened sense of their vulnerability-but turn the tables. The invaders finally get them out, only to find they wish they had not when the girls fight back. The film does play this card to a certain extent, but you never get a sense that over the course of the story, the panic room has begun to protect the invaders, not the tenants. What we end up seeing is your standard, overly violent, bloody, couldn't-think-of-something-better thriller ending.The major downfall of "Panic Room" is that it's not scary. There's a lot of nice cinematic tension, but no 'jolts' to make you clutch the elbow rest. But then, this is not horror. If you want scary, rent "Se7en."
Grade: B-

Not that exciting of a movie, not like I had expected.  Storyline was a bit unbelievable.  I mean, risking everything for a cell phone, that you know is not going to work (very predictable), getting the gun only to give it over to an almost dead man with a broken arm.  Oh well, I think I will go rent Silence of the Lambs for a decent Jodie Foster movie.  All in all, this isn't that bad, I'm just glad I didn't pay $10.00 a ticket to see it!!

Review title: Far from perfect, but still quite good
Review_body: Panic Room has a great story with potential. Unfortunately there are some annoying and very obvious errors that shouldn't be there. They put this film down a bit.Meg Altman, a newly divorced, moves into her new flat with her daughter Sarah. On their first night they get some uninvited guests and seek refuge in the "panic room", a bunker inside the house. Unfortunately what the thieves are looking for is inside the panic room as well.Panic Room has an original story with lot of potential. Unfortunately the characters don't live up to the story and there are some obvious holes and errors that pulls this whole movie down. The story, however, is well told and thrilling from beginning till end witch helps a lot, but David Koepp should have done some more work with the script.The cinematography and editing, however, is excellent. There are some nice long takes and beautiful moves. The composition of the shots, lightning and over all look and feel of the movie is good. The cinematographers does a good job in capturing the mood of the film and the feelings of characters. Jodie Foster delivers as Meg Altman and Kristen Stewart's kind of tomboy style works good as Sarah. The rest of the cast delivers a adequate performance, but still good enough. Dwight Yoakam, Jared Leto and Forest Whitaker makes a good cast for the thieves, but I didn't think Patrick Bauchau did too good as Stephen Altman. In my opinion the wrong man for the character.You don't really notice the score. It's just laying there, building up the mood and excitement. It's really not given that much focus, but it's a good classic score by Howard Shore.Panic Room is a good movie, by all means. I can recommend it because of good cinematography and an original story. It's well worth to watch and if you don't expect all too much you won't be disappointed.

Review title: Too slow to get going but it does eventually.
Review_body: A house is under attack and there is only one place to hide. A special place.Starring Jodie Foster, Kristen Stewart and Forest Whitaker.Written by David Koepp.Directed by David Fincher.This starts off really slow!In fact I'd say the first two thirds of the film are slow and pretty silly. The guys that break into the house are more slapstick than they are sinister. Their various attempts at getting at the two main characters is lame at best and doesn't make for exciting viewing.However the final third of the film builds up to a decent climax and has enough thrills and spills to satisfy. It's a pity the rest of the film wasn't as entertaining. The acting is decent throughout, especially Jodie Foster, Kirsten Stewart and Forest Whitaker.It's a shame it took so long to get going. 7/10

If you're going to see what appears to be a female-driven film, at least give the females something to really root for.  Like similar thrillers before this, Panic Room has us thinking that the women in this film are going to really do something to make us think that the seemingly 'gentler sex' can one day have their chance to really kick some *&#!  You'll know what I mean should you decide to watch this one being currently shown in theaters.  Panic Room is still good.

The overwhelming question that I needed answered before I could possibly enjoy this film was this:How was I supposed to sympathise with a women so well off that she can afford to buy a house with a room that serves no purpose other than for her to hide in when people break in to steal all her stuff?I mean, I have a good job, I pay a third of my income in direct taxes, I live in a nice neighbourhood with a garden and a garage (if not a picket fence).  I am Mr Average Suburban.  And yet the idea of a house WITH A ROOM THAT SERVES NO PURPOSE OTHER THAN TO HIDE IN WHEN PEOPLE BREAK IN TO STEAL ALL YOUR STUFF strikes me as both hilarious and repugnant.  It's so forced that it hurts, it really hurts.  I simply can't suspend my disbelief, and if I could, it would only mean that I would hold the protagonist in utter contempt.The only emotion that this insane, overblown shockfest imbued in me was disgust.  Disgust at a society that would allow such a concept in the first place, but especially one that would tolerate a film with that as a premise being released as anything other than science fiction. Avoid.

I went to see this movie against all of my movie instincts. However, given that it was directed by Fincher and had Foster playing the lead role, I went anyway. However, the movie was slow paced, had no surprises and lacked in intellectual plots (unlike his previous movies). I was disappointed in this movie, after three great movies- Seven, The Game and The Fight Club - this movie is a definite disappointment. Fincher should realize that the Fight Clubesqe cinematography and camera work does not make a good movie, a strong plot does.Rating: 2* out of 5*.

Warning! Don't expect to like this movie if you liked Fincher's last three movies!spoilers, interpretation:So it appears that Fincher has taken the Kevin Smith route: in order to safeguard his directing career he is going to intersperse corny Hollywood mainstream movies with his innovative films. 'Aliens 3' and 'Panic Room' fall into the first category, with 'Se7en,' 'The Game,' and 'Fight Club' falling into the latter. I have no problem with Fincher's survival instinct, I just wish I would have known of it ahead of time. So take this as a warning.What you have with 'Panic Room' is your typical Hollywood "thriller." It's not thrilling if you've seen a "thriller" before and remember any of it. A goal is made apparent within the first ten minutes of the movie, and the other two hours are used to frustrate this goal, over and over and over again. Even unrealistic aspects are accepted if they cause frustration. Also, anytime there is an uncomfortable moment, prolong it as long as possible. Use contrived undeveloped tension to add suspense (tension between Jody and daughter, Jody and husband, Jody and good robber - of course all three tensions are resolved nearly simultaneously in the end ). Make use of poetic justice because the good guys always win. Another hackneyed ploy: throw in an anti-materialistic moral into the mix (all three robbers, as well as Jody and daughter, are punished because of their greed) even if it hasn't been built up and has nothing to do with anything in the movie. Advice for film majors: suspense doesn't make corny humor funny, it just makes it annoying.I'll give Fincher another chance of course. In my opinion, nobody has ever directed four must-sees in a row. So I don't resent him, I'm just a bit disappointed. This was not even close to a must-see. It really was ridiculous; I ended up laughing at many of the supposedly scary parts because they were so unbelievably trite.  4/10

On their first night in a new home, a newly-divorced woman and her feisty daughter are terrorised by burglars.A simple, 'old-as-the-hills' plot is given some nail-biting new twists in this hugely atmospheric, extraordinarily shot thriller from Mr. Fincher. Foster is superb as ever, creating a deeply believable mix of vulnerability, bewilderment and toughness in Meg Altman (Kidman's loss was our gain, methinks), and she's matched at every turn by Stewart as her disapproving and resourceful 12 year old daughter. Whittacker and Yoakam add rich layers of pathetic good and menacing evil (although Yoakam is a little self-serving in the 3 DVD set commentary, if you ask me). Only Leto hits a wrong note, giving a deeply overplayed and caricatured illustration of over-acting.

Review title: It's 20 years ago, it's very good
Review_body: It's not a big budget film(despite Foster's pay check at that time) but full of drama and twists, it's still worth a watch even after 20 years, especially after watching Bruse Willies' Survive the night a few days earlier, consider it as a 2002 production, I would say Panic Room is one of the best thirllers of all time.

Review title: Simple plot with some nice flourishes
Review_body: Sometimes it's easier to enjoy a movie if you start with relatively low expectations. Panic Room is directed by David Fincher (Seven and Fight Club) and stars two great actors who are capable directors in their own right (Jodie Foster and Forrest Whittaker). Because of this my expectations were fairly high, perhaps unreasonably so.Jodie Foster plays a wealthy divorcee with a teenage daughter. As they are looking at a house they are considering buying in New York, they discover that the house has a unique feature-a hidden room surrounded in concrete and steel. The room comes complete with sophisticated surveillance equipment, a direct phone line and a variety of supplies designed to facilitate survival in the case of a siege.What they don't know is that the house has another secret, a hidden treasure worth millions of bonds. The person who does know this enlists the aid of two henchmen to help him find the hidden treasure. They think they are entering a vacant house. When they discover otherwise, the complications unfold-enter the panic room.One of the henchmen (Forrest Whittaker) has spent the last 12 years installing safe rooms for wealthy people. He knows the ins and outs, and he knows that the treasure they want is locked in the panic room with the two rightful inhabitants of the house.This is an intriguing premise with some interesting symbolism. The safe room that keeps the bad guys out soon becomes a prison that keeps the good guys in. A similar premise was developed in the film The Last Castle when Robert Redford compares castles and prisons. Same basic design, it's just that one is designed to keep people out, the other designed to keep people in.The film has some excellent cinematography and some great editing. Jodie Foster and Forrest Whittaker turn in great performances as would be expected. Kristen Stewart does an excellent job as the teenage daughter. The other characters are, unfortunately, cartoon cutouts. So much so that at points the film looks a bit too much like Home Alone.Don't get me wrong. The film is suspenseful and has some outstanding elements. Jodie Foster continues to be one of the top actors working today and her performance here is compelling. In spite of the aforementioned flaws, the film really is worth a look-especially if I have helped lower your expectations.

As always i have to admit David Fincher is quite a genius in building up suspense and making you live with the movie, he has done it with 4 movies now, we all know which, the thing about Fincher is that he keeps you guessing till the very end everytime, that includes this movie.The movie is about a divorced Mother who moves into a big house with her daughter, the house has a panic room (duh) and at the very first night burglers come to collect a hidden treasure hidden in the house, expecting nobody to be there they just walk directly in, the mother and her kid hides in the panic room, and of course they both suffer from each their weakness with closed in rooms.The movie is very moving and thrilling, Fincher is a master at building up the thrilling moments and the suspense that keeps a movie alive, this was shown first in Se7en, and since that he haven't made a bad movie. This one is good too incase someone misunderstood.One of the things i really like about Fincher is his originality and his creativity, and his untradiontal methods, for example in this movie we got a very different camera work from what has been seen before, which is nice at some points, it doesn't forefill it's purpose at all times, but it's a good idea with a "free" camera and it does work quite well most of the time. Furthermore Fincher always gives an ending that doesn't fit into the regular Hollywood formular, nice to have a director with guts to not always end a movie with the obvious happy ending.

Review title: One of the best thrillers I´ve seen in a long time
Review_body: When I first heard about the Panic Room I thought it would be a supernatural thriller like the Sixth Sense or What Lies Beneath. I can´t say that I´m a huge fan of David Fincher, but I must say he´s done some pretty unique films like the Game and Se7en. Hell, I even liked Alien 3! The Panic Room turned out to be a quite traditional thriller which is not a bad thing at all. Fincher has made a very memorable and thrilling movie which has one of the coolest opening titles I´ve ever seen. Another fantastic part is when the camera slides through the kitchen, I´ve rarely seen such camera work! The DVD is sure to be a must-buy! Great work, David & Jodie & Co.! 8 out of 10.

Review title: Not altogether unsatisfying but ultimately unremarkable and forgettable.
Review_body: Panic Room comes from director Fincher whose body of work up until now can be characterized as refreshing and unconventional, even if not all of his efforts have been succesful. It is therefor surprising to see him turn out something that is relatively run-of-the-mill and unremarkable. Panic Room relies on the premise of a mother (Foster) and her child finding themselves trapped in their own house by criminals, having to retreat into a so-called panic room, their only safe haven. In this sense at least it fits into the paranoia-realm that Fincher made his own. Panic Room doesn't suffer from any obvious flaws. Stilistically, the film bears the Fincher-trademark: the sets are dark and gritty, a lot of attention has been spend on detail (especially on the dimly lit panic room itself). Also, the opening-credits sequence deserves special mention. Furthermore, Panic Room features many acrobatic camera-movement as previously seen in Fight Club, although i have to say i sometimes found it too distracting from the narrative. Whitaker is unremarkable as on of the criminals suffering from a morality-attack in the middle of his operation, his acting-range is basically reduced to looking really sad and troubled. Few can be said concerning Foster's acting: it is solid but lacks depth. This is probably not her fault as her role is underwritten; we constantly see her heavy-breathing with eyes bulging out of their sockets but there is relatively little dialogue for her to excell at and there is little complexity to her character. Twists are few and none of it made much of an impression on me. Panic Room is violent but not earthshocking in any way (as we have come to expect from Fincher, eventhough it may not be fair to compare this to his other work). The problem with Panic Room lies in it's subject matter or lack thereof. One of the strengths of Fight Club was it's tendency to cover a lot of ground, tying together many loose ends that didn't seem to add up. The same holds true for The Game, which is extremely cleverly constructed in retrospect. In Panic Room storytelling is chronological, restricted to one space and one (all-seeing) perspective, all of these restrictions add up to a film that isn't altogether unsatisfying but ultimately unremarkable and forgettable.

This movie was very excellent. It was filled with suspense and terror. I really liked this movie because it wasn't cleche or boring. It kept me on the edge of my seat for the whole thing. I recommend you take your kids 12+ to see this movie.My MPAA rating: R for terror/violence and language My OFRB rating: AA, frightening scenes, coarse language, violence.

Review title: OK, but it could have been better
Review_body: The first 30mn of the movie are absolutely amazing: The non stop camera shots, music and photography, and especially the fact that at the beginning of the film there is very little dialogue...creates a disquieting atmosphere.But....As the thieves gets in the house and start arguing to each other....part of the mystery is gone.The girls has some chances to get rid of the robbers,but they don't seem to get advantage of it, and this fact makes the story not much believable.Anyway, the movie worth seeing: is not typical Hollywood stuff.

Panic Room was certainly worth the money! It was thrilling edge of your seat excitement! It also had humor to it. This being the robbers who at sometimes seemed to have no clue what they are doing. There were also wonderful breakthrough performances by Kristen Stewart and Dwight Yoakam. I do recommend though to read the book before seeing the movie because it provides a lot more background information and helps you understand the movie better. But overall I have to say that 'Panic Room' deserves 4 out of 4 stars!

David Fincher can always be relied on for well paced, visually interesting, darkly tantalizing entertainment; and David Koepp is a fine and versatile writer.  It's no surprise, then, that "Panic Room" doesn't disappoint, but it hardly ranks with their best efforts to date.  As in "Fight Club", Fincher's wall-dissolving camera tricks are pretty impressive.  But they actually work against the tension in this story by placing the audience beyond the claustrophobic reality of the house.  Similarly, Koepp's story premise and dialogue are good enough to keep you watching, but his plot offers few real surprises.  Ultimately, it's the performances which save the day.  Leto, Whittaker and Yoakam strike the perfect balance between incompetence and menace; and Jodie Foster manages to be maternal, terrified and fearless  all at the same time.  No wonder she has two Oscars.

Review title: After the Failed "Fight Club", Fincher Returns in Style
Review_body: Fortunately David Fincher lifts himself up from the mediocre Fight Club to deliver one of the most stylish and exciting thrillers of recent years. That said, our favorite actress Jodie Foster adds an extra level to the film. This is simplistic, straight forward and extremely efficient without using cheap tricks that most thrillers do. It is also fun to see that David Fincher once again takes a stab at Jared Leto's face.

Review title: David Fincher creates a greatly suspenseful if straightforward thriller
Review_body: David Fincher is one of my favorite directors, apart from Alien 3 all of his films I've seen hold real high quality. It took several year after it was released until I finally saw Panic Room. I tried to see it with an opened mind since I knew the reviews had been mixed. Mostly I found it an entertaining movie. It has its flaws and its not up to the standard of Fincher's Se7en or Fight club. The script is the big flaw, the story is pretty thin and simple. It just starts and you don't really get much of an background, I guess it not really necessary but even later the story is weak in giving any explanation to some of the events. A couple of thinks I feel doesn't make complete sense, maybe some plot holes but it doesn't bother me.
