Review_body: David Fincher is one of my favourite directors. As I would expect, the film is directed and shot beautifully and the plot is intriguing. So intriguing that it keeps you on your toes. But the end fails to withstand the build-up and is actually quite bland. Pitty.

Wow. The whole 1 point I gave this movie goes to the trailer.  If you've seen only the trailer, stop there. There is nothing more to see.  If ever a trailer lured you to a movie, this one is it; I watched excitedly, but when the credits began to scroll, the movie was still batting .000.  I don't blame Jody Foster if she thought she was getting herself into a good script after she took over from Nicole Kidman or whoever was supposed to be the lead originally, but it just turned out awful.  All in all, the movie should have been a short.

Let me start by saying the cinematography and the 3D /CGI work (for the time) are excellent, some
Of the camera moves are really good. But... this doesn't make up for this movie being total garbage.Firstly, why the hell did Jodie Fosters character by a 4 storey Manhattan apartment for two people to live in? She even said she couldn't afford it. What was Jodie Foster even gaining by locking herself up in the panic room and almost killing her daughter? She didn't even know about the money and so literally had nothing to lose by allowing them in to steal what they wanted. Even so, the rest of the movie is just awful. Jared Letos acting isn't OTT and hard to watch. The ending was awful as well, don't bother.

This was an excellent movie. Jodie Foster made it a true one-woman show. Though I think Jared Leto was miscast. But that didn't bother me at all. After all, it's Jodie Foster who I want to see. This is a kind of movie you only wish to see because of the leading character. The other roles weren't really interesting. This one really got me at the edge of my seat. I can't wait to see more of this. I give it a 10/10. It really gave me a claustrophobic feeling seen the fact that the entire story took place in the house. Jodie Foster still rules, that's for sure. I can't wait until her next movie comes out.Yes, this was a good one.

A film overflowing with excellent lighting and amazing camera work. I would imagine anyone who loves technically artistic films to appreciate the original camera angles and color schemes in this film. Jodie Foster as always, perfectly plays the refreshing role of a single mother. Finally a movie that accurately represents a REAL child, played by the calm and mysterious Kristen Stewart.  See this movie, and leave the theatre with a twinge of curiosity for what lies in *your* home.

Panic room is one of the best films I've seen in a long while, as far as pure entertainment goes. This won't be nominated for any Oscars, but it is a perfect popcorn flick.The first part of this film is more funny than thrilling. From the trailers, everyone knows the basic idea -- there's a steel room and some guys break into the house. The criminals, however, bring a great deal of comic relief, and unlike most scary movies this one means to be funny. Watching the men trying to get in the room and bickering amongst each other adds a light-heartedness to the show.Not that it isn't suspenseful. The tension is running high throughout the film, getting you wrapped up in the movie. I remember one part, a mad dash for a cell phone, which had the audience yelling at the screen "Hurry up, he's coming!", "No, turn around!", "Run! Run!", and "Close the door!". There were cheers and gasps from everyone in the theater.As the movie goes on the laughs die down for the most part as it becomes a much more tense film. The shift is done very well and doesn't detract from the enjoyment of the film or the film's story. The ending is very suspenseful and exciting. I have heard the phrase "edge of your seat" before, but this was the first movie I've ever been to where people literally were on the edge of their seats.I won't call this a scary movie, but rather a thriller/suspense movie. There's nothing jumping out at you, no monsters in the closet or anything like that. Ultimately, the movie delivers on every level. While it won't be winning any awards, this is the perfect weekend movie to go to for a good time. I gave Panic Room an 8 out of 10 (easily could be a 9 too), and I recommend it for everyone who likes laughs and thrills.

Review title: A worthy addition to Fincher's body of work
Review_body: Panic Room is not a masterpiece. That disclaimer should be taken not as a knock against the film, but merely as an advisory for those that are expecting this film to be a work of genius in the way that Fight Club was. This film is more akin to Fincher's The Game in that it takes a tried-and-true film genre and shows that a simple of story can generate incredible suspense. This isn't the type of film that will leave you mulling over the intricacies of its plot and meaning for days; it is 100 minutes of adrenaline. I am going to avoid going into great detail about the story and even the performances; this isn't the type of film that needs to be analyzed on every minute level. Quite simply, Panic Room is an excercize in the way that a great setting, coupled with superb acting (for the most part) and direction, can create a very enjoyable night at the movies for either thrill-seekers or students of film, even if many of the plot developments are heavily foreshadowed. The suspense isn't achieved in the ends, but in the execution, and Fincher's ability to continually create an engrossing and entertaining product across his body of work is what makes him one of Hollywood's best talents at the moment; this film is no exception. The casting, as was anticipated, was nearly perfect, though I found Jared Leto's character to be overly comical in a quite serious film. All gripes aside, this film is quality, and is one of the best nights at the movies you'll have in the annual spring lull. My rating: 8/10.

I am shocked at all the praise this movie is receiving. Remember: Fincher, Foster, Whitaker...formula for success? Not here. I've never seen a picture about a safe room, but the standoffs here seem like they've been done to death. It's not too suspenseful where the slow motion and other cues seem to indicate, not funny where the jokes are. And the resolution! A slow pan on thoughtful Foster then a cut to Whitaker in obvious distress, then a fade? Ludicrous! Not ambiguous nor thought-provoking. Just a real miss. A few "camera" moves are good here, but the flashlight shot was the most unnecessary shot in the history of film. Thanks for showing us, for absolutely no reason whatsoever, the inner workings of the flashlight, guys. Yoakam is good here. Cold and funny as a destroyed clown in the end. Otherwise a true swing-and-a-miss for Fincher.

Review title: Not Fincher's Best, But Still Pretty Dang Good
Review_body: Personally I prefer "The Game" out of his other films, but that's just me, I like them all. There is definitely a dark mood brought about by this film. It's got the requisite good mixture of thriller, drama, some laughs, and the like. It is clearly more mainstream than "Fight Club" but that's not a bad thing. There's isn't a whole lot to say about it without giving too much away (I had been avoiding the previews for months because I wanted to go in as blank as I could). Good thriller, realisticaly played out. You'll probably like it.One thing that you can always expect from David Fincher is a really neat-o opening credit sequence, and I sure did like this one.

Review title: Set up for sucess, but riddled with too many holes
Review_body: Panic Room had the potential to be a very engaging and a very different suspense/action movie.  Jodie Foster plays the divorced wife of a rich man who moves into a very elegant Brownstone/Townhouse mix.  With her daughter, the pair discovers that the house has a "panic room" -- a covert room fully equipped with water, food, and supplies in case of emeregency.  Sure enough, the room will be put to use very early on.  The filmmakers spend little time BS'ing and just jump right to central premise of the movie: lockdown.My main gripe with the film is that too much of the action went back and forth between the characters trapped in the room and the characters on the outside.  This third-person approach just seemed to dilute much of the suspense in the movie -- even though the filmmakers used every gimmick in the book to build suspense.  The movie should have focused more on the plight of those in the room -- make the viewer feel as if he or she is in the room, rather than watching omniscently as a third person spectator.As with any suspenseful movie -- horror movies being the prime example -- characters in this movie make stupid decisions which the audience knows will cost them later.  I have a tolerance for a few mental slips at which I may express verbally their stupidity, but when the film constantly relies on character mistakes and horrendously bad luck, it begins to get on one's nerves.  I can understand a few bad things happening -- I can suspend some reality & accept some improbable events for the sake of the story -- but not the onslaught of impossible occurrences.  In particular, the two lines in the movie which delegitimizes so much of the movie:-"Hello, 911!" -"Please hold."The film does have some dazzling camera tricks, as the camera gives the audience a magnificent tour of the house (although I believe these tricks helped contribute to the third-person problem which I believe causes the movie to suffer).  Additionally, the acting is very good.  The movie just suffers from a well-contrived concept turned into a poorly-told story.4/10

Review title: Good suspense ruined by bad plot holes
Review_body: At the beginning of this movie, I was sucked in by the fancy camerawork and fast paced action.  Those aspects of the movie were consistent throughout, but I could not bring myself to overlook the obvious unrealistic aspects of the plot.  The bumbling crooks reminded me of when I was eight years old watching "Home Alone".  I kept waiting for them to trip over some Micro Machines and get hit with some paint cans or an iron.  The film was very predictable with obvious foreshadowing and a hackneyed, unoriginal climax. I feel the need to point the most obvious flaw in the movie, so the next section will contain a minor spoiler:*********SPOILER ALERT***********When you dial 9-1-1, the operator will never say "please hold", and if they cannot call back, the police will arrive ASAP.  This would have been game over for the wet bandits, but the director needed to get another hour out of the movie.*********************************In the end, the fancy cinematography, great acting, and superb special effects could not redeem the horribly written script.

Panic Room was pretty forced.  The suspense built and built, but on nothing. Every time things took a turn for the worse, there seemed to be a more reasonable action for the characters to have taken.  Since I could not believe the story, I was only riveted by the movie once or twice.The camera work was fantastic, and there were some unique tricks that couldn't physically be pulled off without some magic.  The characters were interesting and well-acted, especially Jodi Foster's character (the mother). Even the realtor was interesting.Panic Room was a nice diversion but ultimately forgettable.  I will not see it again.  If you want a good thriller, see 'The Others' on video instead.

I Finchers Fight Club and Se7en so I figured this one would be at least good. Boy was I wrong... It was great. Besides two short scenes on the street and a few exterior and outlooking of the house Fincher pulls it off with only one set Jodie Fosters newly purchased house. The House has a "Panic Room" an amazingly safe room with 3 inch steel walls and seperate phone and ventilation lines. Sure enough people break in on her first night in the house. She and her daughter Sarah narrowly make it into the room and a siege of three thieves who by a small escrow miscalculation find Foster asleep like Goldilocks. Unfortunetly everything they want is in the Panic Room Everything they want is in the Panic Room.  Of Course the weakness of every secruity system is the man who built it(Forest Whitaker) and he is among the three men that break in. Fincher was smart not to make the thieves international thieves that just haven't counted on Foster. The thieves often miss smart things they could do and seam to be a bigger opposition to themselves than Foster. A well known virtue of this film, the camera work was great I heard "How the hell they do that?" more than once. I will not spoil the end but I will suggest this in the greatest way I can it was a true nail biter.

Review title: This is a perfect suspensful thriller.
Review_body: Sure, Jodie Foster and the daughter don't play particualy likeable characters and nobody can relate with the movie, but it is a solid example of it's genre, with perfect suspenseful scenes, action and drama. Great.

Review title: A real nailbiter, I could sure go for one of those little rooms...
Review_body: I have to say I went into this movie thinking it was going to be just another suspense type movie having to do with a botched robbery. However this movies unique plot and great cinematography make this one a must see. Well maybe not a must see, but definitely one of the best movies in theatres now. I can honestly say I got to use my brain a little bit and my heart was racing at times. If you want a to see a good all-round movie after a long day at work, check this one out. Who knows, you may even decide to get one of those nifty rooms. And you will defintely reconsider keeping a handy propane tank in your home.

it's a very polished movie, and jodie foster pulls off another great performance. however, there was never any real threat in the movie. the evil guys aren't evil enough. i left the theatre disappointed that there was no gutsy bad dude in the movie, or monsters hiding in the panic room.  dwight yoakam was about the only thing that came close to a threat in the movie. it's not a repeat-viewing movie. not too bad for first time viewing though.

From the moment the movie started...I could tell it was going to be interesting. I was very right. The story starts out with A woman and her daughter trying to find a house. They find this humongous house with a {you'll never guess} panic room in it. During their first night...the house gets broken into. From that moment on...you will be on the edge of your seat. The cinematography was wonderfully done. It was full of suspense that kept you on the verge of your chair. I give it 10 toes up. :)

This movie is jam packed with a wonderful screenplay, filled with suspense and plenty of wit. The acting is flawless, and an Oscar nomination is to be expected for Jodie Foster, and possibly for her young co-star Kristen Stewart. The cinematography is unique, fresh, new, and daring. Entertaining from title to credit. You must go see this film, and you must see it on the largest screen you can possibly find.

Review title: An average film with a disappointing ending
Review_body: This movie could have been a lot better. I would give it a six out of ten, just a little above average.  The plot had holes in it, the ending was really bad, and there was a complete lack of suspense. The things I liked about the flick was that it had some good action sequences and it was humorous at times.

Damn shame if you ask me! Jodie Foster refused to be the president of the jury at the Cannes Film Festival to do this. Maybe it looked good on the page and it certainly looks good on the screen, specially the opening credits but there is very little else to recommend. David Fincher does some dizzying things with the camera but the script by the very rich David Koepp is just plain amateurish. I was so frustrated by the waste of everything here. The characters seem a facsimile of characters from other, better, movies without being able to nail that extra dimension that could make them, at least, watchable. The husband, the cops even the baddies are all laughable. Jodie Foster has a couple of moments and she's one of my heroes anyway but that's maybe why I felt so annoyed by this movie, so much so that I decided to vent my frustration writing this comment. If you love Jodie Foster, avoid this for her sake.

As suspense movies go, Panic Room was definitely watchable and holds your attention throughout.  Beyond that, there is nothing outstanding about the movie, nor anything tragically flawed.  There are frequent times during the movie when you inevitably ask, "Why didn't she just do this?" or "Why don't they simply do that?".  But those errors do not detract much from the action and the story maintains a healthy amount of believability.  Six out of ten.

Review title: Ranks among the worst movies I have ever viewed!
Review_body: Jodie Foster should be ashamed for lowering herself to this caliber film which, to me, had not one redeeming feature. To classify this film as a "Z" movie would be generous! A total waste of time, potentially great talent, and one's digestive system!

Review title: Why do people always writhe around on the floor looking for guns
Review_body: Panic Room is an adequate thriller with a good dose of suspense but like most films constructed within the confines of a big studio it lets itself down at the end. Why are people always writhing around on the floor, half-injured  reaching for guns which are seemingly out of their reach only to be grabbed at the last moment. The ending is predictable in the extreme, which was disappointing considering the suspense and intrigue which was built up during the film. This film would have been better off in the hands of an independent film-maker.

Fincher almost outdoes himself here, yet I noticed he gets mostly criticism from IMDB users. I think the reason is mainly the lack of emphasis on the narrative here, as compared to Fight Club, for instance. The visual aspect has a bigger role here. It is the house which is the main character of the movie, not Meg.I am similarly surprised that Whitaker's character is described as the 'good guy' by some users. Short attention span perhaps? See it, if for nothing else, for the long tracking shots. 9/10

Good film but could have been slightly better with more tension.The first 20 minutes rock! Then once she's in the room it becomes very boring.Anyway, you wouldn't have had energy for a twist in the plot, because "Panic Room" really scares the crap out you! It keeps you at the edge of the seat during the 2 hours! It's true! Probably the most frightening movie from the last years.Maybe "Panic Room" could be compared to "Home Alone" but for adults, maybe the ending is quite predictable and poor (hey, think about "Planet of the Apes" for a bad ending), but it's a brilliant thriller with a creepy atmosphere, a lot of style, and created by David Fincher.

Review title: The movie should have ended an hour early
Review_body: UNBELIEVABLY SILLY MIDDLE AND ENDING.If the female character played by Foster had any brains, she would have opened the door to the Panic Room when she saw that the criminals were away from the door on the video screens, and gotten a good enough signal to dial out on her cell phone.Then again, the criminals should have figured that sh*t out and waited next to the door to the Panic Room, on the other side.There are other 'glitches' where the movie should have ended much earlier than it actually did.Overall, the action is fine, I enjoyed the cinematography, but otherwise, I'm not sure how this movie could be getting more than 6 or 6.5 stars TOPS from these audience reviews.

It was on in cinema near me so I decided to see it. It is awesome and I love many actors/actresses in the movie. *SPOILERS*I rated it an 8 because I think that an ending wasn't really fair. The black guy was arrested but he was the good guy and the money (22 mil.) got lost. That wasn't really fair in my opinion. Overall the movie was great, all tho I didn't really like Kristen Stewart's character that much. And another thing that I thought was weird is that, why the hell do they need that big house, I mean, it's just too big. And in the end I found it weird that the masked guy actually came back to kill all of them when the police were already there when he could've just ran away and escaped.

Actually i thought the movie was good...I mean more could have happened...but it was still good...the little girl is a pretty good actress...well she's older now of course...but yeah I only really watch the movie on regular TV because all those stupid cuss words really start to turn you off after awhile you know? I mean all these rated R movies with their hundreds of "F" words and such it's so pointless...to me it shows that the screen writer didn't have enough lines or time to fill in so basically every other word they say has to be the "F" word....this movie wasn't too bad with them though...there are worse ones I mean...but still....look at Pirates of the Caribbean...they don't use the "F"word and guess what? Still a great movie! ...Anyway this movie could have used a little more action and suspense....but it's alright...not as bad as that other reviewer says.
Solid movie with a lot of suspense and very pleasant camera work. Ending was missing something, did not get the closure I was hoping for. Still solid movie.

The film started off well but sadly went off into the wrong direction. Maybe the script writer got stoned while he was creating Panic Room but it just got ridiculous and unrealistic. A real shame, this movie had real potential. What a waste!

Review title: Great suspense with excellent cast and director
Review_body: This movie was a really pleasant surprise for me. Though I am a real fan of the other fincher movies (especially "se7en" and "the game"), I didn't really now what to expect from this one.The story didn't sound very original, but like stuff that could make a great movie in the hands of the right director.Well, Fincher was the right director. With this movie about a young divorced woman and her daughter being trapped in a security room of their house while criminals trying to lure them out in my opinion is his very best work so far.Despite some little plot holes that are very easily forgiven, "Panic Room" not only is a great flick, but a wonderful pice of art. I think so because even though the whole movie takes place in one big house, director David Fincher and cinematographers Conrad W. Hall and Darius Khondji manage to create some truly unique shots you haven't seen in any other movies so far.I don't want to go too much into detail, but if you are even a little interested in the art of film making, you have to see this movie.Of course I also highly recommend it for fans of Fincher and/or Jodie Foster.I talked to some guys who didn't really understand what I meant when I told them how great the (digitally enhanced) camera movements were, but that was only because they weren't really movie fans who would recognize these kinds of details.My conclusion: you might argue that the plot is not very original, but the cinematography alone justifies to see this movie at least once.I give it 9 out of 10 points.

Review title: I got just what I expected, and more!
Review_body: We all know what to expect from a premise like this. Sometimes it's reward enough to see it done well. While his talent can effortlessly surpass the genre of the "thriller", David Fincher's direction makes "Panic Room" something out of the ordinary. It's truly dark. It's truly suspenseful and it's the smack-in-the-head one hopes for from this genre. Jared Leto and Dwight Yoakam shine, comic book style. If you're looking for edge-of-your-seat entertainment, don't hesitate. "Panic Room" will make you squirm.

How is it possible for this movie to have a rating of 7.5 - I thought the folks on the imdb had more taste than this!!!First of all the camera work seemed excessive, the script was implausible and annoyingly, predictable and the movie in its total effect was a great cure for insomnia.I did love the mother daughter dynamic between Meg (Jodie Foster) and Sarah (kristin stewart).  Both gave quite good performances which, alas, did not make up for the terribly forced and trite acting of Leto, Dwight and Whittaker.  There was no development and no convincing interaction in this threesome.The movie had some holes which I believe have already been given adequate attention on this list.  I will give this movie (not film, mind you) a few points for effort.  The initial camera work in the tour of the house was superb, especially the movement through keyholes and walls (we really didn't need to see the inside of a flashlight later on using this technique, however) I also love the opening credits - How unique and fun to watch!
My real problem with the movie was that I had expectations.  I have come to expect so much more from the director of Fight Club, Alien 3, The Game and Se7en, all of which I loved because they were so innovative!  That was the problem with the Panic Room - It was not innovative in its feel or script. I also love most films Jodie Foster touches in any way and I was hoping for more - she came through with a great performance but had to work with such a pathetic script and that deserves kudos. This movie let me down in a big way.

Review title: Very intense! If you want to be thrilled, GO SEE THIS MOVIE!
Review_body: The Panic Room is THE most edge of the seat thriller I've seen in a long time. Gory horror movies don't scare or enthrall me. But movies like this and Speed do.In recent years, thrillers have relied less on suspense and tried to outdo themselves with over-the-top endings and plot twists like Se7en, Usual Suspects, Spanish Prisoner, Sixth Sense, and Unbreakable.Writer David Koepp spent the most of the 90's successfully adapting other thrillers like Jurassic Park, the first Mission: Impossible, Carlito's Way, and Stir of Echoes. While his originals, Trigger Effect and Snake Eyes, were just so so. Here, he sets up a wild premise, intriguing characters, and some very funny moments.By now, director David Fincher has proven that he is by the best thriller director period. Se7en is by far the creepiest film of the 90's. The Game is a great ride and that just keeps on twisiting and keeps you guessing.Panic Room's key moments are when the viewer is kept waiting for what will happen next. The filmmakers have set the film with some terrific rules. The burglars aren't going on anywhere and there is no outside communication. Then, they add on the complications.

Review title: Panic Room is everything I watch movies for.
Review_body: I saw Panic Room this weekend and I liked it. David Fincher rocks. I would even say he has a unique vision unto Hitchcock for the 21st century. His movies include Se7en, The Game, and Fight Club. All excellent movies.I almost hate to say this, but the opening titles to Panic Room are one of the best parts of the film. A revolutionary use of typography, computer generated graphics, and beautiful photography of Manhattan is used to create eye-popping, 3-D titles aligned to the photographic perspectives of New York buildings. After this, Fincher proceeds to make camera moves through a house that know no bounds. Some of the coolest camera shots I've ever seen.Panic Room is a tightly wound thriller that kept my undivded attention for the duration and made me jump, wince, and laught in several spots. Jody Foster's performance is excellent. Forest Whitaker plays a burglar one can almost sympathize with and you won't believe Dwight Yoakam as Raoul. Panic Room is everything I watch movies for.

Review title: Not as good as I had expected
Review_body: I went to this film because I thought it would be interesting and offbeat. I mean, come on, David Fincher directed Fight Club!  It is not a horrible movie, but it is fairly predictable and mundane.  The commercials make it look much more exciting than it really is.  Not a bad movie, but not really a great one either.

Since this movie has no plot whatsoever, it is clear that David Fincher just took the money instead of keeping up his high quality of films. This movie has one of the dumbest plots I have seen in the suspense/thriller genre. There is some amazing camera work as is usual in Fincher's films, but that does not even come close to making up for the lack of a good story. Every twist and turn in the movie is completely predictable, and the foundation of the plot is highly implausable to begin with.  I would not recommend this at all.

Review title: Save yourself the $9 (or whatever the horrendous movie price is in your area)
Review_body: Not impressive not horrible.  The movie is kind of boring but since it is directed by Fincher it keeps you thinking about what suprise there is going to be.  But unlike all his other movies, this one doesn't leave you in shock, it leaves you thinking how unique the movie is not, and how nothing really puts you on the edge of your seat.  Worth renting yes, worth seeing in the theatre no.

Review title: First rule of Panic Room, don't go to Panic Room
Review_body: It is usually the movies that had the potential to be good that make the worst movies.  Panic Room is just such a film.  David Finchner, with the exception of his first film Alien 3, has up to this point been making exemplary films.  They are suspenseful when they mean to be and thought provoking as well.  Panic Room is not.  While Finchner has been known for his original cinematography here, with the exception of the establishing shot of the Alten's apartment, a lot of it is superfulous and quite distracting.  The other major problem here is that David Koepp's script makes two of the three robbers quite likeable and sympathetic.  Worst of all is the resolution, very incomplete and illogical.  A lot of ingredients for a good if not great film were here, just someone left the oven on for too long.

If you've read plot summaries about this one and found yourself wondering how much suspense and thrill can you get from a movie whose entire storyline centres around one room, the answer is: "probably more than you think".This is a very good production with all the elements of a good thriller and will keep you on your toes throughout. Jodie Foster gives a splendidly controlled performance and David Fincher through excellent positioning of cameras always clearly defines the characters' positions in the house as well as in relation to each other. In addition he "sends" the camera through walls, keyholes and other unlikely places creating some very smooth footage that adds to suspense and is very enjoyable to watch.Again, this IS a tense movie, (probably just up there with "What Lies Beneath") and I fully recommend it as such. (8 out of 10)

I saw this at a sneak-preview. When the (very stylish) opening credits appeared I was hoping this to be yet another Fincher classic, not that it's a bad movie or anything, but I came out of the movie slightly disappointed. It is all photographed beautifully and Foster does a good job, but the problem is it's just not exciting, it's all very predictable and Forest Whitaker in the role of one of the the bad guys? I didn't buy that at all, Jared Leto plays the dumb crook and Dwight Yoakam is the only one that's remotely scary. This is I feel the main problem with the film: it's simply not very exciting and the ending is too predictableIt seems that Fincher wanted to make a film that would appeal to the general public and in that he has definitely succeeded: this is a film that seems to follow the Hollywood guidelines perfectly, there's nothing wrong with that, but It's a shame, because Fincher can do much better than this, but let's just hope that for his next film he goes experimental again like he did with Fight Club(to excellent results)*** out of *****

Fincher employs every tension producing technique, from slow motion and exaggerated silence to rapid inter-cutting editing and anxious close ups. The result is a tight and tense viewing experience.  Highly reccomend this film.

This movie was really good.  I love scary movies and this one tops my list. It's really nerve wracking the whole way through.  They do some amazing things with camera angles and silence.  I was on the edge of my seat during most of the movie.  I even caught myself taking deep sort of panic like breaths during one scene.  I guess I'm just a little over dramatic when I see really scary movies, but if you like to be scared this is a must see! I give it a 9 out of 10.

Wow, what a film. The shots of this film is beyond great. How the hell did they made them back then. It looks like a high budget film although its mainly one location. no? Im not sure. Well, watch it. It's fantastic.

Could have got an 10 had the last five minutes not been predictable, but it still is a very very solid 9. Ok, I know, I am a Jodie Foster fan, but aside from that this was an incredible film. Intense, well acted, and well written. Even from the beginning with the credits, the producers were doing something different. Camera angles, characters, the general story line... all made this movie an A. I can't say enough about the realistic acting. Kristen Stewart (plays the daughter) not only calms you at times, makes you laugh at others, and just terrifies you with her completely believable terror and acting. And then Jodie Foster, damn! She is just always on top of her game.To make a movie that solely takes place in one room, but yet keeps you on the edge of your seat, is a feat on its own. Paranoia and suspense keeps you guessing and gripping. In the end, I couldn't wait to sit through it all over again and I plan on locking myself up in the Panic Room many more times to come

I loved Se7en, I loved Fight Club. Panic Room is no different, why? because I love it. David Fincher is slowly becoming a new Hitchcock. Not to say he is replacing him, but the styles of the directors are similar, alot of imagery. Great camera work, haunting visuals, and a Pace that never drops. Alot of effects that were used in Fight Club are used here plus some new tricks.The characters are well developed for their purposes. The actors, all superb. I really enjoyed watching Jared Leto in this film, as well as Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart and Forest Whitaker.We become involved with both sides and nothing becomes unclear. We see how human all these characters can be and we see the leaps and bounds they will go to for survival.You might think that the film would get boring if everything takes place in a house. You quickly learn that you are wrong. Character chemistry comes into play and we don't want to miss a beat.I loved it, I gave it a 9. Do yourself a favor and see it.

I sometimes still can't believe how incredibly stupid and boring Hollywood's blockbusters have become. With disasters like Tomb Raider or Pearl Harbour in mind, one can't possibly look forward to next blockbuster summer. Who knows how empty and hollow Attack of the Clones nad its clones may be.But here is David Fincher, Hollywood's hotshot, with something we wouldn't expect from him: A flat, boring so-called thriller. After two overrated (Seven, Fight Club), one underrated (Alien 3) and one just plain good film (The Game), we believed that guy could do at least one thing: Keep us interested.Wrong. After probably twenty minutes, Panic Room falls flat. Jodie Foster and her terrible cliché daughter hide in a special Panic Room in their new house when Forest Whitaker and two thugs (one of them being Jared Leto in the worst of overacting moods) break in to get the previous owner's money out of the Panic Room.And that's about it. Fincher shows absolutely no talent for suspense here. When Foster at one point leaves the Panic Room to get her mobile, it's important that no one hears her. So Fincher turns off the sound and makes it all slow motion. No excitement. Fincher prefers to show one digital camera move after the other, which is boring at first but ultimately becomes unbearable. There's also a digital gas explosion. I wasn't sure whether I was watching Poltergeist IV at that point.The script doesn't help. The attackers are not scary at all. Whitaker's the nice guy, the good guy, the sad guy; Leto is a joke, and Raoul, the masked marauder, is all violence. So we're not really afraid. What scared me was Jodie Foster's daughter because I had hoped that we would never have to see a movie character like that again.Then, after 90 minutes of boredom, comes a moment that totally sinks the film: The gangsters are in the panic room with Foster's daughter. The cops arrive. Foster's opening the door, telling the cops nothing's wrong because she's afraid something might happen to her daughter. Now at that point we know that the gangsters have absolutely NO CHANCE of hearing what she tells the cops because the film told us EXPLICITLY earlier on. So why doesn't she tell the cops to stay outside, but also what is going on in there??? I rest my case.The finale would be a letdown - if there was anything good in the film before that.Now don't get me wrong: Of course it's not as bad as Michael Bay. But exactly that is why I'm so disappointed. And by the way, it worked with the audience I saw it with, so it may work with you. But I hated it and it makes me angry that this film turned out to be so bad.

Review title: It reaches the highest peak, then falls off...
Review_body: Ok, yes I enjoyed this movie. Yes it was made well, the acting is good, and the sheer thought of being trapped in a "panic room" is eerie. But what ruined the movie for me was its ending, or rather the lack thereof. To me, what makes or breaks a movie is it's beginning and ending. If your movie opens with a lot of action then it has to go out with a big bang! Now by no means did this movie open in a huge way (I did like how the credits actually loomed over New York City though...this WAS set in New York right?) but it seemed as if the director was unable to think up a way to end it. The last ten minutes are predictable and the ending scenes just seem to have been tacked on. This is only MY opinion however, so I do suggest you see this film. My final judgment for Panic Room is a 5 out of 10.

despite it not being well advertised, it looked like it should be a really good film. it was disappointing. the story was thin and predictable and made the characters look 2D. the effects left something to be desired - looking through wooden floors, walls and the like.however, it was full of suspense and aesthetically pleasing. an entertaining film, though easily forgotten.

The only panic I experienced was when I thought I had paid to watch this movie.Although well put together, the plot leaves nothing to the imagination. Throughout the beginning of the film the view is left thinking "I wonder when that bit of information will be used later in the film". The villains are predictable and, given their goal, painfully stupid. In the name of suspense (I assume), the villains bumble around providing windows of opportunity, while the heroes dash around risking their lives with obvious consequences. There are so many points which are simply too far fetched to be believable, for example: The timing & manner of the police arrival - If they took that long answering my distress call I would demand my taxes back!

Review title: Was this David Fincher's attempt to do Special Edition "R" rated Home Alone version?
Review_body: Is this pathetic or what?  David Fincher, Wake up... David Koep is writing the script for your next movie!  Haven't you noticed yet!  Yes, David Koep is the same man how Slaughtered Michel Crichton's best selling novel The Lost World with his screen adaptation. For all you Fincher fans, all you Foster fans,  get ready for a movie that is sustained for an hour and half on a plot that isn't mearly as complicated as that on Home Alone.  A story that could have been told in a much simpler and shorter way, lags on for too long (long enough for you to fall asleep in the theater...LOL)  Yes it has an amazing CG/live footage secuence in which the camera goes through walls, key holes, and coffee pot handles, but does that really contribute to the story's end... No.  Absolutely not.  The same rule aplies in the game of chess.  You strategically postion your pieces in the fastest and most logical way to get an end result.  Here Fincher Plays with his pieces like if he is playing chess for the first time. SPOILER ALERT!! Another thing that bothered me was (Spoiler) the way a character is practically smashed to death with a sledge hammer and thrown down the stairs, then magically climbs up, hits the little girl, sends her flying to the wall and still has the strength to try and strangle Jodie Foster... Give me a Break!!! A total waist of time and money.

Anyone who didn't like this movie has mental problems! This movie was defintitely David Fincher's best work! Jodie Foster was amazing and so was Kirsten Stewart. All of David Fincher's movies are amazing and I think he is the best director out there! I give it 10/10 for being intense, suspenseful, and overall entertaining! Can't wait for the DVD!!!!!!!!!!!

Jodie Foster is very cute in this film, and her acting is impeccable. While the plot tends to make you slightly claustrophobic, it does pick up some 20 minutes into the movie and carries you in a state of tranquil suspense toward the end.  Would make a good date.

Review title: Like Rear Window? Ha Ha Ha
Review_body: This picture is really bad, and some guy from  CNN told that this movie was like Rear Window. Poor Hitchcock... This guy, Fincher isn't good, and really, I don't know what people saw in this movie. I prefer re-watch Rear Window than see this movie again. WARNING: don't watch this movie, go to the video store and get Rear Window. IS LOT BETTER!

I thought that Jodie Foster did a great job in this movie.  The acting and story lines were to a T.  It had me on the edge of my seat at many times and kept me guessing until the end of the movie.  The music was fantastic and really gave the movie the eerie feeling.  I would recommend this movie to anyone who has a liking to suspense movies.  Forest Whitaker and Kristen Stewart did a great job of acting as well as Jodie Foster.  Well worth the money to see it in the theaters!  :-D

I see movies every weekend and the last few weeks have been horrible movies. But this week I saw the Panic Room and this movie is great. It's suspenseful, and you can't help but to fall in love with one of the bad guys. This is a must see movie.

This movie was worth my time and i plan on seeing it again.  I think Fincher's superb ideas in directing are once again shown in this movie. However, i think the script somewhat lacks the power of the other movies he has directed (ie. Fight Club, Se7en, The Game, and Alien 3).  While I definately would recommend this movie to anyone, i would also warn them that this is the worst film he has directed so far.

Review title: Is the Panic Room, the safest room in the house?
Review_body: Movie choices are often a matter of taste. I personally don't like olives, but many do even when it's not soaking in a martini. Jodie Foster's new film, PANIC ROOM, was anything but an olive for me. Most films deal with conflict of one sort or another, good films take the movie goer to the next level referred to as "complication". Foster's character finds herself with her child in conflict when intruders invade her home and seek the safety of the panic room. The plot becomes an emotional complication when Foster's character becomes trapped outside the panic room with her child trapped inside with the intruders. That's good story telling with a twist. The film is edited especially well and does not lose the audience with a series of quick action scenes. So, here's my suggestion, stop sucking on olives and go see the PANIC ROOM.

Review title: Pretty watchable, given the poor 2002 crop to date - better for the big screen.
Review_body: Not quite as good as "Wait Until Dark," but it reminds me of that movie.Jodie Foster is good -- at least as good as this somewhat limited role permits.  Forest Whitaker gives his usual excellent performance, although you've seen him play this same essential character elsewhere.  The really interesting performance for a relative newcomer is from Kristen Stewart. Dwight Yoakum also makes a pretty doggone good bad guy.I give it a "5," but I think that is a pretty good grade for a movie that is entertaining but not enduring.  (Only the very best get higher from me.) Overall, I think it is a pretty watchable firm, especially in view of the overall poor crop of films in 2002 to date.  It is probably worth the extra $4 to $5 to see this one on the big screen -- lots of the filmmaker's work will likely be lost on videotape or DVD.

Review title: Sometimes too much, sometimes not enough.
Review_body: WARNING: there may be plot spoilers in this review.This piece seems to have two major problems: some elements are far too superfluous, while others are simply not there.On the technical side, I found that the (I admit) beautifully original sweeping camera shots/dollies throughout the house were creative and well-made. However, when viewed in the cinema, they tend to make an audience feel queasy rather than excited or interested. I suspect these scenes would have a different 'feel' (and therefore a different impact) on smaller screens. The transparency of these shots (especially the computer-generated ones) did however mean that I personally was made aware all too often that I was watching a film, rather than being drawn into the whole experience. It was a nice idea, but half of these shots could have been left out.As far as the plot is concerned, I felt that the major weakness there was the lack of character motivation and history. For example, the character is obviously very frightened when she is first shut in the room - yet she still wants to buy the house. Why? I would have expected her to not want to stay there (in fact, the plot could have been contrived very differently to make this a lot scarier). The characters are introduced in a very weak, cliched, manner.The idea of a panic room is an excellent one for a creepy film, but frankly: I wasn't that impressed.And finally, how is it possible to put one's HAND in a FLAME and come out unburned (and still nicely manicured)?

I thought somebody made a movie of "Stupid White Men" and it turns out to be a mess called "Panic Room". This has to be the dumbest movie of the year. Without the cute little mouse-cam action exactly what is there to watch here?  It's like a colorless video game that never ends.  Is Roger Ebert on Finchers' payroll or did he see a different movie than I did?  Or did he get hit with the sledgehammer too?  This movie was not scary. It was AWFUL!....I suspected it might be so I bought tickets for "Changing Lanes"(which I knew was good) before slinking in to see Jody Foster trying to be Bruce Willis. Yuck!

The only way i could have had a minute of pleasure watching "Panic room" is if the "good bad guy"(always an interesting point of departure but totally unexploited here) got away with the money.Fincher obviously prefers morals to pleasure (a quality for a priest, a heavy load for a hollywood filmmaker). I guess even one minute of pleasure is too much to expect out of a Fincher movie. "Pleasure", (visual, intellectual or even physical), isn't that what a movie should bring to the viewer

Review title: Not what I had hoped for...
Review_body: I thought Panic Room was a bit of a disappointment.  It was not as suspenseful as I had hoped, and I often found myself bored with the characters.  It is, however, worth-seeing because of the amazing camera work by the genius David Fincher.  (7/10)

Tense, thrilling, fast paced......just the usual brilliance from Jody Foster!! Outstanding performance from Forrest Whitaker and also from Kristen Stewart as Sarah. The movie held my attention from the very start, there were some unexpected twists in it which were great.

Review title: Since the thieves appeared on scene, the movie became more a comedy than a drama.
Review_body: You know, we all love David Fincher, but this piece is surely not a drama or thriller. I was really scared and feared in the first 10 or 15 minutes, but that was all! As the very dangerous and efficient thieves appeared, the whole athmosphere of the movie was gone. You only wait - from this moment - what they will do, where they will not succed. Quite boring and with the worst end imaginable.

Review title: Despite all the plot holes- a decent thriller.
Review_body: I read some of the other reviews and felt that a lot of them were rather harsh. I admit that there were many flaws in the tale and won't bother to go through them all as that ground has been well covered. As I read the plot holes, I found myself amazed at the fact I hadn't noticed most of them while I was watching the film as I tend to pick fault with story lines of movies a lot.I confess to being totally ignorant on the subject of diabetes, and although this wasn't supposed to be a public information film, I think they ought to have got those medical facts right because there are enough people out there that have diabetes and would know the difference and especially having made it such an important part of the plot it should have been accurate. Otherwise I think the errors are forgivable and didn't intrude on my enjoyment of the film. I have come to expect to spend a good bit of any thriller shouting "Why are you doing THAT?" I think in Panic Room the characters were good enough to engage the audience and once the movie got into the main story the direction kept it rolling along in a competent manner. Overall; a decent thriller if you don't look too closely.

Knowing all of David Fincher's previous movies, I was extremely disappointed by this film. While you never know how the story would twist in his former works, the script of Panic Room is a regular Hollywood thriller like 1000 others that keeps you minimally attracted from the beginning to the end (the end of the movie is probably the most disappointing - you would expect some final, unexpected twist, but nothing). The only thing that is really excellent is the movement and the viewpoints of the camera - a Fincher feature one is used to since Fight Club. Hopefully, one of my favorite directors returns to the level of his previous titles!

I enjoyed this film despite a few things: 1) Jared Leto's over-acting which made his character borderline comical 2) Dwight becoming considerably less menacing the moment he lost his mask 3) Unrealistic bits (911 puts you on hold? Doesn't trace the call?) 4) the fact that the weak & abrupt ending left me going huh what? That's it???SPOILER - - - - - ->Forest's character ends up saving their lives, and get's nothing out of this selfless act except a long insinuated jail sentence. I realize he was a bad guy and should typically go to jail but he is the only reason they made it out of that situation, and you're basically sending a message to people that says "don't do anything ethical like saving lives, it might just blow up in your face." It was a beautiful moment, him standing there, arms out, with his treasure blowing in the wind, knowing that in the end he'd given up everything for these people. And then all you get after that is Kristen and Jodie sipping a latte on a park bench reading the classifieds. "Hey, thanks. Life is good for us." Come on. Something should have turned out right for him. He turned back and they should have done something for him in return. That would have made this ending feel right.

Review title: If you love Jodie Foster, you must see this great thriller!
Review_body: I watch this movie every time it comes on cable! Jodie Foster gives the best performance of her life! In this thriller, a single mom, and her daughter, played by Kristen Stewart; have just moved into their new very luxurious condo in the city. The movie is all about just the one (first night) in their apt..totally,You cannot leave the room for a moment as you watch it,Jodie Foster is in for the fight of her life as some "robbers", have been planning to break in and steal some valuable bonds.I advise anybody that has not seen this movie to do so! You will love every minute of suspense, and; if you love Jodie Foster, it's a "must-see"!
You wont move from your sit kind of thriller. Some too mainstream story line but all in all good one time watcu

Director David Fincher dominated the box office in the 1990s with hits such as "Se7en" and "Fight Club", his first film of the new century was widely anticipated. With stars such as Jodie Foster (known for The Silence of the Lambs and Taxi Driver) and Jared Leto (known for Requiem for a Dream and American Psycho), it was bound to be a hit. Panic Room was considered to be a solid thriller, but audiences and critics alike compared it to that of Fincher's other work. Meg Altman (Foster's character) is the mother to Sarah Altman (Twilight girl), who is diabetic. Both move into a new home, which contains a panic room (hidden shelter). The room is proven useful when three men, Burnham (gentle giant Forest Whitaker, Raoul (country star Dwight Yoakam), and Junior (Jared Leto) decide to break in and uncover the secret that lies in the room. The cast is the film is solid, with characters that grow and change throughout the film. The audience eventually beings to care about the safety and survival of Meg and Sarah. The three thieves are likable and provide an entertaining yet well-written presentation to the film. The film really shines with the camera work and cinematography. There are many shots in the movie that one room to another and the execution of these shots is exceptional. The tension build-up and paranoia is amazing, and well done. The only real thing that crumbles, is the story line. It's similar to Cujo (1983) in the sense that the lead characters are trapped in a corner while the threat is lurking outside. It drags and drags to the point where the audience begs for something to happen. Overall however, this thriller is quite enjoyable. While not on the league of Se7en, it's a different and entertaining movie. It scores 7/10 stars. The great cinematography and acting are the best parts, while the story suffers a bit from slow pacing. Stream or buy this one!
The suspense is there, but I find the criminals dialogues very annoying. A bit too overly aggressive and dramatic. It's good to watch just to watch, not a movie you'll remember for a long time

This is a perfect vehicle for Jodie Foster--woman wronged gets her revenge. It is a theme throughout her later movies. I cannot imagine that this movie would have been as powerful with Kidman who portrays mostly frail characters.In a way, it is a period piece. The safe room is a metaphor for the tragedy of 9/11, about the fears we face in everyday life and how vulnerable we are.I love the moody, spectacular cinematography. Think about the camera work when it zooms through the kitchen, seemingly suspended. I agree that Finch is woefully underrated as a director.While the premise looms as somewhat predictable, what happens throughout the course of the story is anything but predictable-plot twists and turns abound.This movie is another gem in Jodie Foster's crown!

Review title: Chick flick meets Action film (warning: spoilers)
Review_body: This film is all about female empowerment. The basic plot is this: Smart, sexy newly divorced mother outwits bumbling male robbers. And on that level the plot works. In other words, if you're looking for some light entertainment to take your mind of your day to day problems, then this is a good way to kill a couple of hours. The main characters are well acted with great camera work and the director manages to keep the suspense going even though you can guess how its all going to end (I mean we've all seen Home Alone and we all know the dumb burglars are not going to get away with it). However, what spoils the film for me is the tedious sub plots: Foster coming to terms with her divorce and trying to build a relationship with her daughter. Okay, I realize its an unwritten rule in Hollywood that you can't have a convincing female lead who doesn't have some kind of emotional baggage. But, in this case it just slows down the film.

Review title: Reliance on cliches almost ruins a decent thriller
Review_body: Foster turns in a very convincing performance, and the bad guys are all effective and interesting, but over-reliance on cliches and showy, pointless camerawork brings down this film several notches.  A sampling of the more tired cliches:1)  Foster's character, who is forced to spend much of the film inside a small, windowless room, is a claustrophobic 2)  Her daughter is a diabetic who needs a shot or she will die 3)  The evil psychotic bad guy can withstand punishment that would kill HerculesFincher and the cast manage to mostly redeem the movie, although the former's use of camera pyrotechnics distracts from the tension more often than it helps.  Worth seeing, but catch a matinee unless you are an avid Fincher and/or Foster fan.

~yawn~A completely predictable thriller from start to finish.The only true suspense of the movie was when the house was being broken into.  As soon as the crooks break into the house you learned that this was going to be a home alone with a few gun shot victims.  Why even bother with going any further into the movie when the two idiots and the crook with a heart start messing things up within 20 minutes of the film.  The end feels like your starting back at the beginning with just as many unanswered questions: What happened to the dad?  Why did the only crook with a brain get caught after doing good things?  What happened with him?From start to finish, the film had MANY MANY flaws.  Examples of flaws include Jodie Foster's invincible to fire hand and the crook whose fingers were caught in the door that wasn't suppose to close on ANYTHING.  They go on and on, but ~yawning again~  Go see Ice Age!  It's a much better film!

I enjoyed the movie thoroughly though, some points of the film should have been more fully expanded upon or explained, that is not to say things are not explained but some points are mentioned only once and never refereed to again. The action is excellent and quite visual at points making for scenes which will actually have the crowd jumping. Though this is not Finchers strongest film I do recommended it.

Review title: Unrealistic, boring and takes your IQ for granted
Review_body: Panic room disappointed me.  It sounds a lot more interesting than it is. The premise is that a mom and her kids are trapped in a "safe room" while dangerous criminals try everything they can to get into the safe room.Unfortunately - the movie goes very wrong.First - I found her older kid distracting as I couldn't tell if it was a boy or a girl.  I know it sounds stupid, but the whole movie this bugged me. Secondly - I think this movie would have been much better if the criminals had a collective IQ above that of a rodent.  These are the dumbest criminals this side of "Home Alone".  Which makes the whole picture unbelievable. Thirdly - In a cat and mouse thriller - the movie needs to be one step above the audience.  This movie is so stupidly written that the audience figures out what's going to happen and waits for the film to catch up.The last distraction is that there is no point to the direction.  Camera shots are pointlessly convoluted (i.e. swoop down the stairs over the counter and through the keyhole).  It's like the director knew that the story couldn't hold it's own - so he threw in a bunch of camera effects just to try to keep the audience interested.This movie is unrealistic, boring and takes the audience's IQ for granted.3/10

I went to see this movie with my boyfriend a few days ago, and oh WHAT a HORRIBLY BORING film! NO suspense, NO Action! Not one damn thing to make this deserving of "Number one movie in America" at all! The movie is filled with moments of sheer stupidity and lack of any wit whatsoever. Don't wait for it to come out on video, wait for it to be the Channel 5 "3 AM Movie Feature".

This is one of those movies that guides the viewer through the movie.  You are shown enough to figure elements out on your own--without being treated as stupid. Jodie Foster is wonderful, her terror and her love and fear for her daughter (who is also a terrific actress, I look forward to seeing her in more movies) make for a wide range of emotions and attitudes.The movie shifts gears several times, so the viewer never gets too comfortable or bored with a situation.  David Fincher gives a whirlwind two hours that is heart-pounding (I didn't check my watch once, which generally implies the greatness of the movie).  But after "Fight Club" I expect that out of him. I rank it as one of the year's best so far.

If you suspense, you'll like this movie a lot.  All of the characters were pretty credible.  Perhaps the only aspect that didn't seem credible was that the burglars would choose to strike when they realized that Jodie Foster and daughter were home (as opposed to waiting for them go out the next morning, perhaps).  In a way, I found this movie to be reminiscent of the 1967 Audrey Hepburn flick, "Wait Until Dark".  The two movies share the following similarities:  NYC setting; a trio of bad guys infiltrating the home of an arguably helpless woman; the trio of bad guys looking for something in the woman's home that the woman doesn't know is there; one of the trio of criminals appearing to be more sympathetic than the others (Richard Crenna as "Mike Tallman" and Forrest Whitaker as "Burnham"; and  a young girl who helps the adult female main character.  There are probably other similarities that I'm overlooking.  Overall, this was a very good movie.

This movie had me sitting on the edge of my seat until the end of the movie. Jody Foster performed very well in the leading role. And literally I enjoyed 95% of the movie. It was the last 5% that caused me to have a let-down.The problem was that there were several outcomes at the end of the film, and I felt that the writer choose a very safe ending. What disappointed me about the ending was that there was no 'grey' area.  The movie ended quickly and in a very neat and tidy hollywood script fashion.

Plse note: spoilers below! I would have considered this movie to be a mediocre to fair thriller if not for one major flaw which ruined the whole movie for me.  This flaw was the injection scene.  Anyone who knows anything about diabetes knows that when someone is suffering from low blood sugar and verging on going into a coma the last thing you would do is inject them with insulin (which would just cause them to go into a coma that much faster and very likely kill them). Even if the syringe contained a sugar solution the film-makers should have known that to be the least bit effective this would have to have been injected directly into the blood stream not into stomach tissue.  Not only is it insulting to diabetics everywhere that the film-makers couldn't even be bothered to get the facts right about this deadly disease, but this depiction could conceivably result in a tragedy.  Anyone using this scene as a basic for trying to help someone who is suffering from low blood sugar could end up killing them.  Other minor flaws with the movie: how could Forest Whitaker's character have know what Jodie Foster's character was doing when she was trying to ignite the gas, how likely is it that Jodie Foster's character would know how to reconnect the phone, pushing a light sofa in front of the door is not terribly effective in blocking the door which is made clear when Jodie Foster's character had no problem later in the movie in getting the front door open, etc., etc., etc.  Very poorly thought out and executed.  Shame on you guys.

Review title: How do you get out of the Panic Room?
Review_body: Fincher is just a vision of a director.  I was one who could not wait to see this film for months ahead of time.I left the theater wondering - what was he thinking!  This movie started off just fantastic with the opening credits grabbing the eyes.  Though once in the Panic Room this movie takes a fast ride down a steep hill.  Save your money - rent the DVD or have someone tell you the whole story.  If you expect anything on the same level of Fight Club, ou will be hugely disapointed.

The acting and cinematography in this film are excellent.  (Jodie Foster and Forest Whitaker are particularly good.)  But, this is one of those movies where everyone is SCREAMING at the screen to do some really obvious things. (I have included some examples in the "SPOILER" section below.)  I know that this film is trying to lure you in and "feeeeeel" Jodie's pain, but when she can't even make simple, obvious choices to help herself I can no longer empathize with her.  I think, "She deserves to be stuck in there, she's just too stupid to be out roaming the streets with the rest of us."
Some of the camera shots are incredible and the timing of the movie is phenomenal.  You do manage to stay at the edge of your seat without a lot of TENSE music added to force you there.  Really, the movie is good, but the plot stinks.SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER!!!!!!!!!!!!
An example of how STUPID Jodie's character is.  In the trailers for the film they show this very creepy scene where the bad guys hold up a sign reading "What we want is in that room."  Now, does Jodie say "what is it?" or "how about I put it outside the door, you take it and then leave".  NOPE, nothing....the film doesn't even address that fact.  Later, it ends up being a stupid floor safe containing bonds.  That's another thing, she is in this tiny, tiny room making McGuyver-esque use of everything and she doesn't notice a safe under the area rug????????

Review title: Not as good as I thought it would be
Review_body: I went to see High Crimes, and decided afterwards that I would like to see Panic Room (I am a big fan of Jodie Foster).  I was a little disapointed. It lacked that very important factor that makes you sit on the edge of your seat.  Jodie and the girl did a good job of acting, but I personally thought some of the scenes were just too far fetched.  I mean, if you look on the video screens at the men to get out to get your cell phone, then surely you can look again to get out and call 911 when they are all downstairs, instead you have to to the lengthy procedure of trying to hook up the landline>>>>>>> A little bit dumb I think.  They had enough time to go out in the room, dial 911 and give the address and then run back into the panic room, while the robbers were downstairs.Anyway, it is an okay movie.

The movie is very thrilling... as it should be... I'm not going to tell you any details, it is more fun to go look for yourself.The only negative point I see, is that the ending lacked content. I think they could have considered a little more and made the ending a lot better!Enjoy the movie!

Review title: This is the worst movie ever made!
Review_body: If you need a movie spoon fed to you then this is the movie to watch.  It has the same plot as every other movie in theaters now and is insulting to the viewers intelligence.  The acting is horrible and the story line is painfully predictable.  Don't waste the time or money there are much more valuable things to do with the precious two hours of your life.

Brilliant. Jodie foster is a winner in this movie which is full of suspense. A great and original storyline adds to the effect. I First saw this on TV and was taken a back by the great acting, a really good film to see if there is nothing really to do. doesn't really require a lot of thinking so is good for the hard of thinking . I wasn't expecting much as I had not come across Jodie's former work such as the accused and silence of the lambs. She is a great actress who really delivers. Wow she is good and so convincing. Of course the film is not just about Jodie as the other members help bring the movie together. If you haven't seen this movie yet you must it will leave you shouting at the screen.

I'm not usually one for suspense/thrillers, but I am a big fan of Jodie Foster, so I went to see this movie.  It's excellent!  It keeps you guessing the entire way through.  I didn't know how it would end until literally 60 seconds before the film ended.  It's a very tight script, not a wasted moment (except maybe a rare few chatty bits with the bad guys) but the whole thing works so well in sequence, always surprising you, that it's definitely worth a look.  Suspense fan or not!  This movie had me clutching the armrests and covering my eyes.  I'm still wired from it, hours later.The cinematography is also amazing.  With a very limited set and a muted palette of colors, the cinematographer somehow manages to keep everything visually interesting and constantly varies what you see and how you see it. I love that in movies!  There was one funny moment when I realized from the changing angles that the camera person must have been perched on a toilet seat.  There are some amazing parts where the camera does impossible things.Overall Panic Room was a lot of fun, completely stressful, and not for the faint of heart!

I'm a huge David Fincher fan, and if you like his work, this movie doesn't disappoint. By no means flawless, Panic Room is a solid effort that's definitely worth checking out.The cast is fitting for the most part, I had my convictions against Jodie Foster in this role, but after viewing it I must say she did a good job. The three men who break into the house hold just as big a role also. They provide a good amount of humor at times (as do Jodie and Kristen Stewart, who plays the daughter role fairly well), and are easy to watch on screen. The movie itself moves along pretty quickly, and doesn't have very many dull moments.The standout point is by far David Fincher's incredible camera angles and techniques. If you were a fan of Fight Club's tracking shots that penetrate walls and buildings, and follow objects as they twist and turn (like the apartment explosion scene) then this movie will impress. Towards the beginning, it's absolutely full of them. This movie also holds some very intriguing action scenes that are executed well, though sometimes exaggerated in terms of reality (you'll see what I mean). As far as being suspenseful, at times Panic Room truly pulls of suspense.Overall, the acting is perfectly watchable, and the humor is actually very funny sometimes. If you can look past the mundane plot, the script is actually pretty refreshing in the way its handled. I personally think it falls apart near the end, and the ending itself left me kind of empty. But hey, you might like it. As a whole however, I'd say it's worth a look. Enjoy.

This movie was so full of holes that I don't know where to start. So I won't even bother! Jodie Foster is to good of an actress to be in junk like this.Why do actors get in these kind of movies, is it for the money or just to keep their faces in the public eye?

Thanks, Jodie Foster, for reassuring my confidence in you! In Panic Room, Foster gives a performance worthy of praise as a single mother in a terrifying situation. Moving in to a NY brownstone with her daughter, it's not long before she (Foster) must utilize the "panic room", a steel walled saferoom for paranoid rich people. The burgulars (Whitaker, Leto, and Yoakam) are there just to get-- you guessed it-- in that room. Whitaker plays to perfection a good guy in a bad situation once the power hungry Yoakam is brought in by the hysteria-prone Leto. Foster and her daughter (Stewart) must fend for themselves as the burgulars resort to devious methods to get them out. This movie thrilled me to the very bone, provoking true emotions out of me as I rooted for Foster. It's a frustrating, gritty, terrifying movie-- and if it's violent at times, it's because it should be. Go see it-- although don't be surprised if you find your legs jelly- like afterwards!

Review title: Great suspenseful, thinking mans thriller - (or womens' in this case)
Review_body: When I decided to watch Panic Room, I didn't think I would get much enjoyment out of it. Mainly because of the mixed reviews I've read on IMDb. But having watched this film, I realise that some people don't recognise a great, clever and personal film when they see one.The dialog in Panic Room is fantastic, especially the conversations between the three intruders. Characters where great and never veered off track - Raoul was the icing on the cake, being a socially retarded, violence buff.The only criticism I have with Panic Room are three things: One being that no-one can possibly walk on broken glass with bare feet (Jodie Foster) and two being that no-one would survive in igniting a room full of gas with a lighter. And finally third... NOBODY can survive a sledge hammer to the head... yes I'm looking at you Raoul.But that aside; Panic Room is a really suspenseful thriller and clever in it's logistics of story telling.Bernard: "Man, who the f@ck is he?" Raoul: "I'm Raoul..."

I consider Jodie Foster as the world's best actress and I always enjoy Forrest Whitaker. However, they were definitely plagued by a poor script. As writers and directors attempt to come up fresh ideas on the big screen, this one fell short of the mark. I didn't find myself scared at any moment during the film and the only suspenseful segment of the film was when Meg (Jodie Foster) was attempting to get from the panic room to retrieve her cellular phone. Expectations often play a role in determining whether or not a film is entertaining and that was the case with Panic Room. However, you still come to expect to be scared at some point by watching a movie that is called a 'thriller.' I was not. Bring back 'The Exorcist!' Now that's scary!

The first 7 minutes were excellent, building up the suspense and I was looking forward to the rest of the movie. However, this is where it went pear shaped, it was stupid, I laughed out loud at inappropriate moments, It could have been a movie about 3 dim witted burglars like a remake of a 3 Stooges film. Terrible waste of my time.

Review title: One of the best action-thrillers I have seen in a long time...
Review_body: What can I say?  It's been almost 2 hours since I walked out of the preview screening... and I'm struggling to find a flaw in the whole film. The acting is top-notch, with the characters being believable and the talents sliding into these forms effortlessly.  Jodie Foster stands out though as Meg, the lead character who has just gone through a divorce and is trying to settle down in a new house with her daughter. As a strong Fincher fan I was not at all disappointed with this film, as I knew before I saw it that there was no way it would be as good as Fight Club.  It was better than The Game (starring Michael Douglas), which I thought was dragged out a bit too much and had an ending which, amongst my group of friends and myself, has been the target of many laughable conversations, although I guess there wasn't really any alternative... I can only pick on one part of Panic Room - the ending.  I won't give anything away (coz that'd be nasty) but you do get out of your seat thinking "hmmm. I wish they'd at least done something better with the money than that..." Otherwise, all the other Fincherisms were there.  The CG-assisted camera shots moving through walls etc (like in Fight Club) could be considered overkill, but I prefer to look at them as required art which raises the tension by portraying the proximity of the burglars to the females, whilst raising the sense of chlaustrophia in the Panic Room itself. With enough touches of humour to call this a part-comedy, this is a thriller that grabs you, throws you about a bit and doesn't let go until the final scene... and the action sequences themselves are pulled off with incredible stamina and energy.  And boy, that bit with the cellphone, all in slow-mo and absolutely NO sound whatsoever... had me sweating! This is going straight on my 'to-buy' list...

Started hating the movie when Jared Leto said "she's a woman she needs assurance"
Clearly a white man wrote this movie, lazy.
What kind of a panic room doesn't have food???? Or an insulin shot if your daughter has diabetes??

I happened to catch a screening of David Fincher's new film "Panic Room" while I was on vacation in Los Angeles. Since 3 out of 4 of his movies have been disappointing for me, I wasn't to enthusiastic about it.It tells the story of Meg Altman and her daughter Sarah. Meg has been recently divorced and both of them are looking for new life after the rather unsuccessful marriage. So they settle down in the big city and find a nice, cozy, perfect house. Or is it...They learn of a safe or "panic" room in the house that has video screens, buried phone line, ventilation system, and a 1 foot thick steel wall. Why would a house need a room like this and when would they need to use it? They find out soon enough.One of their first nights in the house (You'll never guess) people break in. Meg and Sarah are able to get to the Panic Room quick enough, however, to hide from the intruders for a short time. So the first 2 questions on the 2 girls' minds are, of course: Who are you, and what are you doing in my house. They find out that the burglars want nothing other that what is in that room. In fact, they won't leave until they get it. So what is in the room that is soooo special. Are you just dying to know otherwise you won't see it because it looks too scary or something? Well I'm not going to tell you. It's against IMDB regulations.I will however say that this is a very VERY creepy film. If you get the heeby-jeebies already when you stay home alone, this movie will make you catatonic. Just because it takes place in a house doesn't mean there isn't room for fancy camera work. David Fincher can and does take the camera wherever he wants to. Whether it's through cracks in the wall, keyholes, or coffee pot handles, the camera will go there.So did I like it? Yes I did. It is my favorite movie of 2002 so far. (Keep in mind there haven't been many good ones) I loved pretty much everything about it. Do I recommend it? Yes, but only to people who loooooooove a good scare.

Panic Room is what you expect and a lot more.  It is overall a great movie, the only problem I have with it is that if you pay close attention to the beginning of the movie and minor plot line is given away, other than that it was a good flick.  This movie is worth the full price of ticket.

Panic Room starts out giving us a detailed tour of a 3 story brownstone built in the later 1800's located on the upper west side of Manhattan that has quite a storied history with the last owner being a paranoid rich eccentric.  The house looms large as the 3rd main character with it's intriguing construction and the inclusion of the "Panic Room", which in theory is an impenetrable room from which one escapes harm.  Located inside the Panic Room and it's 3 inch steel enforced reinforced walls, floor and ceiling are various supplies such as blankets, food, water and a state of the art video surveillance system with cameras in virtually every room of the house.  The movie starts out a bit on the slow side and adequately builds the suspense throughout the movie.
