If you're looking for a well written, superbly acted suspense movie, this is the film for you!The real movie starts when 3 intruders break into the house and the two tenants (Meg and Sara Altman) are forced to escape into the Panic Room. The intruders (played with more than adequate believability by Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto and Dwight Yoakam) believing the house to be empty, are there to crack a safe located inside the Panic Room.  Things begin to unravel when the intruders realize that a mother and daughter are located in the house.The two main characters (Meg and Sara) played with wonderful brilliance by Jodi Foster (as a recently divorced mother of one) and Kristen Stewart (in only her 2nd performance in as many years) as her 11 year-old, wise-cracking, diabetic daughter are forced to retreat to the Panic Room when Sara realizes there are unwanted "guests".  After it's clear that Meg and Sara won't come out of the Panic Room, the intruders bolt, screw and nail all the doors and windows thereby ruining the chance of escape.  One feels trapped inside the house and the Panic Room for the rest of the movie as Meg and Sara Altman feel.  The rest of the movie is a well constructed with even some light and funny moments.  If you want to learn more, GO SEE THIS MOVIE!!

Review title: Really enjoy this more with each time I watch
Review_body: I didn't feel like Panic Room stood up to Fincher's previous lovable monsters (The Game, Seven, and Fight Club) but it was certainly better than what most people claim it to be. This movie has an incredible cast, a grouping that I wouldn't think could have played off of each other so well, but Fincher made it work nicely. After reading on who was originally cast, I applaud Fincher for going with Jodie Foster, she's dead on excellent in 'most' of her roles and is very believable in this film. To me, though, Kristen Stewart and Jerod Leto steal the scenes until the end where Dwight and Forrest really step out of the shadows and perform brilliantly! Take this movie for what you will, but the idea of it on top of the excellent direction makes it a classic thriller in the path of mid-era Hitchcock films.

Review title: Held my attention for nearly 2 hours!
Review_body: First let me echo the comment about the wicked-cool opening credits. Something I've never seen before but will probably be used in many movies to come.The movie was paced well, like the headline says I never even looked at my watch, a rare occurrence for me.  It is a good movie to take you away for a couple hours, as there are few moments where you are not anticipating the next move by the girls or the boys.  Unfortunately a healthy handful of those moves are fairly predictable, as with most suspense/thrillers these days.  The R rating is almost not needed, although a couple of shots are somewhat graphic and Jodie Foster uses the F word.  At least the idea is original, hats off to Koepp for that.

Review title: Captivating Thriller, Fincher reigns supreme once more
Review_body: While his other movies have all silent thunderstorms, Panic Room has the media hype to match the brilliance of the film, for better or worse. I belieive worse. For people expecting some horror flick with a bit of a thrill you're mistaken. This film while it has its brilliant moments which will, shoot me for using this terribly over used cliche', have you sitting on the edge of your seat, is mainly a great film to watch, and watch again because of the mastery Fincher has over the camera, his ability to place the camera anywhere, and i use that in the exact sense, is spectacular. The film it self lacks the depth and creative flare commonly assosiated with this now, household name director. David Keopp, who also wrote Jurassic Park (screenplay)and number two and three doesn't handle the mood and tempo of the movie with the correct dialoge, perhaps his intention to make it comedic, however jokes in the wrong places never work. Overall a great film to watch but do not go into it expecting anything better than Fight Club, alas, perhaps i shall view it with these intentions myself.

As an avid movie-go'er I have high standards when it comes to movies, and Panic Room was not exception, I thought it was great. The ideas, action and cinematography were excellent. Panic Room kept u in a suspenseful state the whole way through and guessing what would happen next, a must see movie...Better than fight club!!! (just by a bit)

I am a fan of Fincher.  I love Fight Club, I like Seven and my opinions for his other films vary.  His direction was so absurdly horrible, I couldn't help but to be distracted.  Almost every shot was unmotivated toward the action; the camera was subjective to the house more than the characters, so the visual aspects dominated the film.  Further more, it is my opinion that the visual aspects of the film (Fincher's trademark), were nothing to behold.  The lens choices were terrible; extreme wide shots of intense drama on charcters made certain scenes come across phony; the lack of depth of field and very wide lenses, caused shot after shot to have so much 'dead space' in the frame, it seemed painfully obvious the reason was for a claustrophobic mood. As a fan of Fincher, it was a slap in the face to have the amount of product placement abundant (the Cocca Cola scene in the beginning is cringe inducing), when his previous 'Fight Club' basically negated his aesthetic choices in this film.  The screenplay was brain dead and gimmicky, mood was so contrived it was shoved down your throat.  Maybe Fincher should calm down a bit, understand the meaning of the term subtly and not be so in our face. Just because the camera moves through objects doesn't mean it is well directed, motivation is the key and that was absent.

Perhaps you saw Fight Club and could appreciate the visceral intensity but were put off by its muddled message. Or maybe you saw Se7en and noticed the slick and grainy visual style, but couldn't handle the more grotesque aspects of that film. Or maybe you (like me) love everything Fincher's ever done and cannot wait to be once again welcomed into his world of paranoia, pathos, and amazing visuals. Well, no matter who you are, you need to see Panic Room.In Panic Room, David Fincher pulls out all the directing stops, every trick in his magic black bag of film wizradry and delivers on a simple, solid suspense story with none of the concept or pretense of his previous films. This one goes straight for the gut, fiendishly manipulating every standard suspense contrivance, mercilessly playing with any jangly nerve, and keeping you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.There is not one sour note in the whole film (with the exception of the possibly too Hollywood ending, but it still works). Every aspect of Fincher's technical mastery is on full display. His camera moves gracefully across every square inch of the house which becomes a prison for Jodie Foster and her daughter, and the three men who break in one night in search of the former owners hidden riches. In one amazing shot, Fincher moves from the fourth floor of the house where Foster and her daughter are sleeping soundly, all the way down to the first floor where we see the intruders beginning their break-in, throught the handle of a coffee pot, and then all the way BACK UP to the fourth floor where they finally succeed in getting in without the shot breaking once and sliding the whole time with the cool, slow, impartial grace of a cat burglar.The premise is simple: Foster and her daughter are locked in an impenetrable room in their home, along with the loot that the 3 bad guys are looking for. The bad guys want in, the good guys want them out of the house. The plot is really as simple as that, but in Fincher's hands it turns into a beautifully paranoid battle of wits. No time is wasted on anywhere and the suspense is instantly in high gear. The performances are all perfect, with characters fully developed in their first moments of screen time. You know who everyone is right away, with no time wasted on extraneous details, so all that's necessary is to sit and wait while the tension builds to the breaking point. It is a terribly effective tactic as it leaves the audience totally open to watch the sparks fly without miring them in sentimentality.Essentially, if you like suspense, see this movie.

Review title: A good movie, but Hitchcock it is not.
Review_body: This movie is about fear and suspense, and it does a terrific job of scaring you and keeping you on the edge of your seat.  Jodie Foster is as remarkable as she always is, once again proving she is among the elite actors in the world.  Forrest Whittaker is also great playing the more sympathetic of the criminals who break into the house.  Jared Leto is very good as well, and even Dwight Yoakam is good.Fincher does some incredible camera work, bringing the perspective through floors, keyholes and anything he cares to.  The tracking shots are good and help build the psychological drama of the film.In the end, the movie failed for me because of one small point that it is hard to tell without giving away much of the film.  The criminals fail to do one incredibly simple thing to make their lives easier simply to allow the criminals and the captives to communicate.I still give this movie 7 of 10 because of the fear that Fincher creates. If the criminals had been smarter, it could have been a 10, though.

Review title: The worst movie I have ever seen
Review_body: I saw the trailer to this movie and decided not to go. Joy of joys I was then invited to see a preview screening for free. I went with low expectations and these were shattered. This film is contrived, insulting, boring and a total waste of your time and money.It is not the scary suspense you are lead to believe by the trailer. In fact you've only just met Jodie Foster and her daughter when the crime begins, and you care no more for them as characters than the criminals who are trying to get inside the "panic room". The minimal plot is completely inconsistent and has you laughing in despair. After films such as Fight Club and Seven, it's hard to see how the director could have made a film so monumentally awful. Sadly though your left wondering if it was all done on purpose, not so much as to mess with your mind, but just to see how disappointed and angry they can make you feel, whilst running away with your cash.On top of this the film was shot terribly, showing countless close ups of mundane items, such as phone rechargers and plugs, and repeatedly flying the camera through walls, door cracks, key holes and coffee pot handles. Complemented by blatant brand placement, contrived close ups of Jodie's bust and unnecessarily gruesome violence.However, there is in fact a good game you can play with this film. Take any detail, and then ask yourself "Does this really make sense?" or "Was this believable?". I challenge you to find one thing that made sense.  A few for example...If you built a panic room so that no one could get in or harm the occupant, would you really put the wires and ventilation system on the outside?Rather than simply stocking a panic room with water, might you not also put some food inside?Is there any reason why you can't use a cell phone inside the room? Wouldn't this have been an obvious feature?It goes on and on, but don't waste too much more of your time on it, you've already been robbed of 2 hours.

I thought that this was yet another cinematical achievement for David Fincher.  His fast becoming signature camera angles and filming style shine yet again.  Being a huge fan of both Fight Club and Seven, it is very satisfying to see his work maturing.  I am very sure that David Fincher is well on his way to becoming a key factor in the shaping of twenty-first century cinema. The movie itself is very fast paced and very well written.  I will admit I went to this movie not expecting much, and I was pleasantly surprised leaving very happy.  If you are going to see one film this weekend, I recommend this one.

I don't find fault with the acting or directing of this film.  The camera angels on many shots were new and innovative. But the writing was was terrible.  The premise was a good idea, but this was just stupid and predictable.  There was very little suspense.  Many of the people in the theater were laughing and checking their watches.

Review title: Jodie Foster still a favorite with me...script needs help though!
Review_body: If you like Jodie Foster, then see this movie. She's is still an excellent actress and, Kristen Stewart, who plays her 12 year old daughter, is just as good!  This kid was remarkable in this film. It was fun, exciting, and tense on the whole but I was distracted by a few "holes" in the story.  For example, it bugged me that she didn't tip off the police when they FINALLY arrived at her door.  The premise being she couldn't say a word because she was being watched on a security camera by the "villians" but in actuality they couldn't "hear" her so she could have easily alerted the police that she was in trouble.Another scene which really didn't make sense was in the first 1/2 hour of the film when the thieves break into her home and realize someone has actually moved into the once vacant house and now lives there.  Any good villian would know to leave and come back later when it is safer; namely, when no one was home. DAH! And I'm not even in the robbery business!!  All in all, I enjoyed it.

Wow, this gave me the six cups of coffee shakes.An extraordinary on the edge of the seat thriller, Foster is superb, it really really scared me!It has an intense claustrophobic feel, combined with some great camera angles and shots

This truly was a great movie. Unlike anything other movie I've ever seen, Panic Room was a very suspenseful, scary, and extremly emotional film. Jodie Foster gives a great performance, and while this movie was not a extraordinarly action-packed, it delivers so well on the suspence and emotional planes, it recieves my highest recomendation without a doubt. A true "edge-of-your-seat" thriller, Panic Room is not to be missed and is by far the best movie I have seen so far in 2002, and probably the best thriller I have ever seen as well.

As a film lover I have always found David Fincher's style to be new and fresh, very entertaining to watch.  His past three films, Seven, The Game, and Fight Club are at the top of my lists.  However, I was very disappointed with PANIC ROOM.With the slim two-dimensional characters, a mediocre plot line, and the poor dialogue I had a hard time believing I was watching a Fincher Film. The acting was good for what they had to work with, but the ending and the plot progressions were very predictable and heavy handed.  Fincher style usually is to give you bits and pieces of information as you need it, but in PR the audience knows what is going to happen 30-40 minutes before it actually happens.  I do not know if it is the script, the editor or produces' that are responsible for this piece... But we know that Fincher can direct a great film and the visuals were great.  But something was wrong.  This is not a great film in my opinion.For the new Director of Photography Conrad, I think the film looked like a great film.  But it was lacking in so many departments that it is considered to me as just fair.

Review title: nothing makes sense in this movie
Review_body: ***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** I like the idea of the panic room, but the room itself has to be much better than the one in the movie. And too many things in the movie that do not make sense: (POSSIBLE SPOILERS, so do not read on if you dont' want to be spoiled, but the movie is SO predictable anyway)1. You call 911 and get placed on hold after you tell them your address and it's an emergency? 2. Cell phones don't work in the room? If it was a room designed for the purpose as described in the beginning of the movie, shouldn't cell phones be usable in it? 3. Isn't it obvious to just kill all the surveilance cameras all over the house so people in the room won't know what you're doing? 4. Can't Jodie Foster tell the cops something or signal something since she was in the room before and should know they can't hear her from inside the room? 5. How can someone get smashed in the head like that not only not die, but still has the power to wrestle someone down and try to kill her? etc.etc. please write a better script next time Fincher.

Review title: Best movie I've seen so far this year.
Review_body: I had heard a guy on the radio comment that this was the best movie he had seen all year, and that it had him on the edge of his seat the whole time. For whatever reason, that was the only person I heard giving it good press. For the week between when I heard that interview and when I actually got to see the movie, all I heard was about how awful this movie was.  How the plot was totally unbelievable.  How Jodie Foster's acting was horrible (which is totally untrue...I've never seen her give a bad performance).  And so on.I'm glad I went to see the movie based on the radio reviewer's recommendation.  The acting was great, the plot was great, and the movie really did have me on the edge of my seat.  I also liked the fact that the movie didn't drag on forever, boring you until it got to the good part.  My eyes were glued to the screen the entire time.  The movie did kind of creep me out; going home to a dark, quiet house after watching that movie felt kind of scary.Anyway, its the best movie I've seen so far this year.

Review title: PANIC ROOM - THE NEXT GENERATION IN MOVIES
Review_body:
The movie that took Australia to the cinemas wasn't starwars 2 or any other movie of that sort it was actualy a movie that was made and filmed in New York ! Some people say its a simple story line - well if so how come no one had fort of it Unbelivable GREAT WORK FROM KRISTEN STEWART (Sarah Altman) DAVID Fincher (directer) Jodie Foster (Mis Altman) and all the others including Forest Wilker As we all Know the mother has split up with sarah's father and poor sarah is stuck in the middle, she's a tough chic but she's under alot of stress parents splitting up, new school, missing her old friends and making new ones + on top of all that she's a diabetic Sarahs mom/mum is also understress divorce and she's going back to school (uni) to finish a course Burnan - one of the robbers, poor bloke - he's at the right place at the wrong time - he's a good robber if there is one a quote from the movie " Hey I told you I don't hurt people" there are several other character in this GREAT THRILLER !!! There are moments of incredible comedy and drama A MUST SEEC U IN THE FUTUREKRISTEN STEWART RULES
PEACE OUT

Kristen stewart - the 12 year old who looks like she's about 17 did very considering this was her first major flick... in my opinion... She was competent and convincing. Foster was also very good and although the plot was slightly predictable the foster-stewart relationship kept the pace of the film up.

I thought to myself, great, David Fincher is brilliant, this will be fantastic, but no. Panic Room is disappointing at best. It starts well, with wonderfully clever long, sweeping shots full of Fincheresque imagination, and little cinematic hints of events to follow, however, the subtle hints begin to become screamingly overdone, and the audience is treated as children to be explained to. This never happens in Fincher's past gems. Also, never before have we had to put up with ridiculously stupid characters; the premise of the movie is flawed, no protagonist or antagonist should be that ill equipped.

Review title: A nice ride, tad predictable - spoiler!
Review_body: This movie really did have me on the edge of the seat - however the movie was not completely perfect.Some of the plot was predictable - such as when the three men kept arguing, and the fact that it seemed obvious it would lead in part to their downfall, and the ending was a tad trite - however in terms of a suspense movie, I think it really delivered.It has been accused of several flaws which I thought I would address in my own understanding of the movie:that you could speak out of the panic room, but not in.. I don't remember anything being said about that, and when it did happen, Jodie Foster's character used an intercom which I thought was part of the security system in general.that "Raoul" could not have gotten his hand stuck due to sensors being in the door.  Yes there were sensors, in my understanding there was one at the head, one at the chest area and one at the feet - but these don't sweep the whole way down, therefore if his hand was not where a sensor was, it would get caught (which it did).One flaw that really was a flaw however was the gas cylinder scene - it was wishful thinking to believe that it would be possible to do that and not blow the whole place up or something equally drastic!!I find the movie visually was quite appealing, and the opening credits really set the scene, and made me think this movie was going to be something different than a movie about a panicky mum.As to Meg turning away the cops - well it's simple really.. if she let them in, the men would have killed her daughter for sure, but by not letting them in on anything, she could be sure that at least whilst inside that room, her daughter would be safe.  As to why she didn't wink etc.. I'm not sure, it could be something to do with the fact that she was freshly divorced and wanted to prove she could stand on her own and be just as capable as any man.All in all, it's NOT a waste of money, it's a nice ride even though at some points a tad predictable - in general, I don't think David Fincher has let himself down with this one.

The film explores the basic psychology of survival in a clever, well-timed manner. The characters play a cat and mouse game with unpredictable twists in the house. Given the length of the film, it may be too much to ask for more character development and better dialogue, especially for the chief baddie. Altogether an unexpectedly enjoyable ride!

A completely ineffectual thriller that has all the fancy camera work, top set design and an A list actress and director.  What's missing though is the suspense, intrigue, and that on the edge of your seat aura.  Kudos to Jodie Foster for doing a fine job in a very sterile film.  A half empty script that's beautifully shot.Pick yourself up one of those black and white british thrillers from the 60's.  That's the real Mccoy, this is just Hollywood baloney.

Jodie Foster registers well as a middle aged New Yorker looking for a new house with her teenage daughter (K Stewart) in the city. During their first night in they're spacious new Brownstone home three burglars break-in resulting in a game of "Cat and Mouse".This movie had high expectations and it didn't fail to deliver. With its suspenseful scenes and great visuals this movie is one of my favorites. The opening scene has shown the capability of computer graphics/generation today. The location was chosen very wisely as it brought twists into the script.Although Jodie Foster was very convincing (as usual) it didn't make up for the long and tedious second half of the film. Most of the twists were very predictable and didn't deliver the suspense.On another note Kristen Stewart proved herself in her first big role. She plays the diabetic daughter of Jodie Foster. Kristen and Jodie worked extremely well together, resulting in two very well played characters. On the same note Jared Leto brought a very much-needed comical element to his character (Junior).Even though this movie had its major flaws it still delivered a decent script and great cinematography.

Way ahead of it's time. If you can come up with a story based in a single room and make it as engaging and exciting as this one... you deserve to be frozen and preserved for future teaching of inspiring film makers. This is a fantastic film and I'm glad Jodie Foster was available for the lead when Nicole Kidman got knocked up and bailed. I loved the off-character casting of Jared Leto and the unbelievable casting of Dwight Yoakam... DWIGHT YOAKAM. Everything worked. Another great, and yet again... underrated film by David Fincher. How long is it going to take for an established directed like Fincher to take a chance and roll the dice on trying to make a script like this work again? ...No one has the guts.

Review title: Not Fincher's best, but still impressive
Review_body: This latest movie by David Fincher is not exactly what you may call a masterpiece, but is still one of the best thrillers in a long time. First of all, because it's a Fincher. And you can see the director's cut. He used most of the same techniques that made his previous movies (Se7en, Fight Club, The Game) the best thrillers of the 90s. Then, there is the superb cinematography of Darius Khondji, who really puts his mark on the tensionate atmosphere in the picture with slow moves of the camera. Jodie Foster also gives a pretty good performance and the villains are beautifully portrayed by Forrest Withaker, Christian Bale and Dwight Yoakam. So it's a decent movie, but not revolutionary (like Se7en and Fight Club) and I think that Fincher is indeed a master of suspense. Probabily, the new Hitchcock. The only thing that disappointed me in Panic Room was the end. A bit to predictable. Otherwise, a good film that might haunt you for a while. 8/10

After watching the trailers, I was really looking forward to watching this movie.  But the plot holes, inconsistent character behaviors and erratic character development left me wondering why this received such favorable critical reviews.  The acting was not bad, but I thought the writing was inconsistent and illogical.  Places where I should have been on the edge of my seat, I was unable to because I was still shaking my head at events leading up to those points.  I give this a 5 out of 10.

*spoilers!!!*To my opinion, Panic Room was made with a great fealing for building up the tension and keeping it that way. I got incredibly nervous when Jodie Foster ran out into her bedroom to get her cell phone while the burglars were comming back up.However, there were few strange parts in the story which altered my overall rating on this film.1. If the panic room is so designed that it would imposible to get in, why is it possible that intruders can easily access the phone lines and the ventilation shafts? I mean, that clearly showed that this panic room was not as safely as it should have been. The drain tunnel wich Jodie Foster and her daughter used to send light signals through it could also have been used by the burglars to blow in gas or something.2. Why wouldn't there be any other means of communication in the panic room? Now the victims had only 1 phone that they could use, so that if the phone would not work (which was the case), they would be stuck there forever! There should have been something like a cell phone with a large antenna or a 27MC radio.3. Why was it impossible to talk to the police? The burglars could not hear Jodie Foster talking, so if she just said like "my daughter is held hostage and if you show up she will be shot", than the police would at least try to find a solution. If the squadteam showed up just 10 minutes earlier, then maybe the daughter would have been shot because the burglars would think that Jodie Foster alarmed the police!!Without these flaws I would give the movie an 8, but now only a small 6. If you shoot a movie at such a small spot with a small number of actors, than you should invest the energy and time you gained by that into a foolproof script.

I watched Panic Room not knowing what to expect, I read nothing about it. I only knew that the cast had award winning actress Jodie Foster known for her role in "Silence of the Lambs". Knowing her from that movie and seeing the cover art of the DVD for Panic Room lead me to think this was a horror movie. I was happily surprised to see that Jared Leto was in the movie because he's a great actor and one of my favorite singers. Forest Whitaker is always good, and it was funny to see a young Kristen Stewart. Kristen is 12 in this movie and she does a surprisingly good job and turns out to be one of the most likable characters. So right off the bat the cast is strong. So the plot is a mom and her daughter move into a new house that has a room that is for emergencies that has a vault like door and monitors on the wall to watch whats going on inside the house. Three robber break in not knowing they moved in. When the robbers first break in one of them named Raoul drops 3 one liners that had me laughing at each one. This movie has several comedic moments that are sure to make you laugh. This movie isn't all jokes though, at times you're at the edge of your seat. It's a great thriller because the situation these people are in could happen to anyone. Well anyone who has an enormous room in their house with screens so you can watch whats going on in every room. You get so attached to the characters in this movie that you really want them to get help. On the other hand though you also like the dialog between the robbers so you don't really want them to be caught. I loved this movie and would suggest it to anyone.

Review title: Some Plot holes, but still decent movie
Review_body: Panic Room is not a bad film by any means, but it does suffer somewhat from a mediocre script, thin characterization and a lackluster ending.The main problem I have with Panic Room is the performance of the three thieves. They enter the film like The Three Stooges, immediately undermining the tension that their entrance generates. I mean, for the film to work as strongly as it could, they should be a major threat, but instead they enter the film while bickering like a bunch of numbskulls. And two of them even think they can break through concrete and three inch steel with a sledgehammer. You're dealing with mental midgets here.Stupidest of the three is Leto's character. He doesn't know how escrow works, he puts his head against the wall when Foster is about to ignite the gas they're pumping into the panic room, he shouts at a PA system and he exposes his plan to screw over his fellow burglars simply by talking to himself. The extent of his stupidity is really too much to ask of an audience with any intelligence and his whole character smacks of lazy writing.But thankfully Leto's character gets shot halfway through. And his killing is nicely done. It's quick, it's brutal and it allows the unhinged Raoul to step up to the plate as the main villain. And although Raoul is a knob and a bit of a rent a psycho, he does seem like a genuine threat. And it's even more impressive considering that the actor who plays him, Dwight Yoakam, is a country music star. He may sing hick music, but he turns in a superb performance.But although Yoakam is excellent, the film easily belongs to Foster. She's strong, she's resourceful and she's entirely believable as a mother who'll blow your head off if you mess around with her kid. After all, is there anything more dangerous than a mother backed into a corner? Personally I'd rather take on a 6 foot 4, 300-pound, bum-hungry redneck called Bubba than a 5 foot 4 woman who wants to defend her kid. The burglars should have left the second they realized they were dealing with a 'mom'.However, while I can easily believe in Foster managing to wrestle a gun off of the psychotic Raoul (again illustrating how stupid the thieves are, Raoul at one point tells her to come out of hiding so he can shoot her and get things over. Didn't he ever have a mum?), her MacGyver routine stretches credibility – igniting the gas is fair enough, but there's one bit where she somehow hooks up the phone line. She even says, "I have no idea" when her daughter asks her what she's doing. It's obvious that Koepp (the writer) has written himself into a corner and this is the result: suddenly she's a phone expert. But I'm willing to overlook these sorts of things as Fincher gives us ample opportunity to stare at Foster's cleavage when things get silly. It was actually an excellent decision to have her spend virtually the whole film in a black vest, as you're never too far from jiggling breasts, which is fair compensation for gaps in logic.

PANIC ROOM (2002) Jodie Foster stars in Panic Room, written by David Kroepp and directed by David Fincher. The movie tells the story about Meg (Foster) who inhabits an apartment in Manhattan. The Realtor explains to her that this house contains a 'panic room', which is used to ward off any intruders.Unfortunately, the Panic Room is something Meg and her daughter Sarah are forced to use on their first night there: three burglars enter her house searching for something. Unfortunately, what they need is in the Panic Room! The burglars stop at nothing to get her out, while Meg tries to defend herself from their attempts.The story is pretty simple, and all plays in one day (and night). There are only two locations used in this film: a bench in NY City and of course the house Meg and Sarah live in. The story takes a simple approach to a not very original plot.However, David Fincher manages to make this in to a thrilling experience, which makes Meg twist and turn to get her out of the Panic Room. The film is nowhere scary, but the thrill is there; and how! The minimum cast (mainly consisting of 6 people) sets an experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Furthermore, Kristen Stewart does an excellent performance as Sarah; the diabetes-daughter.Then why not give this film a 10/10? Because it fails to add any originality or story twists. From the moment you start, you can pretty much expect what's going to happen. Furthermore, the CG Title Sequence seems to hi-tech to compare with the simplicity of the film. The long takes, which take the viewer from the top floor, all the way to the third are (although beautifully shot) again a total difference from the style of the movie. It seems that these things were included to make sure the audience would not write this off as a independent film of some sort.On a total view, the film is certainly not bad and is definitely worth viewing. If you're a fan of very thrilling, yet not complicated films: watch this. If you like clever story lines and plot twists, you might want to leave this.

Review title: Kill a little girl with 2 cops present?
Review_body: Loved this film as it's always a pleasure to watch an actress as talented as Jodie Foster. I did however give the film 9 out of 10 due to a plot element that truly annoys me. What mother, regardless of how strong her maternal instinct is, would actually believe that the intruders would have killed her daughter whilst two cops were present? Compound home invasion, burglary, assault and murder with a second murder with nothing to gain but more jail time? Would any criminal be THAT stupid? She could have swung the door wide open and told them they were in the panic room on the third floor with her daughter. The End? Perhaps they would have shut the door and taken her hostage? That would be a truly ironic plot twist.

Panic Room is a wonderful piece of film-making, a pure thriller.  Almost the entire film takes place inside of one house, in a near real-time unfolding of events.  Fincher takes us on a modern-day Hitchcock ride, building suspense at every turn.  With obvious inspiration from "Rear Window", the film is a joy to watch, and keeps you on the edge of your seat.  The acting is top-notch, Jodie Foster is great, Jared Leto turns in a performance above anything he's done to date.  Forrest Whittaker is magnificent, building his character as much by his actions as by his silence.  And Dwight Yoakam is the most surprising, entirely unrecognizable, and one of the most terrifying characters seen on screen in a while--pure coldness.  All in all, the acting and directing make this movie subtly disturbing, unlike any suspense film we've seen in a while, from the visually stunning opening credits to the morally ambiguous ending.  It all combines to more than make up for minor shortcomings in the script--tacked on developments to hastily add more suspense.In short, it's worth watching.  Five characters, one house, two hours, and constant thrills.

Review title: An enjoyable, if somewhat disappointing thriller
Review_body: Fincher's "Seven" and "Fight Club" were masterpieces in my opinion, so I was enthusiastic to see his latest, "Panic Room."  Unfortunately, I am not so enthusiastic about recommending it to others.  It is definitely signature style, David Fincher, but it appears as if Hollywood script doctors got ahold of this otherwise excellent movie.To start with, it has all the usual Fincher direction.  As a telephone call is placed, you get the camera moving along with the 'pulse' through the phone wires.  As a key is inserted in a lock, you are treated to the same perspective as the key.  All of this is signature Fincher (see Fight Club's opening sequence if you don't know what I mean).  Visually, it is an excellent film.  Fincher deserves the usual credit for direction and casting.  The actors portray real emotions on screen.  Jodie Foster does an excellent job of emoting as a mother, and Forest Whitaker's concern for life comes across colorful conflict.Unfortunately, the writing withers.  A sudden surprise illness of the daughter, Kristen Stewart, seems too scripted to be believable.  Likewise with appearance of police officers, and the ludicrous dialogue in the '911' call for help.  Why do script doctors, writers, and other Hollywood parasites continue to churn out carnage?

I'd read in a review something about laughs, and thought there must have been some kind of mistake.  Yet as I sat on the edge of my seat last night, I found there were several great laughs in this one!  Not to mention all the suspense and action.  This is an extremely well-written, original movie that will surely draw huge crowds.  The ONLY thing I didn't like was that there were some bloody scenes that didn't need to be quite so gruesome. The characters were flat, the villains were wusses (with the exception of Raoul, but even he lost all his mystique when he took off the ski mask), the action was minimal, and the story was lame. I caught a prescreening tonight of panic room and just loved it, so much in fact that I don't have any finger nails left to bite. The camera work was incredible, the pacing was spot on, and the performances were good, no Oscars here, but more than enough to carry the film.  Even the titles were awesome. This movie is about as tense as they come, the climax will have your pulse sprinting.  Jodie Foster delivers the goods yet again, Fincher keeps everything moving, and David Koepp has written an excellent script, go see it!

Review title: Movie was flawed by unbelievable or bogus situations.
Review_body: This had the opportunity to be a good movie, but the story line and characters were so flawed it was pathetic. The little girl is portrayed as being a diabetic going into a coma because of low blood sugar. Unfortunately, the insulin shot she supposedly needs would worsen her condition, not help. Diabetics suffer from high blood sugar, unless they take too MUCH insulin. Then, there is a third crook who suddenly is brought in, for no reason, other than to be the mean guy. The fellow who is supposedly smart enough to design panic rooms, is too stupid to take off the jacket he is wearing with his name on it. All the crooks had to do was act like they left the hosue to get Foster and her kid out of the panic room. But, no, let's build a story around incredible stupidity. Why do two people need, or for that matter, want a three story house? How ludicrous is that? Makes no sense. Jody foster can afford a three story house in Manhattan, but has to hook up a friggin phone line herself and didn't get it done before the crooks show up. Finally, you can short out a phone line anywhere in the house and it will make the line appear busy to outsiders and be unusable to insiders. Why would mister smart enough to design a panic room have to use a sledge hammer to disable the phone line?! These were a few of the things that took away from my enjoyment of this movie, eliminate those flaws, and it was a neat concept, just poorly done in the details.

David Fincher's previous film; "Fight Club" offered something new and exiting to its audience. It was a critique, a statement not only about consumerist society - but about the state of masculinity. "The Panic Room" seems to me to be more about the entertainment value a thriller creates and forgets about the "message" it transcends.The stereotyping of the different characters makes this film quite predictable - which is a shame. It is a good film when looking away from these issues but the ending spoils the film completely. I am not going to go into details in order to not reveal the plot - but it must be said that I would have expected better from Fincher..

Review title: Awesome; had the whole theater breathless
Review_body: I just saw this movie a few hours ago and LOVED it.  I go to the movies all the time and this was my favorite movie in years.  It may be my favorite movie since American Beauty.  David Fincher is a genius.  His camera work is beautiful.  There were "wow's" from the audience as the camera went through a keyhole or a coffee pot.  The scenes in the elevator when the wall disappears is wonderful.  The plot is not that complicated, but this is one instance where "the criminal with a heart" is successfully pulled off by Forrest Whitaker.Jodie Foster makes a triumphant return to the big screen in this movie. Being a Nicole Kidman fan, I was upset to hear of her departure from this movie.  However, Jodie was wonderful.  The entire cast was wonderful.ONE FINAL NOTE:  COMIC RELIEF --- Some of you may remember this term from high school english and this film is a perfect example of it.  It is used perfectly throughout to relieve tension.  Without it, the film would have been overbearing.SEE IT AND BUY IT WHEN AVAILABLE!!

This film is really underrated, and that is really evident by the fact that it inst available on bluray. I love the camera moves and he acting on display here. For any Fincher fan, this is an essential watch.

Review_body: This movie was the best movie I have seen in a VERY long time. Well worth the hype! It kept me on the edge of my theater seat at all times and was Jodie Foster's best work since Silence of the Lambs.  I feel that this will be in the theaters for a long time, so please go check it out.

I was in awe with how this movie was shot. It was visually such a beautiful experience. Even the violence was beautifully done. My favorite shot is when Raoul is coming at Jodie Foster with the sledgehammer, because the lighting and camerawork is so smooth and well-done. Fincher employs a lot of panning and zoom-shots and they're almost all amazing. It's a really interesting technique and really elevates the film.You can nitpick and say that the plot isn't that revolutionary. Yeah, it's not all that original. But, it IS entertaining, and Jodie Foster cements herself yet again as a great actress.Long story short, this movie is great, and I'll probably watch it again.

I would first like to point out that this movie is the perfect example of the genius that is David Fincher.  No other director that I can think of of the top of my head, except perhaps Ridley Scott, could have successfully adapted this type of a story to the silver-screen, let alone make it as GOOD as he did. This is, to put it short, the most suspenseful film I have ever watched. Upon leaving the theater I was so tense that I felt like yelling as loud as I could to vest the feeling.  And I loved ever second of it.  From the first five minutes, until the credits began to roll, not a single sound came from the audience witnessing the spectacle.  Not one.  Not a cough, not a laugh, not a clearing of a throat. The entire crowd was caught in Fincher's brilliance. He has, perhaps, out done himself.  I cannot possible imagine how he will ever be able to top this movie.  But, I pray he does. He seems, with every movie he has released, to improved on aspects from the one before. Se7en was much better than Alien3, The Game, though not better in my opinion, showed him experimenting and trying to make it better.  Fight Club was a major improvement cinematography wise(and to some, plot wise) from all predecessor's, and now, Panic Room, in my opinion, has topped them all in every aspect.  My recommendation is that you watch it.  Then watch it again. You'll like it even more the second time.  Trust me. 10/10

I knew this movie was coming up in last night's sneak preview and I was eager to see it, knowing it was directed by David Fincher, whom has made beauties such as 'Se7en', 'The Game' and 'Fight Club'. And I must say: the movie didn't let me down! It is a solid story about a mother and daughter spending the first night in their new house. A house that isn't really something out of the ordinary except for one peculiar room: a panic room, used in cases of emergency to seek shelter in. It has everything on the inside to keep one alive: survival goods, cameras with views on every angle in the house, a separate phoneline and ventilation system, plus steel walls and a steel door. On that first night three men are breaking in and the mother and daughter seek refuge in the panic room with no means to get out.. The movie is basically a dark thriller which has its funny moments, set in just this one house, delivered by a well-chosen cast.The camerawork is simply fantastic once again: through floors, inside keyholes, etc. David Fincher is a true master when it comes to innovative handling of a camera. Plus his choice of colors, entourage and timing is superb.All in all: a very nice, straightforward thriller [no plot twists at the end or whatever] revolving around an intriguing concept: a room that no one can get in to or out of..

Jodie Foster stars as a recent divorcee who moves in with her daughter to a "townstone" house on the Upper West Side of NYC.  She quickly finds that the house has a hidden "panic room;" a fallout shelter for rich eccentrics. When three robbers look to find some hidden treasure, Foster, and daughter Kristen Stewart, have the room as their only means of survival. Foster is spectacular in her finest role since Nell, and Stewart is her match as her precocious daughter.    Forest Whitaker, and, especially, Dwight Yoakam are standouts as, respectively, the conscientious and psychotic thieves, though Jared Leto is over-the-top.  Fincher's direction towers over a weak script by David Koepp, creating real tension out of a contrived situation.  A winner. ***1/2 out of four.

Jodie Foster has done it again, a star role in another intense thriller. Dealing with her recent separation, Meg and her daughter purchase a plush home in New York.  This four-story home is a complete package deal, combining the modern conveniences of its own elevator with the door prop locks of yester year.  A panic room is another luxury, with TVs hooked up to the home security system, a phone that is not hooked to the main line of the house, and a steel door with motion sensors.Just before going to sleep, Meg disables her high tech security system, allowing the intruders easy access.  She is able to get her daughter and flee to the panic room.  And realizes she forgot to have the "other" phone line hooked up.  After futile attempts via the intercom to convince the intruders to leave, they tell her the only thing they want is inside the panic room.  The story unfolds, will the intruders find a way into the panic room, how long can the girls last in the panic room, what exactly is it the intruders want?This movie is edge of your seat, covering your eyes, peaking in-between your fingers, and not wanting to miss what will happen next.  Simply put, not a horror flick but a great suspense movie.  Go see it for yourself.
