Review title: Brilliantly done, as if I expected anything else from Fincher.
Review_body: As David Fincher is one of my favorite directors (next to Kubrick, Scorsese, and Coppola), I was anticipating this movie's release for months. I saw it tonight and was absolutely blown off my feet. Now, let me assure you that this is not your typical "thriller", as I knew it wouldnt be. This was not a movie theater teen slash movie that you'd go to with a girlfriend or boyfriend, with little stupid suspenseful scenes where the person hears something and turns around and its just their little brother coming downstairs for a drink of water. No, its not like that. With even a plot as simply thought as Panic Room's, Fincher refuses to give in and sign the teen slasher cheesy directing paper. He scared me with simply the theme of the movie. He constantly reminded me what was going on in the film, and how petrified I know I'd be if I were in Meg's (Jodie Foster) position. I guarantee all of you reading this that this movie would not be as scary as it is if it wasnt Fincher in the director's chair. The fear he puts on the characters' faces, the way he set up the whole story through the camera, and especially his camera placement and movement. He throws in all of his unique directing trademarks, most of which will remind you of Fight Club, and does them all the right times. The camera placement and movement alone scared me. I will now say that Fincher is one of the most thought provoking directors in the movie world. He makes his movies come alive, and with simply his angles, timing, and movement of the camera in coordination with the characters makes you think. Perhaps I'm speaking a little too deeply here. Fincher fans should understand what I'm talking about, especially after you see this, unless you already havent. This movie is strongly strongly recommended. I'd definately pay another 8.50 to see it again... in fact I'm considering going again tomorrow with a friend who wants to see it. David Fincher will one day be recognized as one of our greatest filmmakers, as long as he keeps making films like this.

Review title: A gruff woman, tom-boy daughter, and 3 Buffoons...
Review_body: A gruff woman, her tom-boyish daughter, and three buffoons trapped in a house-those are practically the only characters you are going to be watching for the entire two hours of the movie.  The three buffoons want to get into the panic room, which Meg(Jodi Foster) and Sarah Altman(Kristen Stewart). One might think that premise would become dull after the first 20 minutes, but interesting camera shots due to the directing of David Fincher(also director of Fight Club), extremely good acting by Jodi Foster, and the comic relief of bad-guy criminals, the film remained interesting all the way through.

as the movie progressed  it took on  a HOME ALONE  type of feeling.  It was not a scary or chilling movie but one with the traditional hollywood action scenes.  Even the ending was never satisfactorily explained as to how it came about.  I give it 2 1/2 stars

This movie will entertain but that's about it.  I found it harder to watch after the 911 person asked her to please hold.  If this is common practice, than call ME stupid.  They only reason I saw this is that I got a free coupon when it was out of stock.  I wouldn't pay for it.  Keep an eye on the sledgehammer that Foster totes around(Damn she's strong).

David Fincher has the style and technique that gives a visually impressive and immersive experience, but without the "knock your socks off" story the impact is diminished. It seems that Fincher gets a rather less than spectacular story for every other film he makes, starting with his first film and it leaves the audience less than blown away. Alien 3 looked good and was a solid effort, but the viewer didn't leave the theatre cheering the way his follow up Se7en did. Then his next "tween" film, The Game had an interesting premise, but lacked the "what the hell is going on" twist and turns that made Fight Club the much loved story it was.Here now we have  Panic Room which in my humble opinion continues this trend by telling a rather simple tale that really leaves you simply asking yourself, "How are they going to get out of this one?" instead of "What the hell is going to happen next?" With Alien3, The Game and now Panic Room we pretty much know where this story is going it's just a matter of how we get there whereas Se7en and Fight Club in the end left us in awe, slightly dizzy and numb from the trip we had just been on.Panic Room (and Alien and The Game for that matter) is a 1st rate suspense-thriller that carries the audience through the whole film without any snags and delivers a much better than average film.The cast was top notch and though we've seen most of these actors in many other films they left any hint of their former movie identities at home and delivered totally new and convincing performances. My only gripe is with such genre blowing titles as Se7en and Fight Club under his belt you'd think Fincher would be searching for a much more amazing tale to tell.

Just a moment to share my thought on the new film Panic Room. I happened to get a pass to an advance screening of it, and the US release date is March 29th (2 weeks from now). Many people (including myself) liked Fight Club and will probably go see Panic Room in part because it's directed by the same guy.I have to recommend against paying money to see this movie.For those of you who don't know, the basic plot :A mother and daughter move into a house that was owned by a reclusive multi-millionaire. The house comes with a "panic room", a safe room adjacent to the master bedroom which is intended to keep the person safe in case of home invasion. Of course, shortly after moving in, there is just such a home invasion.The fundamental problem with this film is that it isn't plausible. In order for a dramatic situation to be suspenseful, the audience has to be able to imagine that actual events would unfold as they unfold in the film. This is not the case with "Panic Room," and neither nice cinematography or solid performances from two (Stewart and Whitaker) of the five leads can save it.Example :The mother and daughter are in the panic room. They're unable to call the police because they haven't hooked up the extra phone line, but the bad guys can't get in because the room is encased in steel and concrete. The bad guys try to think of a way to put pressure on the people inside, and knock holes in the wall. Luckily for them, the ventilation duct for the room is easily accessible behind a thin layer of drywall. The bad guys make use of this to pump propane gas into the room, causing a crisis.This crisis is only exciting if one can imagine a world in which a paranoid millionaire pays tens of thousands of dollars to construct a steel and concrete safe room, wire cameras to it, stock it with supplies, etc. etc., and then ALLOW UNRESTRICTED ACCESS TO THE AIR HE WILL BE BREATHING.There's a long list of similar no-brainer plot holes that you could drive a Budget truck (from Pittsburgh) through. There's lots of bells and whistles and the script/direction keeps the movie going, but the real excitement of a thriller like this lies in imagining "what would I do in this situation?" However, you could never be in this situation, because this movie is not set in the real world that you and I share. The movie even makes hip self-aware nods to some of the most obvious plot holes, but referencing them without explaining them only serves to make them more glaring.I give it a thumbs down. I don't have a problem suspending disbelief, but I do have a problem suspending rational thought.

Panic room is one of the best looking movie's I have ever seen.  The director did a great job and this movie should definitely be seen only in the theater.  Jared Leto's character was well acted and I thought he was a great bad guy.

Review title: Panic and Terror at ITS Finest
Review_body: Semi~Spoiler* The Movie is based UPON a Woman and Her Daughter who move into a Town Stone. Three Men find Their way in and terrorize the Two Females while They are locked into the PANIC Room that is built into the House which contains a safe that has the MONEY that the BAD Guys want and will do ANYTHING to get IT!! Twists and Turns mixed with laughter along with the Frightening yet funny humour of Dwight Yoakam who plays a very MEAN and Ruthless KILLER!! One Bad Guy survives and though He tries to do good, HE ends up doing real BAD!! A definite MUST See for Intense Action and Suspense and some comedy thrown in too to make this ONE Rounded out Killer Thriller of 2002~

Pretty simple. Meg and her daughter Sarah move into a beautiful old house in Manhattan, right after Meg and her husband get divorced. She notices that one of the rooms are smaller than it should be, and the realtor explains this "Panic Room". A room that is a "safe-haven" for anything that could go wrong. You then have the 3 burglars that break in and try to get something from the house. They are furious because they hadn't planned on Meg moving in yet, just a slight obstacle for them. The movies keeps you on the edge of your seat for most of the time, and has you jumping in some cases. The camera work of David Fincher is absolutely amazing. Anywhere he wanted the camera to go, it went; keyholes, through walls, through floors, anywhere. The only reason I gave the movie a 7 out of 10 is because I found it pretty predictable. Although, still good, I was able to determine what was going to happen long before it actually did. In general, a good movie.

Review title: Exactly where was the suspense supposed to be?
Review_body: Like any other true movie buff, I'm a big David Fincher fan. Regardless of what the academy may think, Fight Club was one of the best movies of all time. However, in Fincher's lasted film (Panic Room) I felt that it lacked a certain edge to it. With this genre, the quality of the film is defined by its ability to take the audience into the eyes of the victim and feel his/her terror. All I really ended up getting out of this film was a soar bum from the theater's seats and a nauxious feeling from the vain attempts at suspense. My advice to anyone going to see this movie is this: We've seen Fincher do suspense before, it was a little mishap called "Alien 3", I'd recomend learning from history and save myself the six bucks.

Tonight, I attended a radio station-sponsored showing of the film.  I left very happy that I had not paid for the experience.  After reading many glowing reports at this site, I was prepared for the "ride of my life".What I viewed was a very well-made film (technically speaking), but with an extremely predictable plot and very little suspense.  The cinematography and acting were excellent, but the film just simply did not pack the punch that I had expected.

I think that the movie was on my average maybe a tad below average scale. It is a good thing I saw it for free because I would rather rent it than spend 8 bucks.  I think that the suspense was overdone.  In many parts such as the cell phone the suspense was good but I think they took it out to long.  It was somewhat predictable what would happen next.  I don't think it was that scary.  I have seen many movies that made me jump more than this one.  I saw it the night before it came out with my sister who works at a theater.  There were even a few parts everyone started to crack up because it was just stupid.  I am not saying that this was a terrible movie I just think that it was somewhat predictable and some suspense was over done.  I would recommend renting it.

panic room compared to Fincher's other flicks doesn't live up to his reputation but has some of his style camera shots that made the hair on the back of my neck stand up.  The movie itself was pretty suspenseful with some boring parts too.  This movie is definately worth seeing on the big screen, but for daytime rates, but catch it and realize why the last scene should be edited out... fatty

Review title: A god of our generation has died today...
Review_body: Panic Room... mere words cannot describe the expectations that have hit rock bottom for me and many others. How can one come from such brilliant works of film (i.e. Seven, The Game, Fight Club...even Alien 3)to this level of plot holes, pop culture references, and comedians posing as villains? I'm sure that there are many people who will walk away from this movie thinking that it was a "good movie", but by whose standards? We all know the type of people that will like this movie; the same people that wait with great anticipation to see any of the cookie cutter movies that are smothering the art we all know as film. It is a shame to see that David Fincher has dropped to this level, and I hope that this is not the caliber of work that we can expect in the future. A word of advice for all viewers who hold Fincher in high esteem, steer clear of this movie if you do not want to become disillusioned.

Review title: Foster and Fincher - A Winning Combination
Review_body: Having set his tone and style with the breakthrough "Fight Club", David Fincher creates another cinematic masterpiece with "Panic Room".  It's the story of a recently divorced woman (Jodie Foster) and her daughter (Kristen Stewart) looking for a home in New York.  They find one and as an added bonus, it has a panic room, a steel lined room with tv monitors, seperate phone line and ventilation system and emergency supplies stocked in it. On the first or second night in the house, three intruders come in, not knowing anyone is living there.  What follows is a stand-off of sorts between the intruders (Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto, and Dwight Yoakam) and the residents of the house, laced with nail-biting, edge of your seat moments of suspense and action. Although not having as many speaking lines as normal, Jodie Foster is brilliant (as usual) and belivably carries the movie and the emotions in the film.  Just her facial expressions are amazing.  Another incredible force in the movie is newcomer Kristen Stewart, who plays Foster's smart-mouthed, tough but sweet, pre-teen daughter.  This being Stewart's first time under the weight of a major role, she handles it with wonderful depth and realism. Not to be forgotten are Forest Whitaker as the oafish burglar, and Dwight Yoakam is a bad guy you love to hate.  Both are memorable, along with Jared Leto as a wannabe thug.  Fincher's inventive camera angles, x-ray vision style, and uniquely-lit sets really set the mood.  He is a powerful director, who has been quite underrated. I loved this movie!  I was on the edge of my seat the whole time and I will definately be going to see it again!

Review title: Glad I got the student discount
Review_body: Panic Room was one of the lamest "thrillers" I've ever seen.  I scare easily, and I was never on the edge of my seat.  The bathrooms in the theater I visited were far more of a horror than the Panic Room.  Jodie Foster wasn't given a chance to shine in this mediocre film. I felt the movie lacked an interesting plot.  I was expecting numerous plot twists with this movie being a "thriller," but I was sorely disappointed.  Just a warning for anyone who plans on seeing the movie, I don't think this is a spoiler, but I guess it was one of the only "surprises" in the movie... the girl stuck in the room has diabetes and needs her insulin!  I didn't see that one coming a mile away, not even after we were shown her insulin monitor in one of the first scenes.  I'm surprised Jodie Foster didn't start having an asthma attack, or even better a "panic attack" as she worried about her daughter because that's the sort of lame thing that would happen in this movie. Panic Room was one of the most predictable and unentertaining movies I have ever seen.  I came into the movie with high expectations, and I left glad that I had only wasted $5.25 on the movie instead of $8.

Panic Room proves to be a very disappointing film in all aspects, except the creepiness factor. Visual "innovation" cannot save uneven plot with characters you don't believe-in for a minute. And that "innovation" means countless camera drives through insides of locks, through the walls, into the glowing fiber of the flashlight ... none of which reveals anything pertinent to the story. What seemed fresh in Fight Club is now used over and over and over ... but without a structure or purpose it really only underlines the weakness of the whole undertaking. Foster seems to be not well in trying to walk a fine acting line between unsecure sheepish mother and soon-to-burst-out ass kicking mental patient. There is a plenty of "I love you's" between mother and daughter characters but you feel no real relationship between the two. Her character's behaviour towards the end of the movie is out of the common sense realm. She knows that she can tell the visiting cops anything she wants because the bad guys have no audio-only pictures while watching them, but follows with a long scene of trying to make the cops believe nothing's wrong in the house. ... there are plenty of opportunities to better their plight, in the last quarter of the movie she's the one with the gun, yet isn't able to use it to her advantage... And of course she hits the bad guy in the head with a big sledgehammer so hard, he falls down to the next floor, only to come back half a minute later for the "finale" Pleeeeaaaasseeee! How could the director believe that by splattering his "style" all over some overworked, formula, made-by-committee  movie, he can save this goulash of superficiality. He created a creepy movie but not scary one. Once you don't believe - you're not afraid.  Well done acting work by Dwight Yoakam as Raul-the really bad guy of the bunch. Forest Whitaker plays, forgettably, the other, - a "big teddy bear" kind of a criminal, "see, he's got problems at home, that's why he breaks into people's houses"... You don't know if you should get him a counselor, fifty bucks or a hug ... Don't waste your time.

Review title: Fincher masters direction, but fails on the ending.
Review_body: So far, David Fincher has made 5 movies.He started with Alien3, then moved on to the excellent 7even. With The Game he showed us a great story, but the ending was too happy to accompany the film.Fight Club brought us back to the gritty with an ending that wasn't happy, but wasn't sad.In Panic Room, he gives us nearly 2 hours of seat gripping, nearly over bearing, suspense, but the last two minutes makes us wonder who slapped it on there.Don't let that stop you from seeing it.  It's not THAT bad.  The movie twists and turns in directions that you'd not see coming, and better yet, while watching, you don't even TRY to think where it's going.  It grabs you and takes you for a ride.The only negative comment I really have to make is the fairly ambiguous ending.  It leaves things unanswered.  Not in a good way like Fight Club where you want to know what will happen next, but in a way that makes you think... so what DID happen?Everyone is superb in this film, Foster, Whitiker, Leto, and yes, Dwight Yoakam.  He portrays a character that you can't hate any more.  It's just not possible.I give the film an 8/10 Better that what it needed to be to be a good suspense film, but lacking in how much story there is.  The concept does limit us to minimal characters and only 1 setting.  But, definitely a good film to see and enjoy.

Review title: Not as great as the reviews make it sound...
Review_body: Before I went to watch The Panic Room, I was extremely psyched and eager to see it and felt like this could be a movie that is worth my $8.50 and that I could not wait 3 months for the DVD to come out.It fell short of my expectations. The psychological twists and turns did not impress me - I was searching for something more along the impact of The Sixth Sense or The Others. I did not find that in this movie. In addition, I have a big problem understanding movies that aim to cross genres and be both a thriller and a comedy.Comedy? Yes, Comedy.No fewer than two dozen times, the audience exploded into laughter as the thieves' characters were more like the stupid robbers in the Home Alone movies. I faught between telling myself that was the point of the movie, and that it was a goof-off on the part of the scriptwriters. As a result, I found it difficult to generally be scared or frightened or thrilled because each and every time, the suspense is interrupted by laughter and silliness.Is it dark humor? I don't think so. It's not so much dark humor as a totally misguided plot. Jodie Foster's character and her daughter's performance are great - they are genuinely scared, but I see no connection between their fright and the robber's silly behavior.To conclude, I felt like laughing and shaking my head at this one.

Mild spoilers ahead...not revealing the ending but events that happen in the movie....
For the most part I liked it until a few things started to creep in and drag the movie down.  The plot seemed forced along in parts, such as the husband showing up on his own to see what was wrong. This IS New York City we're talking about, and the guy's closer to Moses than Van Damme.  You would think after getting an emergency phone call you would wait for the police. Bring a gun or some mace at least. However he does the "Friday the 13th There's danger there let me go have a look" thing. Speaking of old Vorhees the one criminal that gets hit in the head with a sledgehammer, falls over the railing to the ground floor which is several floors down then crawls back up a few minutes later was REALLY Jasonish. Lastly it baffled me why she didn't at least tell the police what her situation was as no audio could get up to the panic room.  Even if it was just to say "You can't come in or they will kill my daughter but here is the situation." Jodie Foster did a good job and most of the movie is pretty good but the things I mentioned really dragged the whole overall rating down in my opinion.

Although I would agree that it was not top-quality work from Fincher, or at least not on the level as his previous films, it is one of the best suspense films i've ever seen.  The storyline was rather straight-foward but it did not take away from the greatness in being a great movie.  At times i could actually feel my heart naturally beating faster at numerous times. Great acting, great flow of events, and even a great ending, which kind of taught a lesson.

i had fun watching the camera, zooming through a key hole or running through the house into a handle grip of a coffee pot,  through a wall or just racing as fast as your own heart rate was racing.i found myself on the edge of my seat, tapping my feet on the floor thinking run, run run Meg!i absolutely loved the movie but sort of dissatisfied with the ending.

I think that this movie had a good story line, and it was fairly easy to follow. Jodie Foster was good, and so was the little girl. The only part that I didnt like about the movie was the stupidity of the criminals and the remarks that they made. Many of the things that they did reminded me of the Home Alone movies... This was a bloodier Home Alone in my eyes..... Sorry if I offended anyone!

After reading many reviews and hearing everyone rant and rave about this movie, I finally decided to check it out.  Boy, do I wish I could get my $8.75 back for this piece of junk. I went in expecting to be thrilled and kept on the edge of my seat like so many people were claiming, but I left the theater baffled and VERY disappointed.You all know the basic plot of the movie (if not, go find out about it), so I don't think I have to go into details on it.  Instead, I'll concentrate on telling you the reasons why I thought this movie sucked.Basically, I didn't find the movie thrilling at all.  Everything that occurs in the movie is SO predictable that you're not thrilled or surprised by anything that happens.  Supposedly though, the whole thrilling part of the movie is supposed to be the idea of you being in Jodie Foster's situation. However, if you're anything like me, you don't have a panic room so it's kind of hard to relate.  In real life, if people break into your house (God forbid), they're going to take what they want and aside from having an alarm system or something, there's pretty much nothing you can do about it.Also, if this were real life and you by chance HAD a panic room, once you locked yourself in the room you're safe.  There would be no reason to go out, no reason to do anything but either wait for the police to come or wait for the robbers to leave.  But since this is a movie, of course there HAS to be some reason for Jodie Foster to leave the room or else the movie would have no point since the room is impenetrable (although last time I checked, steel is far from impenetrable). So the movie throws in ridiculous, predictable excuses for her to leave the room that are there for no other reason than to prolong this sorry excuse for a movie.Finally, the biggest thing that bothered me about the movie was the end scenes.  I don't want to spoil anything for anyone (although the movie is so predictable, there's nothing to spoil about it), so let's just say that someone portrays super-human abilities after having something done to them. When you see the movie, you'll know what I mean.The bottom line is that this movie is nothing but a waste of your time and money.  As one of my friends that saw the movie with me said, "This is basically just an R-rated version of 'Home Alone.'" I couldn't have said it better myself.

Review title: A mother and daughter move into an old house with a panic room. Three invaders come into the house and the mother and daughter are forced into the panic room.
Review_body: Panic Room is a great movie. Jodie Foster is excellent in this role. It's a movie that has you biting your nails or shutting your eyes the whole movie. Kirsten Stewart is also really good. Jodie Foster and Kirsten Stewart have great chemistry.

Panic room was the ultimate thrills and chills. I loved Panic Room. I loved seeing my outstanding 2 actress doing the films (Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart). Panic Room was great with non-stop action leading you off your seat.

Review title: My favorite movie of all time!
Review_body: To start off, the beginning credits are awesome alone.  That started off the movie well.  I like how it gets really quick into the story.  There are hardly ever any slow parts except for the beginning a little.  I loved the camera work.  The best camera work I've seen in any movie.  Acting from everyone was excellent.  The end of the move was also neat too.  Great job!

I went to see this film because i was impressed by the earlier movies the director made (not going to name them, think everybody knows them) but what a big disappointment. Jodie Foster did to try to make the film work but (just like the other actors) but the script was just lame. Nice concept but no eye for details. For instance the scene when she found out the cell phone didn't work in the room.Fair enough, that could happen in real life, but at the moment she got out of the room to get the stuff she needed to aid her daughter she didn't use her cellphone! Make a call, cops arrive  , everybody safe. Maybe i am just whining to much but there were more scences like this that just irritated me. The only reason i gave 4/10 points is because of the great camera job. Really looked impressive the way the camera just slided through the walls and ceilings.

This movie really doesn't make any sense. I started watching it on TV when it was like busy for 15 minutes, but anyway, the story is that a woman and her daughter moved into a new house, and burglars come to rob it and then they hide in a panic room. Well, the first thing i saw: Who the hell sleeps with the lights on and someone who has diabetes, already passes out if she doesn't get a shot in an hour??. If you read some other comments you see a lot more stuff that just isn't right. This movie is so unrealistic and really no excitement at all. I laughed at parts i actually had to be shocked. Really, do yourself a favor and don't hire/buy/watch this movie.

The best work of Fincher. Not a little thing to say. Make yourself a favor and see this movie without interruptions or any unwanted company. Every line, every shot is a vital part of the plot and put you through another Fincher movie experience.

Ok, that's the best film I've seen recently. (Not counting The Others, but that's another story.) And I just can't see the problem of some people. (Possible SPOILERS ahead.) I just start hating the world "cliché". Yes, I admit that there are many clichés in the world of films, and yes, some of them are REALLY annoying. But hey, wake up! People make films for 100+ years! That means a lot of films! Thus it gets harder and harder day by day to make a really original story of which no one can say it's "clichéd" (I think it is impossible). The most important thing - for me - is simple: Panic Room can stand on its own. And it has no real faults.I don't want to repeat others, but it seems that I have to for some. Yes, the burglars made some stupid mistakes, but hey, they aren't professionals and they are REAL men - not all criminals are "Die Hard"!  And yes, Foster had to be a little bit "MacGyver" and yes, his daughter had to be diabetic, because we wanted an interesting and exciting film - if you would make Panic Room with my sister and her daughter, believe me, it wouldn't be near that entertaining! And the little things... Why is that ventillation system accessible from the inside? Because the panic room isn't a prison for God's sake, its designers were not thinking about cut phone lines and criminals just wanting to get in there! (But anyway, there were that other tube leading to fresh air.) And the cameras... So simple. At the start they were the only way of two-way communication. After that they just wanted to frighten the women so it made sense to let them see what they are up to. Maybe later it would be wiser to set them off but they just forget it (they aren't perfect and they were in a stress).All in all: Panic Room is a great film, 10/10.

Review title: Most unrealistic plot line since Friday 13th part 89
Review_body: Let me start by saying that I am a Jodie Foster fan. The acting in this film is acceptable enough but the plot line is completely idiotic. The bad guys here are too stupid to make it as far as Dumb Crook News. As if they would kill her daughter with the cops standing outside the panic room even if she had let the cops in. Forget about suspension of disbelief since a teenage horror movie is more believable! I won't give away the "surprise" ending in case you are dumber than the crooks and want to waste your money but my advice is that you find a better use for your dollars. Flushing them down the toilet would be one better choice.

Review title: Nice camera work in just another thriller
Review_body: Good camera work but a very predictable plot. Frustratingly tedious situations and toe curling stupidity as often seen in thrillers. It seems hard to deviate from the trodden path of excessive violence induced by predictable behavior of the victims... If you have friends over, spend the night talking about things that matter in life; don't waste their time on this movie...

Review title: One of the worst movies of all times. Why would Jodie Foster do this?
Review_body: My summary says it all. From a predictable plot to stupid things people do there is hardly any suspense in this movie.  There is no motivation for the actions of any of the characters, no sympathy, anger, or any feelings except loss at wasting 112 minutes watching this film.  Other than this it was fine.
This is the worst and most BORING movie I ever seen. Nothing really happens from the start to the end. It was predictable and just BORING!!! Dont ever see this stupid movie. !!! WARNING !!!

The Panic Room is essentially the story of a jilted wife, newly divorced from her wealthy, philandering husband and her young daughter having to fend for themselves and fight off three intruders the night they move into their new large brownstone on the upper west side of Manhattan.  The only place of refuge that they can turn to is the "panic room" - a room built for any sort of emergency to seal them off inside and keep them safe from whatever lurks beyond - an impenetrable fortress of concrete and steel.  The intruders in the meantime wreak havoc on the house trying to get into that room and a tale of cat and mouse follows.  Given the whole idea of a panic room and the premise of outwitting three seriously dangerous men in your home leaves open such a vast array of opportunity for twists and turns and suspense in a movie.Now, all that being said, I would like to say that I was disappointed with this film, but I can't as I found myself too lackadaisical to be able to ever get disappointed.  Technically proficient this movie certainly was, but I pin this waste of time on the writer, David Koepp and whoever the hell the producers were on this film.  Jodie Foster as Meg Altman turns in a wonderful performance, when does she ever seem to fall short as an actress? Her daughter, played by Kristen Stewart was also quite good and David Fincher as a director, well, he's just magic.  You give that man a camera and he settles for nothing less than perfection.  However I have a suggestion for the studios regarding Mr. Fincher - why don't you try giving him a top A list script.  Hell, I don't know, maybe have William Goldman stir one up for him, but for God's sake, do something because to see such a stellar actress and such a phenomenal director deliver all the way round and still have the story be so-so - well, the blames on the executives and the people who were supposed to be producing this thing.  I looked up the budget on Imdb as soon as I finished viewing it, and to find out it cost 48 million nearly made me choke.  Yeah, movie budgets are soaring through the roof nowadays, but please, for close to 50 mil, I want suspense, and I want plot twists that I don't expect and there wasn't much here that I wasn't already anticipating way ahead of time.  I voted a 7 and I really think that's too high but I did so only because of Foster and Fincher - afterall, why should they suffer for something that wasn't their fault.Oh, and by the way, Jared Leto is soooooo two dimensional in this film - what was he thinking?  And actually, what was Fincher thinking putting him in the role?  Villains can be very complex and they can be three dimensional, hell - real life ones are.  Leto, on the other hand, spends half his time whining and the other half screaming and never does it come across as anything deeper going on in him.  Dwight Yoakim is slightly up the food chain from Leto, but on an acting level he's still superficial.  The only one that holds up is Burnham, played by Forest Whitaker.  He shows that it's possible to take a part of a burglar and have conflicts and criminality at the same time as having humanity.  Perhaps if the other villains had been as good as him it may have helped the story not seem so robotic in it's style.All in all, I would say it's not a bad movie, but if you're looking for a good thriller, I would not recommend this film.  The only recommend I would give for this film is if you're killing time watching cable.  Above and beyond that, it just doesn't do enough to warrant much more.  And not to nag, but will somebody please give David Fincher a great script, finally???

I have never wished that bad for a movie to end.Nothing happens, they stay in their panic room during the whole movie while people want to get inside to get some millions dollars inside.  we don't know why there are millions of dollars in there and quite honestly, you don't want to know in the end.I just wish I haven't wasted my 3$ to rent the movie.  Buying three chocolate bars would have been MUCH GREATER!

This is by far of of the best movie i've ever ever seen! My two favorites, Kristen bell and Jodie Foster. What a thriller! My heart is still pumping! 2 thumbs up! My favorite part was when the black guy shot the crazy white guy. I jumped out of my chair and almost cried. Lol. I don't recommend this movie for kids younger then 13 unless they are mature or not easily scared. This movie will surely get your heart pumping. Especially when the mom was trying to get her phone. Im not gonna say what happened but I will say I lost most of my fingernails chewing them off. I can see why people don't comment that much. Its so freaking long

Review title: Great movie "Doesn't give you the ending on a silver platter."
Review_body: I loved the movie. I can't believe the negative reviews, but I guess you can have your own opinion. I didn't really think of any mistakes in the plot or otherwise. I think that the acting was great too.Even though the whole story is staged mainly in one place, I was never bored at all watching it. I especially liked how the ending was not completely definitive, making you THINK: what would happen.Definitely worth a watch at the least.

It is my opinion that the director of this film, David Fincher needs a lot more experience or better yet just pack it in.  Just look at the other dogs, "Seven", The Game, Fight club and one more I can't remember.Where does he get the money to back him up in making this crap....

I thought it would be a movie worth watching since Jodie Foster and Forest Whitaker were in it. It is a waste of time. The main character, acted by Jodie Foster, is pretty weak and incompetent, who finally realized she had a cell phone in the bedroom, more than half way thru the movie. Also, she's trapped in a room and doesn't know what's in it. What exactly is she spending her time while in the safe room. Make an inventory.She knows how important her daughter's medical condition is but doesn't look to see if there is food until it is almost too late. She falls for a stupid trick. She really needs to be more careful. She really should first call the police when she first gets out. Where exactly is her cell phone...I didn't even watch the last 30 minutes when the cops showed up at the door. I am going to assume that she thought it best not to tell them to keep them "safe". This movie grossed millions for the new and different plot but definitely not for common sense of the "victim".

Review title: One of the worst movies I've ever seen!
Review_body: First of all, how did it cost 48 million dollars to make this piece of garbage? I can only remember one or two movies in my life where I felt so uninterested and bored. Honestly the only thing that sticks in my mind about the movie is the opening credits - where the 1 star comes from. Drama: 0%, Suspense: 0%. The only emotional reaction I had in the movie was rolling my eyes a few times at how silly it was. I must admit that I like FW as an actor but even in this movie it seems he was miscast. The crooks are running around like the keystone cops - was this some kind of attempt at comedy? I really really wish I could have my 2 hours back to watch my lawn grow.

Review title: Excellent film making, camera-work and enough suspense and tension to power a steam train!
Review_body: The majority of people who have seen 'Panic Room' have given it positive feedback. I've just bought it on DVD and have watched it previously. It's a film that you can watch and enjoy through out. Great performances from Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart strengthen the story and creates that 'close your eyes suspense'. Never boring and always exciting to watch, 'Panic Room' is a universal film that appeals to the action/thriller genre fanatic. The camera-work is a CSI esquire 'zoom in' 'zoom out' style. Excellent and realistic subtle special effects draws you deeper and is not over the top like other films. 10/10 because throughly enjoyed it to the end and is one of my favourite films. Good enough to buy!

Review title: Film Makers SHOULD HAVE Risked $3.5 Million for Alternate Ending
Review_body: The plot was outstanding; the acting was outstanding; the digital graphics were outstanding; the sound, the lighting, the overall feel was definitely outstanding; however, one thing still looms in the overall satisfactory residual effects of this film - The Ending.Unlike most motion pictures, this particular film contains no real ending. It doesn't leave a cliffhanger as hint to a 'part two'; it doesn't even leave with any real conclusion. All that we know is that Jodi Foster's character & her daughter survived. We don't know what happened with the father, with the remaining robber, with the millions in bonds, etc.This movie leaves an excited viewer feeling completely balked.I believe that a lot more excitement would've followed this movie around for years and possibly gained quite a devoted following had it actually been granted with some form of ending.All of the actors delivered "stunning performances", but were left in the cold with no resolution.I don't recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys seeing a movie through until the bitter end (nor 'happy' end); there is none here.-KT Pierce; Auburn, AL

Review title: Very good movie! Thank you Fincher!
Review_body: While looking to find more movies in the style of Se7en i realised i never saw Panic Room when i came out, but i do remember it being released. I'm glad I finally watched. It was really good, smart and enjoyable film in a gritty style.10/10

Review title: Great movie - a response to the message board filling up with stupid comments.
Review_body: Honestly, I watched this movie from start to finish without any storyline discrepancies. I'm amazed at some of the things people have come up with to complain about. The intruders could not simply leave the house even for a short time because that leaves Meg (Jodie Foster) and daughter Sarah free to wander the house. One could remain in the panic room, eyes on the criminals now outside (thanks to the outside cameras) while another gets a mobile phone, shout across to neighbours, hell even make an escape by taking as long as is needed to undo the barricades previously set  so long as there is ample warning time if the criminals decide to come back in, which the person in the panic room could provide. The situation goes in favor of our heroes once the criminals take the defensive  any lengthy amount of time can be used to their advantage to do whatever they want in the house, including calling the cops, which would defuse the entire situation. The criminals therefore must stay on the offensive; thinking of ways to get them out or lingering nearby the panic room entrance. The also could NOT have waited for them to 'starve to death', which would take weeks given the food supply (they did not know about Sarah's condition), as somebody somewhere would have noticed. As you mention there are cameras in most places but not everywhere. I can guarantee there would be cameras at each entrance/exit, so the "we escaped (but are actually hiding)" trick would have no effect. Even more ridiculous is the user review on this movie that states the robbers could leave he premises and return when they Meg goes "to work". That would be a great idea, because there would be ample time to call the entire state police department the guard the area. Sigh. Think before you write stupid things. The single mother and daughter were able to afford it, as touched on, hmm. many times during the film, the husband was rich and, as stated in the first five minutes of this film, "He could afford it". The SWAT team arrived as a result of gunshots and general loud noises. They had been called before that morning so a second call from multiple people (probably different ones too) would have a greater effect. Anyway, enough bashing people's stupid ideas. I thought it was an ace movie and just how a panic room should be portrayed. A safe as can be humanly created, but once the slightest thing goes wrong in the most intense situation, you can kiss your panic room mentality goodbye. From start to end I enjoyed this flick.

I saw this movie when it was aired on national TV last night. I think Kristen Stewart (who played Sara)was brilliant in Cold Creek Manor, and seeing that she starred in this film, was what attracted me to it. The film is about a mother (Meg Altman) and her daughter (Sara Altman) who buy an enormous townhouse, complete with working elevator and a full security PANIC ROOM, in Manhatten. However on the first night in the house, three armed robbers break in an attempt to steal a fortune which they think is theirs by rights. Unfortunately, Meg wakes up and realises what is happening. She and Sara only have one chance to survive. So the claustrophobic mother, and the diabetic daughter take refuge in the panic room. Sure, with four concrete walls, a reinforced steel door between them and the robbers, as well as monitors that allow them to see every room of the house, they seem pretty safe. But when they realise that the robbers are staying put, things start to go wrong. The Panic Room is more of a Prison Room. It gripped me the entire way through, it seemed so real, so possible, that I had real trouble sleeping afterwards!
Full of plot holes, bad scripts and ridiculous physics this film is suitable for a cult comedy following. Watch it with friends for a laugh but not as a thriller

The majority of the movie was not genius or even well thought out...but there was an element of suspense in most of the scenes that I actually did enjoy(although I wonder if it's genuine suspense, or if you feel that way because the actors are doing all but *saying* that's how you should be feeling...) I would have rated the film higher if the ending wasn't such a LETDOWN!!! They waste all this time making Forrest Whitaker into a good-bad guy, with no cherry on top! Does he die? Does he get arrested? Does Jodi save him? All we're left with is Jodi's "I just smelled a fart" look, then BAM! On to finding another flat! No payoff! Sure, some films like to leave the ending open to interpretation...but I don't think this qualifies as a successful attempt at that. Characters are supposed to grow and change by the film's end...in this film we're left at the exact same place we started...with Jodi and her kin seeking a home. Blah, why bother with the rest of the film if their greatest driving force in life is finding a Brownstone? The more I think about it, the more I dislike this movie. I want my two hours back.

This movie Panic Room about a single mom and her diabetic daughter's fight to get through a night of terror is amazing! After buying a house in New York following a hard divorce they are greeted on their first night in the house with 3 burglars who know something about their house that they don't. This movie was fast paced and kept me on the edge of my seat the whole time. Highly recommend it for any audience that enjoys action!

Out of all my favorite movies, this has to be around #3. True, it does start out kind of slow to introduce the characters and how they act/are. As soon as the killers are in, it's a question of what to do next? This movie really makes you want to lock your doors at night. I really like the choice of criminals: the true-Mofia guy (Raoul), the one who wants the money (Junior) and the one that needs the money (Vernom/Bernom). It was a shame how the last part of the movie was, since we never really did get to see what happened with Vernom (or Bernom, I never could tell). He didn't get the money, had to kill a guy to save a life, and then go to jail.. that is, if Meg didn't tell them he was a good guy. It makes you wonder what she would say, though. "He's my body guard," or "He's a friend of mine," doesn't seem like a cop would believe. I really question what Meg did that made the cops come back. Nonetheless, this whole movie is about 'What comes next?' A lot of questions are left unanswered, but sometimes that makes a great movie. It made this one even more awesome. Jodie Foster, Dwight Yokam, Jared Leto, and Forest Whitaker should get a standing ovation.

Review title: The credits are the best part
Review_body: The credits are the best part, like many David Fincher films. OK, so its a bit formulaic, but the actors really make it work. It takes awhile to get started, but once it does, the suspense and mystery is undeniable. Many reviewers complained that the script was weak, I agree to some extent, but even with an unspectacular script this is still a very watchable thriller. If you think it's difficult to forgive the way this film grabs you, there are other ways to like it. The story, even clichéd, is still interesting and suspenseful. The best part of the movie, though, is the credits, which are not even as good as those Fincher used in Se7ven, which is a better movie, his best probably, better than Fight Club, go see that.
